questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a previous history of deep vein thrombosis presents to the medical department with complaints of dizziness, abdominal pain, anorexia, palpitations, and shortness of breath on exertion. He has pallor, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 105/min, his respiration rate is 28/min, and his blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. He has mild abdominal distention and swelling in his legs. Upon duplex ultrasonography, a diagnosis of inferior vena cava (IVC) obstruction has been made. Which of the following veins is a tributary of the IVC?
questions.solution:
Option A: Right gonadal vein

  • It is a tributary of inferior vena cava.
  • In adults, the right gonadal vein directly enters the inferior vena cava on the right anterolateral aspect about two cm inferior to the left renal vein. Both the right and left gonadal veins can be replaced by other vessels in the lower abdomen and occasionally remain double until their termination.

Option B: Splenic vein

  • It is the tributary of the portal vein.
  • The splenic vein travels medially below the splenic artery and posterior to the tail and body of the pancreas.
  • Anterior to the left kidney and abdominal aorta crosses the posterior abdominal wall. Posterior to the neck of the pancreas, it joins the superior mesenteric vein to form the portal vein and end its tributary.

Option C: Left supra renal vein

  • It is the tributary of the renal vein.
  • The left supra renal vein drains into the left renal or left inferior phrenic vein.

Option D: Left gonadal vein

  • The left gonadal vein terminates in the left renal vein. It is more prone to developing venous incompetence than the right gonadal vein.

questions.text: Which of the following function is performed by the external oblique muscle?

choices.text: Anterior flexion of the vertebral column

questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • The external oblique is the most superficial muscle of the anterior abdominal wall.
  • It originates from the outer part of the 5th to 12th ribs on each side of the rib cage.
  • This muscle then runs diagonally down each side and connects to the iliac crest, linea alba, and the pubis.
  • Functions include:
    • External oblique contributes to maintaining abdominal tone, increasing intra-abdominal pressure (as in active expiration), and lateral flexion of the trunk against resistance.
    • Bilateral contraction flexes the trunk forward and aids in the movement of the spine and back.
    • Contraction of external oblique muscle approximates the two crura (medial and lateral) of the superficial inguinal ring like a slit valve to maintain the integrity of the inguinal canal.

Option A: Anterior flexion of vertebral column

  • External oblique also causes anterior flexion of the vertebral column when its bilateral contraction flexes the trunk forward and aids in the movement of the spine and back.

Option B: Active expiration

  • External oblique contributes to increasing intra-abdominal pressure to help in active expiration.

Option C: Closure of inguinal ring

  • Contraction of external oblique muscle approximates the two crura (medial and lateral) of the superficial inguinal ring like a slit valve to maintain the integrity of the inguinal canal.

questions.text: What is the attachment of Membranous Scarpa's fascia during inguinal hernia repair surgery?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fascia lata of the thigh

  • The patient presented above in the scenario has an indirect inguinal hernia for which he is undergoing repair surgery. In this condition, the abdominal contents protrude through the inguinal canal into the scrotum. It is present lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • It mostly appears as a bulge in the groin region and may get painful when the contents of the canal get strangulated.
  • The superficial fascia of the abdomen is divided into a superficial fatty layer (fascia of Camper) and a deep membranous layer (Scarpa’s fascia).
  • The membranous layer is thin and extends laterally and above, where it becomes continuous with the superficial fascia of the back and the thorax.
  • Inferiorly, the membranous layer passes into the front of the thigh, where it fuses with the fascia lata of the thigh (deep fascia) a few centimetres beneath the inguinal ligament.
  • The membranous fascia layer forms a tubular sheath for the penis or clitoris in the inferior midline and is not attached to the pubis. It then passes to be attached on each side to the margins of the pubic arch, referred to as the Colles' fascia.
  • Posteriorly, it fuses with the posterior margin of the perineal membrane and the perineal body.

Option A: Inguinal ligament

  • It is a band of connective tissue formed by the inferior margin of the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle.
  • Laterally it is attached to the anterior superior iliac spine. Then it curves downward and medially to be attached to the pubic tubercle.
  • It forms a boundary of the femoral triangle and inguinal canal.

Option C: Conjoint tendon

  • The internal oblique muscle has a lower free border that arches over the spermatic cord and then descends behind it to be attached to the pubic crest and the pectineal line.
  • Near their insertion, the lowest tendinous fibres are joined by fibres from the transverse abdominis to form the conjoint tendon.
  • The conjoint tendon is attached to the linea alba medially but has a free lateral border.

Option D: Pubic crest

  • The pubic crest is medial to the pubic tubercle and extends to the medial end of the pubic bone.
  • The conjoint tendon, rectus abdominis, external oblique muscle and the pyramidalis muscle are attached to the pubic crest.
  • The junction between the pubic crest and the medial border of the bone is called the pubic symphysis.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his parents reporting sudden onset of severe right-sided testicular pain. He is irritable and not settling because of pain. His examination revealed a high placement of the right testicle compared to the left one. A diagnosis of right-sided testicular torsion is made. Which of the following structures are not a component of the spermatic cord in males?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ilio-inguinal nerve

The contents of the spermatic cord are shown below:

 

  • Ilio-inguinal nerve is not a content of the spermatic cord.
  • The spermatic cord is a paired structure whose main function is to suspend the testis inside the scrotum.
  • It consists of the structures that allow the testis to function normally. It includes the ductus deferens, arterial and venous blood vessels, lymphatic vessels, and nerves for the testis and its covers.
  • The spermatic cord contains:
    • Testicular artery
    • Ductus deferens
    • Genital branch of Genito femoral nerve.
    • Pampiniferous plexus of veins.
    • Remains of processus vaginalis
    • Artery to ductus deferens

Option A: Ductus deferens

  • It is a content of spermatic cord s
  • so it is a true statement.

Option B: Testicular artery

  • It is one of the contents of the spermatic cord.

Option D: Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve

  • It is a content of the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following lymph node groups is considered a terminal axillary lymph node?
questions.solution:
Option D: Apical

  • The apical group of lymph nodes is the terminal axillary lymph nodes.
  • Lymphatic drainage of axillary lymph nodes
  • Anterior, posterior, lateral → central → apical → infra clavicular → supraclavicular → right jugular trunk → right lymphatic duct → right jugular subclavian venous angle
  • The apical lymph nodes comprise 6 to 12 lymph nodes, so it is located posterior to the superior part of the pectoralis minor muscle extending to the apex of the axilla.
  • It lies medial to the axillary vein.

Option A: central

  • Central axillary lymph nodes are not terminal lymph nodes in the axilla.

Option B: lateral

  • The Lateral lymph nodes are not the terminal lymph nodes in the axilla, so this option is also wrong.

Option C: Anterior

  • The anterior lymph nodes are not the terminal in the axilla, so this option is wrong.

questions.text: The upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, supplying the skin overlying the posterior border of the deltoid muscle,  is a branch of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Axillary nerve

  • The upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm is a branch of the Axillary nerve

Musculocutaneous nerve

  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm is a branch of the Musculocutaneous nerve

Radial nerve

  • Medial Antebrachial Cutaneous Nerve is a branch of the Radial nerve

Ulnar nerve

  • The median and ulnar nerves carry cutaneous sensory fibers for the skin of the palmar side of the hand

Learning Objective

  • General Rule
    • Upper Body Will Have Upper Root Value/Upper Dermatomes
    • Lower Body Will Have Lower Root Value/ Lower Dermatomes

cutaneous nerve of forearm - Wikipedia" />

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department after a fall from a tree house 1 hour ago. He complains of pain in his left arm. Physical examination reveals reduced sensations over the lateral part of the arm and weakness of abduction at 15-90 degrees. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus
Tearing of the Teres major muscle
Inferior dislocation of the head of the humerus

questions.solution:
Option D: Inferior dislocation of the head of the humerus

  • The patient presents with injury to the axillary nerve.
  • Inferior dislocation of the head of the humerus may damage the axillary nerve.
  • The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • It runs through the quadrangular space accompanied by the posterior humeral circumflex vessels around the surgical neck of the humerus.
  • It supplies sensations to the lateral part of the arm via the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm.
  • It supplies the deltoid and teres minor.
  • An articular branch supplies the glenohumeral joint.
  • The deltoid is responsible for 15-90 degrees of abduction.
  • Damage to the axillary nerve causes the loss of both these functions along with the flattened shape of the deltoid/shoulder.

Option A: Injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus

  • The lateral cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to the lateral root of the median nerve, the musculocutaneous nerve, the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, and the lateral pectoral nerve.
  • The lateral cord branches contribute to the medianMedian Nerve from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages"> and musculocutaneous nerve
  • The musculocutaneous nerve innervates the biceps brachii, coracobrachialis, and brachialis muscle
  • It is, therefore, primarily responsible for the flexion of the forearm.

Option B: Supracondylar fracture of humerus

  • Supracondylar humeral fractures are a common pediatric elbow injury but rarely seen in adults.
  • The most common mechanism of injury is falling on an outstretched hand with the elbow in extension (a small percentage occurs from landing directly onto a flexed elbow).
  • On examination, gross deformity, swelling, limited elbow movement (secondary to pain), and ecchymosis of the anterior cubital fossa may be present.
  • Nerve palsies are common with supracondylar fractures, with neuropraxia rates around 10%; however, this rarely results in permanent damage.
  • The anterior interosseous nerve is most commonly affected by the initial injury; however, ulnar nerve palsy is the most common postoperative complication.
  • The axillary nerve terminates before reaching the elbow, hence has no role in elbow injuries.

Option C: Tearing of the Teres major muscle

  • The primary function of the Teres major muscle is to produce arm movements on the shoulder joint.
  • Contraction of the muscle pulls the humerus posteriorly (extension) and rotates it medially towards the trunk (internal rotation).
  • It contributes to the stabilization of the shoulder joint.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male was undergoing surgery for squamous cell carcinoma of the neck. The surgeon notices profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery during the surgery. Which of the following arteries must be ligated immediately to stop bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Costo-cervical trunk

  • The subclavian arteries are among the major arteries of the head, neck and upper limbs. The left subclavian artery arises directly from the aortic arch, just distal to the origin of the left common carotid artery. The right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery arising from the brachiocephalic trunk, a branch of the aortic arch. Although the left and the right subclavian arteries arise from different origins, they follow the same course in the neck region.
  • From the site of origin of subclavian arteries, they arch superolateral in the neck towards the axilla. They pass anterior to the middle scalene muscle and posterior to the anterior scalene muscle, which divides the arteries into 3 parts based on the relation with the anterior scalene muscle.
  • Pre-scalene part: The part before the medial border of the anterior scalene muscle. It gives off:-
  1. The vertebral artery supplies the upper part of the spinal cord, brainstem and cerebellum. It joins with the vertebral artery on the other side to form the basilar artery.
  2. The internal thoracic artery supplies the anterior thoracic wall and the breast.
  3. The thyrocervical trunk: The thyrocervical trunk gives off the suprascapular, transverse cervical and inferior thyroid artery. It supplies the larynx, pharynx, trachea, oesophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands.
  • Retro-scalene part: The part behind the anterior scalene muscle. It gives off the costocervical trunk, which divides into the superior intercostal and deep cervical arteries. It is a short artery and supplies the deep muscles of the neck. Bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck can be controlled by ligating the costocervical trunk.
  • Post-scalene part: The part after the lateral border of the anterior scalene muscle. It gives off the dorsal scapular nerve, which supplies the upper back and shoulder muscle, including the trapezius, levator scapulae and rhomboids muscle.

Option B: Transverse cervical artery

  • The transverse cervical artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk. It is not ligated to control bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck, which are supplied by the deep cervical branch of the costocervical trunk.

Option C: Thyrocervical trunk

  • The thyrocervical trunk gives off suprascapular, transverse cervical and inferior thyroid arteries. It supplies the larynx, pharynx, trachea, oesophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands.
  • To control bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck, the costocervical artery is ligated.

Option D: Inferior thyroid artery

  • The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk which supplies the larynx, pharynx, trachea, oesophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands.
  • Ascending cervical artery is a branch of the inferior thyroid artery.
  • The deep muscles of the neck are supplied by the deep cervical artery, a branch of the costocervical artery. To control bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck, the costocervical artery is ligated.

questions.text: A 26-year-old boxer presents with facial pain and bruising after being punched on the mandible, leading to subluxation of the atlantoaxial joint. Which movement is most affected in the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option D: Rotation

  • This is a case of dislocation atlantoaxial joint.
  • The atlantoaxial joints are synovial joints that consist of two plane joints and one pivot joint and are involved primarily in the rotation of the head.
  • Other movements do not occur at this joint.
  • The first cervical vertebrae, or atlas, do not possess a body or a spinous process.
  • Instead, it has anterior and posterior arches.
  • It has a lateral mass on each side with articular surfaces on its upper surface for articulation with the skull via occipital condyles to form the atlanto-occipital joint.
  • It also has an articular surface on its inferior surface for articulation with the C2 vertebra to form the atlantoaxial joint.

Option A: Extension

  • The atlantoaxial joint is a synovial joint that consists of one pivot joint and two plane joints and is involved primarily in the rotation of the head.

Option B: Abduction

  • The atlantoaxial joint is a synovial joint that consists of one pivot joint and two plane joints and is involved primarily in the rotation of the head.

Option C: Adduction

  • The atlantoaxial joint is a synovial joint that consists of one pivot joint and two plane joints and is involved primarily in the rotation of the head.

questions.text: Which of the following is the last tributary of the azygos vein?
questions.solution:
Option C: Right bronchial vein

  • The bronchial veins are small vessels that return blood from the larger bronchi and structures at the roots of the lungs.
  • The right-side drains into the azygos vein, while the left side drains into the left superior intercostal or accessory hemiazygos vein.
  • Bronchial veins are thereby part of the bronchial circulation, carrying waste products away from the cells that constitute the lungs.
  • The bronchial veins are counterparts to the bronchial arteries.
  • However, they only carry ~13% of the blood flow of the bronchial arteries.
  • The remaining blood is returned to the heart via the pulmonary veins.
  • All of the above are the tributaries of the Azygos vein.
  • The right bronchial vein opens into the Azygos vein near its termination into SVC.

Option A: Right superior intercostal vein

  • A right superior intercostal vein is also a tributary of the azygous vein, but the Right bronchial vein opens into the Azygos vein near its termination into SVC.
  • As the question asks for the last tributary, then the answer is the Right bronchial vein.

Options B: Hemi-azygos vein

  • The hemiazygos vein arises from the left ascending lumbar vein. Formed in the abdomen and puncture the left curs of the diaphragm to enter the thorax and drains the lower intercostal spaces.
  • At T8, it crosses right behind the aorta, thoracic duct, and esophagus and joins the azygos vein.

Option D: Accessory azygos vein

  • Accessory azygos vein drains into the upper intercostal spaces.
  • The accessory azygos and Hemi-azygous vein both turn towards the right in the thorax and pass behind the heart & both, drain into the azygous vein and cross at the T8 level.

questions.text: The internal carotid artery is an important blood vessel that forms the Circle of Willis and the blood supply to the brain. Which of the following embryological structures is involved in forming the proximal part of this artery?
questions.solution:
Option C: Aortic arch 3

  • The proximal part of the internal carotid artery is derived from the aortic arch 3.
  • The internal carotid artery plays a vital role in the blood supply to the brain.

Option A: Aortic arch 1

  • The maxillary artery is derived from the aortic arch 1.
  • It mainly supplies the deep structures of the face including the mandible, pterygoid,infratemporal fossa,segments of the pterygoplalatine fossa.

Option B: Aortic arch 2

  • The stapedial artery is derived from the aortic arch 2.
  • The stapedial artery supplies Stapedius.

Option D: Aortic arch 4

  • The right subclavian artery is derived from the aortic arch 4.

questions.text: A 6-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks gestation and weighed 1800 g. He currently weighs 1700 g. His mother has Graves’ disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), his pulse is 180/min, and his respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The actively secreting follicles of the structure involved in the patient's pathology are lined by one of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Columnar epithelium

  • This is a case of Hyperthyroidism.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium (central spherical nucleus, with a height of the cell equal to breath)
  • Since the question asked is regarding the secretary follicle, the answer is a columnar epithelium.
  • Secreting active thyroid follicles are lined by a columnar type of epithelium.

Option B: Cuboidal epithelium

  • The thyroid follicle epithelial lining depends on the cells' activity in the secretion of thyroxine.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium (central spherical nucleus, with a height of the cell equal to breath).
  • Secreting active thyroid follicles are lined by a columnar type of epithelium.

Option C: Squamous epithelium

  • Simple Squamous: Thin rim of cytoplasm above flat /globular nucleus
  • Scanty (resting follicle): Simple squamous

Option D: Pseudostratified squamous

  • The pseudostratified epithelium is very rare in cuboidal and squamous cells. It is seen in columnar form and lines the respiratory tract, male genital tract etc.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium(not pseudostratified).

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with swelling in her lower extremities. On examination, pitting edema is noted, and laboratory studies reveal hypoalbuminemia. The physician suspects an imbalance in interstitial fluid volume.Which of the following substances is best suited for estimating changes in interstitial fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Option D: Inulin and 125I-albumin

  • Inulin is the best indicator of ECF (extracellular fluid) volume, and 125I-albumin is most commonly used for plasma volume estimation.
  • Interstitial fluid volume= ECF volume – Plasma volume.

Option A: Inulin and heavy water

  • Heavy water is not used to estimate interstitial fluid volume.
  • Heavy water is used to measure total body water.
  • Inulin is the best indicator of ECF volume, and 125I-albumin is most commonly used for plasma volume estimation.
  • Interstitial fluid volume= ECF volume – Plasma volume.

Option B: Inulin and 22Na

  • 22Na is not used to estimate interstitial fluid volume.
  • Inulin is the best indicator of ECF volume, and 125I-albumin is most commonly used for plasma volume estimation.
  • Interstitial fluid volume= ECF volume – Plasma volume.

Option C: Heavy water and 1251-albumin

  • Heavy water is not used to measure interstitial fluid volume. However, 1251-albumin is most commonly used for plasma volume estimation.

questions.text: A neuron, the functional unit of the nervous system, is responsible for initiating and propagating nerve impulses. The axon's initial segment, just between the peak of the axon hillock and the initial (unmyelinated) segment, is also known as the trigger zone for the action potential. Which following is responsible for initiating a nerve impulse at the axon's initial segment?

choices.text: It has a lower threshold than the rest of the axon

questions.solution:
Option A: It has a lower threshold than the rest of the axon.

  • A neuron is the functional unit of the nervous system, and it initiates and propagates action potential to communicate with different body segments. A neuron has two main components; an axon and a cell body (soma).
  • The Axon hillock is the initial segment of the axon. Nerve impulses begin in this initial axon segment and not on the somal membrane adjacent to the excitatory synapses.
  • The primary reason for this is that the membrane at the axon hillock has several times greater concentrations of voltage-gated sodium channels. Therefore, the threshold for excitation at this site is lower than at the rest of the neuron.
  • It means that a relatively lower number of positively charged ions entering the cell at this point will lead to the initiation of a strong impulse.
  • In motor neurons, the initial segment is the portion of the cell with the lowest threshold for producing an action potential.

Option B: It is unmyelinated.

  • Initiation of nerve impulse occurs at the initial segment because it has a lower threshold due to the abundance of voltage-gated sodium channels.
  • In myelinated neurons, the axon is covered by the myelin sheath that acts as an insulator. Along the axon's length, unmyelinated points are present between these myelin sheaths, known as the nodes of Ranvier. Nerve impulse propagates by jumping from one node of Ranvier to the next. This helps to increase the speed of nerve impulse conduction, and these impulses are known as saltatory impulses.

Option C: Neurotransmitter release occurs here

  • The arrival of the nerve impulse at the presynaptic terminal releases calcium ions into the presynaptic terminal. These calcium ions are responsible for the fusion of neurotransmitter vesicles with the presynaptic membrane causing the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft. The binding of the neurotransmitter to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane stimulates the regeneration of the action potential in the postsynaptic neuron at the axon's initial segment.
  • Common neurotransmitters include acetylcholine, serotonin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine.

Option D: None of the above.

  • Nerve impulse propagation starts at the trigger zone (initial axon segment) due to its lower threshold than the rest of the neuron.

questions.text: The patient presents to medicine OPD complaining of fever with chills and rigors with inflammation in the unilateral knee joint. On laboratory investigation, ESR is raised, and TLC is also raised.  Which of the following method is used for ESR estimation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Wintrobe method

  • Wintrobe's Method and Westergren's Method are for ESR determination

Wintrobe method:

  • Two main methods are used to measure the ESR: the Westergren method and the Wintrobe Method. Each method produces slightly different results.
  • Most laboratories use the Westergren method.
  • The Wintrobe method is performed similarly, except that the Wintrobe tube is smaller than the Westergren tube and is smaller than the Westergren tube and only 100 mm (about 3.94 in) long.
  • EDTA anticoagulated blood without extra diluent is drawn into the tube, and the rate of fall of red blood cells is measured in millimeters after 1 hour.
  • The shorter column makes this method less sensitive than the Westergren method because the maximal possible abnormal value is lower.
  • However, this method is more practical for demonstration purposes.

Option A: Drabkin's Method

  • Drabkin's method fundamentally measures the molar concentration of the heme prosthetic group in hemoglobin.

Option B: Sahli's Method

  • Sahli's method is also called the acid hematin method of hemoglobin estimation.
  • Hermann Sahli first performed this.
  • Hemoglobin is measured by the hemolysis of red blood cells so that the pigment is released into the plasma.
  • The hemoglobin is converted into acid hematin when treated with 0.1 N HCI.

Option C: Spectrophotometry

  • A non-invasive technique employing light-guide spectrophotometry is described for measuring hemoglobin concentration and oxygenation in human skin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding fetal hemoglobin?

choices.text: It usually disappears by 2-3 months after birth
It contains 2 alpha and 2 delta chains.
Oxygen has a lesser affinity for HbF as compared to HbA.

questions.solution:
Option A: It disappears by 2-3 months after birth

  • HbF is normally replaced by HbA soon after birth.

Fetal hemoglobin:

  • Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is normally present in the blood of the human fetus. It resembles the structure that of HbA except that γ chains replace the β chains; that is, HbF is α 2γ 2α. The γ chains have 37 amino acid residues that differ from those in the β chain.
  • Adult hemoglobin normally replaces fetal hemoglobin soon after birth.
  • In several people, fetal hemoglobin fails to disappear and persists throughout life.
  • In the body, its O2 content at a given PO2 is greater than that of adult hemoglobin because it binds 2,3-BPG less avidly. HbF is critical to facilitating the movement of O2 from the maternal to the fetal circulation, particularly at later stages of gestation when oxygen demand increases.

Option B: It binds 2,3-BPG more avidly

  • HbF binds 2,3-BPG less avidly; hence its O2 content at a given PO2 is greater than that of HbA.

Option C: It contains 2 alpha and 2 delta chains

  • HbF contains 2 α and 2 γ chains.

Option D: Oxygen has a lesser affinity for HbF as compared to HbA

  • O2 has a greater affinity for HbF as compared to HbA.

questions.text: Which of the following motor events of the GIT is mostly within the Enteric Nervous System?
questions.solution:
Option D: Gastrin

  • Gastrin is a peptide hormone primarily responsible for enhancing gastric mucosal growth, gastric motility, and secretion of hydrochloric acid (HCl) into the stomach.
  • It is present in the G cells of the gastric antrum and duodenum.
  • Gastrin does not help in decreasing gastric emptying.
  • Gastrin, in physiological amounts, is known to increase gastric motility.
  • Gastrin, the main stimulant of acid secretion during meal ingestion, is produced in G cells of the gastric antrum and, in much lower and variable amounts, in the proximal small intestine, colon, and pancreas.

Option A: Protein breakdown products

  • Once a protein source reaches the stomach, hydrochloric acid and enzymes called proteases break it down into smaller chains of amino acids.
  • Amino acids are joined together by peptides, which are broken by proteases.
  • From your stomach, these smaller chains of amino acids move into your small intestine.
  • The acidity of the chyme, hyper- or hypo-osmolarity of the duodenal contents, irritation of the duodenal mucosa, and protein or fat breakdown products in the duodenum are the factors sensed by the duodenal receptors which help in decreasing gastric emptying.
  • Stomach acid does not digest protein. Rather, it activates an enzyme called pepsinogen which then becomes pepsin secreted by the stomach wall.

Option B: CCK

  • It is released (secreted) by your small intestine during the digestive process.
  • It is sometimes called pancreozymins.
  • Cholecystokinin is also found in your brain and central nervous system, though its function is not as well understood.
  • Cholecystokinin (CCK) belongs to the group of substances known as brain-gut peptides
  • It functions both as a neuropeptide and a gut hormone. The peptide and its synthetic derivatives (like, for instance, CCK-8 and the amphibian counterpart caerulein) significantly delay the emptying of gastric contents.
  • CCK stimulates gallbladder contraction and pancreatic enzyme release via CCK1R.
  • In addition, CCK inhibits gastric emptying and food intake through the vagal afferent neurons.

Option C: Enterogastric reflexes

  • The intragastric reflex is one of the three extrinsic reflexes of the gastrointestinal tract, the other two being the gastroileal reflex and the gastrocolic reflex.
  • The enterogastric reflex is stimulated by duodenal distension. It can also be stimulated by a pH of 3-4 in the duodenum and a pH of 1.5 in the stomach.
  • Upon initiation of the reflex, the release of gastrin by G-cells in the antrum of the stomach is shut off.
  • This, in turn, inhibits gastric motility and the secretion of gastric acid (HCl).
  • Enterogastric reflex: A nervous reflex where stretching of the wall of the duodenum results in inhibition of gastric motility and reduced rate of emptying of the stomach. It is a feedback mechanism to regulate the rate at which partially digested food (chyme) leaves the stomach and enters the small intestine.

questions.text: What is the residual volume (RV) of the patient if 800 mL of nitrogen was collected using the wash-out method?
questions.solution:
Option C: 1000 mL

  • In all the respiratory volumes, 80% fraction is nitrogen.
  • Thus, if the total nitrogen volume in the RV is 800 mL, then RV is 1000 mL. (80% of 1000 mL is 800 mL)

questions.text: A professor explains renal plasma flow (RPF) autoregulation in a seminar on renal physiology. He explains that renal plasma flow (RPF) autoregulation is a vital homeostatic mechanism that protects the kidney from elevations in arterial pressure that would be transmitted to the glomerular capillaries and cause injury. The Myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation is mediated through?
questions.solution:
Option C: Opening of Ca2+ channels

  • According to the myogenic mechanism of autoregulation, the rise in arterial pressure stretches the afferent arteriole.
  • Stretch of vascular smooth muscle causes opening of mechanosensitive membrane Ca2+ channels. This increases intracellular Ca2+, leading to the contraction of the smooth muscle.

Option A: NO release

  • NO release is involved in the (tubuloglomerular)TG feedback. They are released by macula densa in response to changes in NaCl in tubular fluids.

Option B: Noradrenaline release

  • Acting via α1 receptors located mainly in the afferent arteriole causes vasoconstriction.
  • Dehydration and strong emotional stimuli (fear, pain) activate sympathetic nerves and reduce RBF and GFR.

Option D: Adenosine release

  • Adenosine release is involved in the TG feedback. They are released by macula densa in response to changes in NaCl in tubular fluids.

questions.text: Which is/are under an inhibitory control by the hypothalamus?
questions.solution:
Option D: Both GH and prolactin 

Hypothalamic hormones:

Gland/TIssue

Hormone

Function

Structure

Hypothalamus
  1. Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)
  2. Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH)
  3. Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH)
  4. Growth hormone inhibitory hormone (somatostatin)
  5. Gonadotropic releasing hormone (GnRH)
  6. Prolactin inhibitory factor
  1. Stimulates the release of thyroid stimulating hormone and prolactin
  2. Causes release of ACTH
  3. Causes release of growth hormone
  4. Inhibits the release of growth hormone
  5. Causes release of LH and FSH
  6. Inhibits release of prolactin
  1. Peptide
  2. Peptide
  3. Peptide
  4. Peptide
  5. Peptide
  6. Amine
  • Growth hormone inhibitory hormone is generally called somatostatin.
  • Prolactin inhibitory hormone is dopamine.
  • Hypothalamic extracts contain prolactin-releasing activity, and a prolactin-releasing hormone (PRH) has been postulated to exist. Thyrotropin-releasing hormone, hormones in the glucagon family (secretin, glucagon, VIP, and gastric inhibitory polypeptide [GIP]), and several other polypeptides found in the hypothalamus stimulate prolactin secretion, but it is uncertain whether one or more of these peptides is the physiologic PRH.

Option A: Gonadotropins

  • The hypothalamus secretes the gonadotropin-releasing hormones that stimulate the release of FSH and LH.

Option B: Prolactin only

  • In addition to prolactin inhibition, the hypothalamus inhibits the release of growth hormone by secretion of growth hormone inhibitory hormone (somatostatin).

Option C: GH

  • In addition to inhibiting growth hormone release, the hypothalamus inhibits the release of prolactin by secretion of the prolactin inhibitory hormone.

questions.text: Which of the following states is characterized by the presence of Delta waves?
questions.solution:
Option A: Deep sleep

  • Delta waves are associated with deep sleep in humans.
  • An electroencephalogram measures delta waves at 0.5 to 4 Hz (EEG).
  • These thalamic waves are associated with slow-wave sleep (which begins during the third stage of sleep.).
  • Early in sleep, people are awake and alert.
  • Here, quick beta waves are generated. EEGs can detect alpha waves as the brain slows down. Once asleep, sleep stages include Stage-I, Stage-II, Stage-III, and REM sleep.
  • Stage-I (N1) is light sleep that lasts only a few minutes. Theta waves represent slow and high-amplitude brain activity.
  • Stage-II (N2) sleep is 50% of a night's sleep and is characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes. The next stage is longer.
  • Stage-III or deep sleep (N3) makes up 20% of a night's sleep. In this stage, the brain produces slow delta sleep waves. People are less responsive and aware of their surroundings.
  • Delta wave sleep is between light and deep sleep.
  • Delta waves are affected by brain disorders. Delta wave activity may be altered in Parkinson's, schizophrenia, and narcolepsy.
  • Some drugs and chemicals can affect delta waves. Long-term alcohol abuse can alter delta waves.

Option B: REM sleep

  • REM sleep comprises beta waves.
  • It's the last stage of the sleep cycle.

Option C: Awake state

  • The awake state comprises alpha waves.
  • Alpha waves are high-frequency waves.

Option D: Stage II NREM sleep

  • This stage of sleep has theta waves, sleep spindles, and k-complexes.

questions.text: Afferent fibers in the auditory department of the eighth CN end in the dorsal and ventral cochlea nuclei, from there the auditory impulses reach the inferior colliculi, the centers of the auditory reflexes, and via the corpus geniculatum mediale in the thalamus to the auditory cortex, which is located in?
questions.solution:
• The auditory cortex (areas 41 & 42) is located in the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe.
  • Postcentral gyrus: In the parietal lobe there is the somatosensory cortex (S I) – areas 3, 1, and 2.
  • Posterior parietal cortex (PPC): Posterior to the S I, this area harbors S II (areas 5 & 7). It receives inputs from S I, and visual & auditory cortices. The area is concerned with visuospatial orientation and the performance of a planned movement.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the correction of astigmatism?

choices.text: Spherical lens along with a cylindrical lens

questions.solution:
Option D: Spherical lens along with a cylindrical lens

 

 

  • The diagram shows light rays focusing at one focal distance in one focal plane (AC) and another focal distance in the plane at a right angle (BD).
  • Astigmatism, a refractive error of the eye, causes the visual image in one plane to focus on a different distance from the plane at right angles.
  • This is caused by too significant a curvature of the cornea in one plane of the eye (egg-shaped).
  • The light rays striking the peripheral portions of the lens in one plane are not bent nearly as much as the rays striking the peripheral portions of the other plane.
  • The rays do not come to a common focal point. Therefore, a person with stigmatism never sees in sharp focus
  • Treatment of astigmatism involves a spherical lens that corrects the focus in one of the two planes of the astigmatic lens.
  • The cylindrical lens then corrects the remaining error in the remaining plane.

Option A: Concave lens alone

  • Concave lenses are used to correct myopia.
  • It neutralizes the excessive refractory power of the eye in myopias.
  • It does not correct the uneven refraction from two different planes of the cornea.

Option B: Convex lens alone

  • Convex lenses are used to treat hyperopia.
  • It adds refractory power to the eye in hyperopia.
  • It cannot correct the uneven refractory power of the cornea in two planes.

Option C: Any spherical lens

  • A spherical lens is used to treat astigmatism.
  • However, it alone does not correct the refractory power of the cornea.
  • It needs augmentation by a cylindrical lens.

questions.text: A mother brings her newborn baby to the clinic for evaluation. The baby has a penis, a scrotum with no testes, and no vagina. Genotype determination shows XX chromosomes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this baby’s abnormalities?

choices.text: Abnormally high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) production by the trophoblast
The presence of a testosterone-secreting tumor in the mother’s adrenal gland/s
Abnormally high levels of LH in the maternal blood
Abnormally low levels of testosterone in the maternal blood

questions.solution:
Option B: The presence of a testosterone-secreting tumor in the mother’s right adrenal gland

  • True hermaphroditism: the presence of both male and female reproductive tissue and/or organs. Pseudo hermaphroditism: mismatch between gonads and secondary sexual characteristics
  • Male pseudohermaphroditism: male gonads, female secondary sexual characteristics
  • Female pseudohermaphroditism: female gonads, male secondary sexual characteristics A very high concentration of testosterone in a female embryo will induce the formation of male genitalia.
  • An adrenal tumor in the mother will synthesize testosterone at a high, uncontrolled rate that could produce the masculinizing effect.

Option A: Abnormally high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) production by the trophoblast

  • Although Hcg has a role in gender determination, it has no role in organ development.

Option C: Abnormally high levels of LH in the maternal blood

  • Abnormally high levels of LH in the maternal blood would result in no effect as there are no Leydig cells to produce testosterone.

Option D: Abnormally low levels of testosterone in the maternal blood

  • A low level of testosterone would not lead to penile development.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the office with poor performance and learning difficulties in school. According to the parents, the child has incoherent speech and stunted growth. On physical examination, coarse facial features, clubbed fingers and a protuberant abdomen is found. Ophthalmic examination shows an absence of corneal clouding. Auscultation of the chest determines a loud P2 sound. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hunter's syndrome

  • Hunter syndrome has an X-linked recessive inheritance. The impaired metabolism of glycosaminoglycans causes due to a deficiency of the enzyme Iduronate sulfatase. As a result, dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate accumulate in lysosomes, leading to mucopolysaccharidoses type 2.
  • It is a milder form of Hurler syndrome with a mutation in the IDS gene.
  • The presentation of the disease is between 2 and 4 years, and death is by the age of 15 years, usually due to cardiopulmonary compromise.
  • Early in life, it presents with intellectual disability, skeletal deformities, coarse facial features, and ivory-colored lesions on the skin. However, later on in life, there is progressive neurocognitive decline, hydrocephalus, and seizures.
  • Complications of hunter syndrome include mental retardation, valvular heart disease, carpal tunnel syndrome, seizures, and airway obstruction.
  • Hunter syndrome is also associated with aggressive behavior. However, corneal clouding is absent, unlike hurler syndrome.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Characteristic findings on physical examination.
    • Urinalysis shows increased dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.
    • The enzyme activity shows a decreased activity of Iduronate sulfatase on fibroblasts and white blood cells.
  • The management plan majorly includes enzyme replacement therapy.

Option A: Hurler syndrome

  • Hurler syndrome is characterized by impaired metabolism of glycosaminoglycans due to deficiency of enzyme alpha-iduronidase leading to accumulation of heparin sulfate and dermatan sulfate in lysosomes.
  • It leads to developmental delay, mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal abnormalities, and abnormal facies.
  • It includes corneal clouding, which is absent in hunter.

Option C: Fragile X syndrome

  • Clinical features of Fragile X syndrome are most apparent after puberty in males.
  • It has an X-linked dominant inheritance with trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene. This expansion results in hypermethylation of DNA and decreased expression of the gene.
  • It is known as the most common cause of inherited intellectual disability. Findings include postpubertal enlarged testis, long face with a large jaw, large everted ears, autism, and mitral valve prolapse.

Option D: Tay-Sachs disease

  • It is a lysosomal storage disease caused by deficiency of the enzyme hexosamine A resulting in the accumulation of an abnormal metabolite GM2 ganglioside in lysosomes.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, "cherry red" spot on the macula, blindness, and lysosomes with onion skin but no hepatosplenomegaly. It is also associated with muscular weakness and seizures.

questions.text: Which amino acid issue causes kidney stones with oxalic and glyoxylic acid buildup?
questions.solution:
Option D: Glycine

  • Glycine is metabolized by three pathways:
    • The first pathway is glycine's conversion to serine by adding a hydroxymethyl group.
    • The second pathway is glycine's oxidative cleavage to CO2, NH4, and a CH2 group.
    • The third pathway is glycine's conversion to glyoxylate in the presence of D-amino acid oxidase, which is subsequently converted to oxalate in the presence of lactate dehydrogenase and NAD+ or can be converted to glycine or formic acid in the presence of transaminase
  • D-amino acid oxidase has higher concentrations in kidneys, so excessive glyoxylate is formed in this setting.
  • In the absence/deficiency of transaminase, excess glyoxylate cannot be converted to formate or glycine, so the only possible pathway is conversion to oxalate.
  • Thus this leads to excessive oxalate accumulation in the kidney, which subsequently forms calcium oxalate crystals and kidney stone formation.
  • This condition is called Primary Hyperoxaluria Type l

Option A: Phenylalanine

  • Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid; it does not convert to oxalate at any step of its metabolism.
  • Enzymatic defects in phenylalanine metabolism result in phenylketonuria – characterized by neurological manifestations instead of renal stones.

Option B: Tyrosine

  • Tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid endogenously produced as the first product of phenylalanine metabolism.
  • Tyrosine's metabolism ultimately leads to the production of catecholamines, melanin, fumarate, and acetoacetate.
  • Enzymatic defects in this pathway lead to Alkaptonuria & Albinism.

Option C: Isoleucine

  • Isoleucine is both a ketogenic and glucogenic amino acid as its metabolism leads to the production of acetyl CoA and propionyl CoA. This pathway has nothing to do with oxalate formation or deposition.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for the simultaneous processes of oxidation and decarboxylation, resulting in the release of carbon dioxide (CO2) and the generation of NADH?
questions.solution:
Option A: Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

  • The simultaneous removal of electrons and CO2 from a substrate is called oxidative decarboxylation.
  • There are total 4 dehydrogenases present in Kreb's cycle:
    1. Isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH)
    2. α- Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex (α-KG DH)
    3. Succinate dehydrogenase
    4. Malate dehydrogenase
  • Out of them, two catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions:
    1. Isocitrate dehydrogenase
    2. α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

Option B: Malate dehydrogenase

  • Catalyzes simple dehydrogenation of malate to regenerate TCA carrier oxaloacetate
  • Use NAD as a coenzyme to transfer electrons from the substrate

Option C: Succinate dehydrogenase

  • Catalyzes simple dehydrogenation of succinate to form Fumarate
  • Use prosthetic group FAD to transfer electrons from the substrate
  • It is the only membrane-bound enzyme of TCA and is also called respiratory complex II

Option D: Fumarase

  • Catalyzes the formation of malate from Fumarate
  • It is a hydration reaction, i.e., adding water across a double bond to introduce an -OH group. So, this enzyme is not a dehydrogenase

questions.text: A 40-year-old male whose brother recently had a heart attack at 45-year age is worried and visited a physician to discuss the risk of a heart attack. Doctor orders blood tests such as HbA1C, lipid profile, and homocysteine level. The report reveals normal HbA1c but elevated homocysteine levels. These findings suggest that which of the following amino acid is not metabolized properly in the patient blood?
questions.solution:
Option D: Methionine

Homocystinuria

  • Normally, homocysteine is converted into methionine by the enzyme methionine synthase, also known as homocysteine methyl transferase.
  • A defect in either the enzyme that forms methionine (methionine synthase) or the enzyme that forms cystathionine (cystathionine ß-synthase) will lead to elevated homocysteine levels.
  • Also, deficiency of cobalamin and/or folate can also lead to homocysteine accumulation

  • Increased homocysteine can lead to damage of endothelium, resulting in exposure to underlying collagen and predisposing thrombus formation.
  • This can present as vascular thrombosis in both arteries and veins.
  • Patients with homocystinuria have the following abnormalities:
    1. Cardiovascular system: Myocardial ischemia, deep vein thrombosis.
    2. Musculoskeletal system: Kyphosis, marfanoid features, osteoporosis
    3. Eyes: Lens dislocations
    4. CNS: Intellectual disabilities
    5. Dermatology: Hypopigmented skin
  • Treatment: Depends upon the cause.
  •  1- In cystathionine synthase deficiency: Decrease methionine and increase cysteine intake. Vitamin B12, B9, and B6 are also recommended.
  •  2- In case of methionine synthase deficiency, methionine should be increased in the diet.

Option A: Alanine

  • Alanine is an amino acid involved in glucose-alanine cycle.
  • A high alanine levels in blood occur in fasting when muscles release alanine due to excessive muscle protein breakdown.

Option B: Cysteine

  • Cysteine metabolism defect leads to Cystinuria.
  • The well-recognized disease is hereditary that affects the kidney and GIT.
  • This results in amino acid urea and increased chances of renal stones.

Option C: Phenylalanine

  • A defect in phenylalanine metabolism leads to phenylketonuria.
  • There is a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase or tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency.
  • Newborn presents with IUGR, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.
  • Level phenyl lactate, phenylacetate, and phenylpyruvate are increased.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for this reaction?
questions.solution:
Option C: Monooxygenase

  • The hydroxylation of phenylalanine to tyrosine is catalyzed by phenylalanine hydroxylase.
  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase is a mononuclear non-heme iron-containing monooxygenase that catalyzes the hydroxylation of phenylalanine to tyrosine using molecular oxygen and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).
  • Monooxygenase incorporates one atom into a substrate, and the other is reduced to water.
  • In this reaction, monooxygenase incorporates a single atom of oxygen into the substrate phenylalanine and the other oxygen atom into hydrogen to produce water.
  • Monooxygenase is more abundant than dioxygenase.
  • They are more commonly present in fungi and mammals.
  • The cytochrome P450 omega hydroxylase is an important subset of the monooxygenases used by cells to metabolize arachidonic acid.

Option A: Dehydrogenase

  • Dehydrogenase removes hydrogen atoms from a particular molecule and causing its oxidation. It can sometime catalyze reverse reaction also.
  • Examples are succinate dehydrogenase, isocitrate dehydrogenase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, LDH dehydrogenase etc.

Option B: Dioxygenase

  • Dioxygenase incorporates both atoms of oxygen into its products e.g Homogentisate Dioxygenase which convert tyrosine catabolic intermediate homogentisate to Maleyl acetoacetate.

Option D: Oxidase

  • Oxidase catalyzes the oxidation-reduction reaction.
  • Example is L-amino acid oxidases which catalyze oxidative deamination of amino acid such as alanine to pyruvic acid

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese woman presents to the clinic for her annual check-up and weight loss assistance. She had lost her father last month due to cardiac arrest. On physical examination, it is noticed that she has a few yellow raised lesions over her body. The physician ordered electrophoresis of lipoprotein to detect abnormalities in her lipid profile. A broad beta band in the electrophoretic pattern of her serum indicates which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Figure: Electrophoresis showing the broad beta band.

  • Familial type III hyperlipoproteinemia is also known as broad beta disease, remnant removal disease or familial dysbetalipoproteinemia
  • The defect is in the clearance of remnant lipoproteins by the liver due to abnormality in apo E.
  • Features:
    • Increase in chylomicron and VLDL remnants of density <1.019 (β-VLDL)
    • hypercholesterolemia,
    • xanthomas, and
    • atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is referred to the outpatient department for evaluation of megaloblastic anemia. The infant was initiated on a regimen of folate, vitamin B12, vitamin B6, and iron. Despite a week of this treatment, there was no improvement. Further investigations revealed crystalline orotic acid in the urine, and subsequent analysis showed no hyperammonemia. The pediatrician administered a formula containing uridine, resulting in a notable improvement in the infant's condition shortly thereafter. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decarboxylase

  • Orotic aciduria is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It is the most common metabolic error in Pyrimidine Synthesis.
  • It is characterized by the excretion of orotic acid in urine.
  • It is caused by a deficiency of either orotate phosphoribosyl transferase and/or decarboxylase enzyme.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Megaloblastic anemia (due to inhibition of DNA synthesis and enlargement of RBCs)
  • Failure to thrive
  • Immunodeficiency

OPRT (Orotate Phosphoribosyl Transferase) & Decarboxylase is a part of a bifunctional enzyme UMP synthase in pyrimidine synthesis.

There are two types of Orotic acidurias:

  • Type I: Both enzymes are deficient, i.e., OPRT (Orotate Phosphoribosyl Transferase) and OMP decarboxylase (it is a bifunctional enzyme).
  • Type II – Only one enzyme is deficient (mostly OMP decarboxylase)

Option B: Isomerase

  • Isomerases are involved in the conversion of one isomer into another.
  • There is no isomerase involved in pyrimidine metabolism.

Option C: Tyrosinase

  • Tyrosinase enzyme is involved in the oxygenation of amino acid tyrosine and involved in melanin biosynthesis.
  • Defect in this enzyme causes albinism due to lack of pigment in hair and eyes.

Option D: Homogentisate oxidase

  • Homogentisate oxidase is involved in the metabolism of amino acid phenylalanine and tyrosine.
  • Deficiency of this enzyme cause alkaptonuria with black urine and ochronotic arthritis.

questions.text: What chemical compound is Folinic acid classified as, particularly in the context of its use as a rescue therapy during methotrexate treatment to prevent adverse effects?
questions.solution:
• Folinic acid is 5-formyltetrahydrofolate. It is also known as leucovorin and citrovorum factor.

• Folinic acid can be directly converted to N5, N10-methylene tetrahydrofolate.

Extra:-When methotrexate is used for chemotherapy, normal cells are also affected.

• Folinic acid is administered to rescue the normal cells from the toxic effect of methotrexate.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with mild liver disease, arthritis, fatigue, and grayish skin pigmentation. A highly elevated level of iron is observed in his liver biopsy report. Which of the following conditions will be most likely found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: High Serum Ferritin

  • This patient with mild liver disease, arthritis, fatigue, grayish skin pigmentation, and a highly elevated iron level on liver biopsy likely has hemochromatosis.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutation in the histocompatibility region of chromosome 6.
  • Iron absorption is increased from the small intestine resulting in increased serum iron and iron-ferritin complex.

Option A: Low serum Iron

  • A high serum iron will be expected in a patient with hemochromatosis.

Option B: High Serum Copper

  • It is a characteristic finding of Wilson's disease and has no association with hemochromatosis.
  • Wilson's disease presents with Keyser Fleischer ring, neurological symptoms, and liver-related disorders.

Option C: Low saturation of transferrin

  • Hemochromatosis is characterized by high serum iron; as transferrin carries iron in the blood, higher transferrin saturation will also be observed.

questions.text: The release of insulin from the β-cells of the pancreas requires which of the following GLUT transporters?
questions.solution:
Option B: GLUT-2

  • Is present in the pancreas, intestine, and liver
  • It is active in the fed state.
  • It acts as a glucose sensor in blood and allow glucose uptake in pancreas post prandially for stimulation and release of insulin from beta cells of the pancreas (see fig below).

Mechanism of action of GLUT-2 for insulin release:

  • After a meal, the blood glucose enters the beta cells through insulin independent GLUT-2 channels.
  • This glucose is phosphorylated to glucose-6-P for entry in to glycolytic pathway ultimately resulting in the production of high amount of ATP by aerobic respiration in these cells.
  • A high ATP to ADP ratio results in the closure of ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP) channels.
  • Depolarization of beta cells results in opening of voltage-dependent calcium channel and resulting in insulin release due to high intracellular calcium levels

Option A: GLUT-4

  • Once insulin is released in blood, it will make GLUT-4 active.
  • GLUT-4 is present in peripheral tissues (skeletal muscles, cardiac muscles, adipose tissues) through which glucose enters the peripheral tissues and this way blood glucose is ↓ leading to hypoglycemic action of insulin.

Option C and D : GLUT-1 and GLUT-3

  • GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 are involved in basal glucose uptake.
    • GLUT-1 is present in Brain, Placenta, Kidney, RBC
    • GLUT-3 is present in Brain (Neuronal), Placenta, Kidneys.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought dead to the hospital. The doctor declares respiratory failure as the cause of death. His brother says he has a history of AIDS-related dementia and also developed severe pneumonia. Many central nervous system neurons show hydropic degeneration on autopsy. Which of the following biological processes is most likely to blame for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option D: Plasma membrane sodium transport

  • The acute and transient change known as cellular swelling results from the body's response to injuries that are not fatal. Because the cells are unable to properly regulate the ionic and fluid equilibrium in their environment, an accumulation of water within the cytoplasm occurs. In parenchymal organs, such as the liver (hepatitis, hypoxia), kidney (shock), and myocardium, it is simple to observe (hypoxia, phosphate intoxication). It could be localised to a specific area, or it could be diffuse and affect the entire organ.
  • Hydropic swelling is a reflection of acute, reversible cell damage that is sublethal in nature and is induced by cellular volume regulation. This is a process that regulates ionic concentrations in the cytoplasm.
  • Harmful compounds have the potential to impede the processes that are regulated by membranes.
  • The accumulation of sodium in the cell generates a rise in the cell's water content, which leads the cell to expand so that isosmotic conditions can be maintained.

Other Options

Option A: DNA synthesis

  • DNA synthesis is unrelated to volume control, so it cannot be blamed.

Option B: Lipid peroxidation

  • Lipid peroxidation is unrelated to volume control, so it cannot be blamed.

Option C: Mitotic spindle assembly

  • Mitotic spindle activity is unrelated to volume control, so it cannot be blamed.

questions.text: Which of the following organelles play a role in the process of apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Mitochondria

  • Apoptosis is the programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms.
  • It is characterized by the following:
    • Blebbing
    • Cell shrinkage
    • Nuclear fragmentation
    • Chromatin condensation
    • DNA fragmentation
    • mRNA decay
  • Apoptosis is a highly regulated and controlled process.
  • It can be initiated through:
    • Intrinsic pathway
    • Extrinsic pathway
  • The intrinsic pathway is also known as the mitochondrial pathway.
  • Cytochrome c is released from the mitochondria by proteins Bax and Bak.
  • Cytochrome c binds with apoptotic protease activating factor-1 (Apaf-1) and ATP.
  • This combination further binds to pro-caspase-9 to create a protein complex called an apoptosome.
  • This apoptosome cleaves the pro-caspase to its active form, which initiates apoptosis.
  • Mitochondria play a central role in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis.

Option A: Cytoplasm

  • Caspases are present in the cytoplasm of cells.
  • Mitochondria play a central role in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis.

Option B: Golgi complex

  • Mitochondria play a central role in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis.
  • The Golgi apparatus is not involved in this process.

Option D: Nucleus

  • Mitochondria play a central role in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis.
  • Activation of necrosis results in nuclear fragmentation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male suffers a heart attack and expires. Lung autopsy on examination reveals numerous pigmented nodules scattered throughout the parenchyma (shown in the image). What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anthracosis

  • Anthracosis is a pneumoconiosis seen in city inhabitants and coal miners due to the chronic inhalation of carbon dust and sooty air.

  • Typically milder than other types of pneumoconiosis and is usually asymptomatic. Primarily affects the upper lobes of the lungs.

Clinical features:

  • Milder than other types of pneumoconiosis, usually asymptomatic

  • The upper lobes of the lungs are primarily affected.

  • Pulmonary fibrosis rarely occurs.

  • Chest x-ray shows Heterogeneous pulmonary infiltrates, with/without mass lesion.

  • In some areas, the subpleural tissue appears white; in others, it appears partly bluish to black.

  • There are many spot-shaped black macules on the lung surface and some larger regions of black discolouration.

  • This is the typical appearance of pneumoconioses, specifically anthracosis.

Option B: Asbestosis

  • Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibres, usually due to occupational exposure.

  • After a long latency period, this condition manifests with nonspecific symptoms, e.g., coughing and dyspnea, which are caused by fibrotic lung changes.

  • The diagnosis is based on a history of occupational exposure (such as working with textiles, cement, ship-building, and insulation) and characteristic changes on chest x-ray (reticular opacities and pleural plaques). 

  • Bilateral pleural plaques (indicated by arrowheads), some densely calcified, appear as curvilinear and irregular opacities.

  • The lung opacities raised concern for lung cancer, but a biopsy established a diagnosis of cryptococcus infection.

  • Partially confluent, white, fibrous plaques with a verrucous appearance are visible. These plaques are pathognomonic for pleuropulmonary Asbestosis.

  • Multiple rod-shaped bodies can be seen throughout the fibrotic tissue. A transparent core is visible in some cases, characteristic of asbestos fibres (unlike other ferruginous bodies). Anthracotic pigment (clusters of small black particles) is also visible in various locations.

Option C: Hemochromatosis

  • Hemochromatosis is characterized by excess iron deposition (or increased risk of excess deposition) in the body due to increased iron absorption. 

  • Increased iron absorption leads to iron overload  as there is no physiologic method for iron excretion (except through menstrual bleeding)

Organ-specific symptoms 

  • Liver

    • Abdominal pain

    • Hepatomegaly.

    • Cirrhosis 

    • Increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (a common cause of death)  [8]

  • Pancreas: signs of diabetes mellitus (polydipsia, polyuria)

  • Skin: hyperpigmentation, bronze skin 

  • Pituitary gland: hypogonadism, erectile dysfunction,testicular atrophy, loss of libido, amenorrhea[9]

  • Joints: arthralgia (typically symmetrical arthropathy of the MCP joints II and III), chondrocalcinosis (accumulation of calcium pyrophosphate)

  • Heart

    • Cardiomyopathy

 Option D: Sarcoidosis

  • Sarcoidosis is an idiopathic, chronic inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of noncaseating granulomas, typically in the lung and, less commonly, in the liver, eyes, and skin.

  • Predominantly occurs in young African American women. Chest x-ray often reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

  • A biopsy is a gold standard for diagnosis.

  • First-line treatment is corticosteroids.

questions.text: A college laboratory experiment is done to evaluate the chemotactic potential of a group of potential mediators in inflammation. Chemotactic factors are substances that are responsible for cellular locomotion. Chemotactic factors induce leukocyte movement and enhance leukocyte adhesion. Which of the following substances most likely has the greatest affinity for neutrophils?
questions.solution:
Option A: C5a

  • Several substances have the chemotactic potential for neutrophils.
  • C5a is a prominent example.

Chemotactic Factors

Factor

Description

Chemotactic For

Formylated peptides

Bacterial products of Escherichia coli

Neutrophils

C5a

Activated complement component

Neutrophils

HETE, LTB

Leukotrienes

Neutrophils

Kallikrein

Product of factor XIIa – mediated conversion, and other cells

Neutrophils

PAF

AGEPC; from basophils, mast cells, and other cells

Eosinophils

PDGF

From platelets, monocytes – macrophages, smooth muscle cells and endothelial cells

Neutrophils and macrophages

TGF-β

From platelets, neutrophils, macrophages, lymphocytes, and fibroblasts

Macrophages and fibroblasts

 

  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2 is caused by the absence of sialyl-Lewis X, the fucose-containing ligand for E- and P-selectins, as a result of a defect in a fucosyltransferase, an enzyme that attaches fucose moieties to protein backbones.
  • This results in a failure of leukocyte adhesion to endothelium, preventing the cells from migrating into tissues and making patients prone to bacterial infections, which are often recurrent and frequently life-threatening.

Option B: Fucosyl transferase

  • The defect in fucosyltransferase causes leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2.
  • The H antigen is synthesized by fucosyltransferase.

Option C: P-selectin

  • P-selectin is a protein which is produced by activated platelets.
  • The absence of P-selectin causes leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2.

Option D: TNF-α

  • It is an inflammatory cytokine which is produced by macrophages.
  • TNF alpha is an inflammatory cytokine involved in scar formation and regression.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents with a 6-day history of a painful sore on his left hand. Physical examination reveals a 0.6-cm abscess on the extensor surface of the left hand that drains a thick, purulent material. Diapedesis of leukocytes into and around this patient's infected wound occurs primarily at which of the following given anatomic locations?
questions.solution:
Option B: Post-capillary venules

  • The leukocyte migration through the vessel wall occurs through the post-capillary venules.

Leukocyte migration:

  • The process of leukocyte recruitment is the migration of the leukocytes through intact endothelium, called transmigration or diapedesis.
  • Transmigration of leukocytes occurs mainly in post-capillary venules.
  • Chemokines act on the adherent leukocytes and stimulate the cells to migrate through interendothelial gaps toward the chemical concentration gradient, that is, toward the site of injury or infection where the chemokines are being produced.
  • Several adhesion molecules in the intercellular junctions between endothelial cells are involved in the migration of leukocytes.
  • These molecules include a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily called CD31 or PECAM-1 (platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule).
  • After traversing the endothelium, leukocytes pierce the basement membrane, probably by secreting collagenases and enter the extravascular space.
  • After leukocytes pass through, the basement membranes become continuous again.
  • The cells that have exited the vessel then migrate toward the chemotactic gradient created by chemokines and other chemoattractants and accumulate in the extravascular site.
  • The most telling proof of the importance of leukocyte adhesion molecules in the host inflammatory response is genetic deficiencies in these molecules, which result in increased susceptibility to bacterial infections

Option A: Lymphatic capillaries

  • The lymphatic capillaries return the excessive fluid leak out of vessels.
  • This prevents oedema formation.

Option C: Precapillary arterioles

  • The precapillary arterioles are intact during the inflammation.
  • There is no leukocyte diapedesis through this area.

Option D: Small dermal arteries

  • The arteries are not involved during the diapedesis.
  • Venules contain significant gaps that aid in migrating leukocytes out of vessels.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath for three weeks. He further gives a history of 5 kg weight loss. He has been a known case of AIDS for three years. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. An X-ray film of the chest shows bilateral nodularities of the lungs. A CT-guided lung biopsy is shown in the image. The multinucleated cell in the centre of this field is most likely derived from which of the following inflammatory cells?
questions.solution:
Option C: Macrophages

  • This is a case of tuberculosis in which the patient presents with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath for three weeks. He further gives a history of 5 kg weight loss. The x-ray chest of the patient shows bilateral nodularities of the lungs.
  • The CT-guided biopsy reveals multinucleated giant cells, which suggests tuberculosis.
  • Granulomas are collections of epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells that are formed by cytoplasmic fusion of macrophages.
  • When the nuclei are arranged around the periphery of the cell in a horseshoe pattern (see photomicrograph), the cell is termed a Langhans giant cell.
  • The other cells do not form multinucleated giant cells in granulomas.

Option A: Basophils

  • Basophilic granules contain histamine and heparin.
  • They often obscure the nucleus.
  • They cause the production of leukotrienes in response to inflammation and allergic reactions.

Option B: Capillary endothelial cells

  • The capillary endothelial cells do not form multinucleated giant cells.
  • They have a ventromedial nucleus.

Option D: Smooth muscle cells

  • The smooth muscle cells have a single central nucleus.
  • The smooth muscle cells have gap junctions.
  • During inflammation, vascular permeability is increased, which results in redness, which is a hallmark of inflammation.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presented to an outpatient clinic with a complaint of difficulty swallowing. He has a history of IV drug abuse. An examination of his oral cavity revealed that most of his tongue and palate are covered in yellowish membranes. Several white, ulcerated lesions in the oesophagus are also discovered during endoscopy. The primary cause of these pathologic findings in this patient is the loss of which of the following immune cells?
questions.solution:
Option B: Helper T lymphocytes 

  • The patient has AIDS, which is caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
  • HIV affects many body organs, but the primary target is the immune cells (helper T cells).
  • HIV enters the body via the mucous membrane. 
  • It is detected first by dendritic cells, macrophages, and T cells. 
  • The virus stays latent in lymphoid tissues and can get activated later on. 
  • HIV infects cells by using CD4 receptors. 
  • Receptors on CD4 cells are CXCR4 and CCR5. 
  • The HIV protein that binds to receptors is gp120. 
  • Different strains of HIV use different receptors 
    • R5 strains
      • Infect macrophage/monocyte lineage 
      • Attaches to CCR5 receptors 
      • Also known as M-tropic
    • X4 strains 
      • Infect T - cells 
      • Attaches to CXCR4 receptors
      • Also known as T - tropic (Thymic T -cell precursors)
      • Dominant virus in most the cases 
      • Causes depletion of T -cells. 

 

Option A: B lymphocytes

  • B - Lymphocytes are not primarily affected by HIV 
  • It produces plasma cells that produce antibodies.

Option C: Killer T lymphocytes

  • Natural killer T lymphocytes are part of innate immunity. 
  • They Protect against many viruses and intracellular bacteria. 

Option D: Monocytes/macrophages

  • They are phagocytes and can rapidly act in case of infection or inflammation. 
  • Monocytes, when entering into tissues, converted into macrophages.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man meets a serious road traffic accident resulting in multiple injuries. He is brought to the hospital, where he is pronounced brain dead. His family reports that he has volunteered to donate his organs after his death. The least chances of rejection are seen in which of the following tissues?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cornea

  • The patient had died in a road traffic accident and had signed to allow the donation of his organs after the death. The transplantation of organs is not a simple process because there are chances of graft rejection when a certain tissue or graft is transplanted from one individual to the other.
  • Graft rejection occurs when the immune system of the recipient recognizes the graft as foreign and triggers an immune response against it, which can destroy the graft.
  • Amongst the organs described above, the transplantation of the cornea (keratoplasty) has the least chance of rejection. This phenomenon is attributable to the “immune privilege”.
  • Immune privilege is a phenomenon in which the introduction of new (foreign) antigens does not trigger the immune system of the recipient, unlike what happens in the other usual sites. Other than the cornea, the immune-privileged sites are the central nervous system, placenta, and testes.
  • Keratoplasty is the most common form of human solid tissue transplantation.
  • Unlike other tissues and organs, corneal allotransplantation usually does not require systemic and permanent immunosuppression. Nevertheless, allograft rejection is the leading cause of graft failure in corneal transplantation. It is estimated that approximately 10% of all grafts fail because of immunologic rejection.

Option A: Hematopoietic stem cells

  • The transplantation of hematopoietic stem cells does not have the immune privilege, and severe immune reactions can potentially happen. For example, the transplantation of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cells can cause a graft-versus-host reaction.

Option C: Kidney

  • The kidney is a highly vascular organ and does not have an immune-privileged status. Graft rejections are common in renal transplantation and require the proper use of immunosuppressants.

Option D: Heart

  • The transplantation of the heart is not free of complications attributable to transplant rejection. The heart is a highly perfused organ, and an immune response can be triggered against the transplanted heart.

questions.text: A newborn boy is brought by his father to the neonatology department as he notices abnormalities in his facial features. The boy has features of a drooping eyelid, and his mouth has a deep  groove between the nose and the mouth, along with a depressed nose tip. Based on the features as given in the image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Noonan syndrome

  • Based on abnormalities in his facial features, such as a drooping eyelid, his mouth has a deep groove between the nose and the mouth, along with a depressed nose tip; the neonate is suffering from Noonan syndrome.
  • Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition associated with a normal karyotype.
  • It is thought to be caused by a defect in a gene on chromosome 12.
  • Features similar to Turner's syndrome (webbed neck, widely-spaced nipples, short stature, pectus carinatum and excavatum), several characteristic clinical signs may also be seen:
    • Unusual facies (i.e., hypertelorism, down slanting eyes, webbed neck)
    • Cardiac: pulmonary valve stenosis
    • Ptosis
    • Triangular-shaped face
    • Low-set ears
    • Coagulation problems: factor XI deficiency
  • Bleeding diathesis in 50% skeletal, genitourinary, neurologic, lymphatic, skin and eye.
  • Findings may be present in varying degrees.

Option B: Downs syndrome

  • Down syndrome is the most common inheritable cause of mental retardation.
  • Symptoms of down’s syndrome (Trisomy 21):
    • Mental retardation
    • Epicanthic folds and
    • flat facial profile
    • Umbilical hernia
    • Simian'screase
    • The gap between the first and second toe
    • Hypotonia
    • Congenital heart defects

Option C: Edwards’s syndrome

  • Trisomy 18 is Edwards’s syndrome.
  • Its symptoms include:
    • Prominent occiput
    • Low-set ears
    • Mental retardation
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Rocker-bottom feet

Option D: Patau syndrome

  • Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) symptoms:
    • Microphthalmia
    • Microcephaly and mental retardation
    • Polydactyly
    • Cleft lip and palate
    • Renal defects​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 3-year-old male presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of the passage of dark-coloured urine with reduced urine output for two days. Physical examination shows signs of pallor, jaundice, and a distended abdomen. He is tachycardic and tachypneic on vital monitoring. Investigations show anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine. Urinalysis shows hemoglobinuria and proteinuria. The peripheral blood smear shows the presence of helmet cells. Which of the following will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Haemolytic uremic syndrome: HUS is characterized by the triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (evidenced by symptoms like dark-colored urine, pallor, and jaundice), thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), and acute kidney injury (elevated blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine).
