Urinalysis showing hemoglobinuria and proteinuria is consistent with kidney involvement. The presence of helmet cells on the peripheral blood smear further supports the diagnosis. HUS is often associated with E. coli O157:H7 infections or other causes of Shiga toxin production

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Polysplenia syndrome: Polysplenia syndrome is a rare congenital condition characterized by multiple small spleens, not typically associated with the symptoms and findings described in the case.

Option C: Spherocytosis: Hereditary spherocytosis is a congenital hemolytic anemia caused by defects in red blood cell membrane proteins. While it can cause anemia and jaundice, it is not typically associated with the acute kidney injury and thrombocytopenia seen in HUS.

Option D:  Acanthocytosis: 

  • Acanthocytosis refers to the presence of abnormally shaped red blood cells (acanthocytes) and is associated with conditions like neuroacanthocytosis syndromes. It is not typically associated with the constellation of symptoms seen in HUS.

Given the clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and peripheral blood smear results, Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is the most likely diagnosis. Prompt medical attention and management are crucial in HUS, as it can lead to serious complications, particularly kidney injury.

questions.text: An 11 Yr old child complained of sudden onset of fever, fatigue, and petechiae for the past 1 week. On examination, Increased Liver span (+), Tenderness over the Right Hypogastric region (+). Later on, further investigations revealed that he had leukaemia. The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome is associated with a Poor prognosis in?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

  • The Philadelphia chromosome is associated with a worse prognosis in patients with Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • Clinical Features Of Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia:
    • Fatigue/Fever / Petechiae
    • Hepatosplenomegaly/Lymphadenopathy
    • B-ALL are positive for the nuclear expression of TdT.
    • TdT activity demonstrates that a leukemic blast is of lymphoid rather than myeloid lineage.
  • Diagnosis: Acute lymphocytic leukaemia
  • The bone marrow aspiration smear shows typical lymphoid blasts with a high n:c ratio, opened-up chromatin, conspicuous nucleoli and scant cytoplasm.

Option B: Acute myelogenous leukaemia

  • Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a blood and bone marrow cancer.
  • It is the most frequent type of acute leukaemia in adults.
  • Signs and symptoms of acute myelogenous leukaemia include:
    • Fever.
    • Bone pain.
    • Lethargy and fatigue.
    • Shortness of breath.
    • Pale skin.
  • A small sample of your bone marrow will be analysed under a microscope to confirm the AML diagnosis. A bone marrow biopsy is what is done in this situation.
  • Chemotherapy is the primary treatment for most AML subtypes, occasionally in conjunction with a targeted therapy medication. A stem cell transplant might follow this.

Option C: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • Signs and symptoms of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia include swollen lymph nodes and tiredness.
    • Lymph nodes in the neck, underarm, stomach, or groin swell painlessly.
    • Weakness or weariness.
    • Below the ribcage, there may be pain or a feeling of fullness.
  • The main test used to identify CLL is a complete blood count, a type of blood test.
  • This is where a laboratory examines a sample of your blood to determine the quantity and appearance of the various blood cells.
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) that is symptomatic or progressing may be treated with the following:
    • Watchful waiting.
    • Targeted therapy with any of the following drugs:
    • Immunotherapy (lenalidomide) with or without rituximab.

Option D: Burkitt leukaemia

  • A rare, fast-growing type of leukaemia (blood cancer) in which too many white blood cells called B lymphocytes form in the blood and bone marrow.
  • Symptoms of Burkitt's lymphoma include:
    • Swollen lymph nodes in the neck, armpit, or groin.
    • Fever.
    • Night sweats.
    • Nausea.
  • Diagnoses of Burkitt's lymphoma and Burkitt's leukaemia may involve biopsies and imaging tests, such as CT scans or MRI scans.
  • The central nervous system form of Burkitt's lymphoma may be treated with intrathecal chemotherapy. The fluid between the membranes of the spinal cord and the brain is where doctors inject this treatment.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from the region of South America presents in OPD with a large, rapidly growing abdominal mass complaint. Abdominal computed tomography reveals enlarged retroperitoneal and mesenteric lymph nodes. A biopsy of one of the involved lymph nodes reveals a "starry-sky" appearance with numerous debris-containing intermediate-sized macrophages. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?

choices.text: The sporadic (Western) form is most frequently associated with EBV
Considered being a derivative of Hodgkin lymphoma
Most common cytogenetic change is t(8;14), with increased expression of c-myc
The tumour cells are derivatives of T lymphocytes

questions.solution:
Option C:  Most common cytogenetic change is t(8;14), with increased expression of c-myc

  • Starry sky appearance on histology usually points toward the diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma; patient age (10 years), gender (male) and presentation of rapidly growing enlarged retroperitoneal and mesenteric lymph nodes further support the diagnosis. The specific cytogenetic change seen in it is t(8;14) with increased expression of the c-Myc gene.
  • It is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma most common in children and young adults.
  • Almost all endemic Burkitt lymphomas are latently infected with EBV, which also is present in almost 25% of HIV-associated tumours and 15-20% of sporadic cases.
  • The endemic (African) form is characterized by the involvement of the face, especially the maxilla or mandible associated with EBV.
  •  The sporadic (Western) form usually involves the abdominal organs.

Option A: Sporadic (Western) form is most frequently associated with EBV

  • The endemic form of Burkett's lymphoma, not western, is associated with the EBV virus.
  • It infects mature B cells, activating them to replicate uncontrollably.

Option B: Considered to be a derivative of Hodgkin lymphoma

  • It is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma is histologically characterized by the presence of Reed–Sternberg cells.

Option D: The tumour cells are derivatives of T lymphocytes

  • Burkitt lymphoma develops mainly from B cells.
  • However, some number of t cells may be seen in it.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 4-day history of joint swelling and pain in his right elbow. His mother reports that he bleeds excessively whenever he gets a minor trauma. He has no other personal or family history of serious illness. The patient has had a tendency to easily bruise since birth. His right elbow is swollen and erythematous. He is diagnosed with a case of Christmas disease. Which of the following factor is deficient in this disease?
questions.solution:
Option C: Factor IX

Hemophilia B is a bleeding disorder which is also known as Christmas disease. It occurs due to the deficiency of factor 9. It is an X-linked recessive condition predominant in males.

Disorder

Deficiency

Haemophilia A

Hemophilia B

Haemophilia C

Parahemophilia

Factor 8

Factor 9

Factor 11

Factor 5

Option A: Factor VIII

  • Factor VIII deficiency is present in Hemophilia A, also known as Classic haemophilia. It has no role in Hemophilia B

Option B: Factor VII

  • Factor VII is the coagulation protease responsible for starting a cascade of proteolytic events that lead to thrombin generation, fibrin deposition, and platelet activation.

Option D: Factor X

  • Factor X, also known as Stuart- Prower factor, is a vitamin K-dependent clotting factor involved in the coagulation cascade. It has no role in Haemophilia B.

questions.text: A case road traffic accident presented multiple fractures, and there was heavy blood loss. The patient needed urgent multiple blood transfusions. Which of the following complications is likely to occur after several units of blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Option A: Metabolic alkalosis

  • Massive transfusion is defined as the need to transfuse one to two times the patient's normal blood volume or > 50% of blood volume within three hours.
  • This is the equivalent of 10-20 units in a healthy adult.
  • Metabolic alkalosis is the most prevalent abnormality.
  • It results from the conversion of citrate (present in stored blood) and lactate (accumulated due to hypoperfusion) to bicarbonate.

Option B: Metabolic acidosis

  • Metabolic acidosis is of two types of  anion gap metabolic acidosis and non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • The causes of anion-gap metabolic acidosis are as follows:
  • Ethylene glycol, propylene glycol, methanol, aspirin (late effect) toxicity, 
  • Chronic acetaminophen use
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Renal failure 
  • High ketogenic states (diabetic, alcoholic, starvation).
  • The causes of non-anion gap metabolic acidosis are as follows:
  • Hyperchloremia/hyperalimentation
  • Addison disease 
  • Renal tubular acidosis 
  • Diarrhoea
  • Acetazolamide
  • Spironolactone
  • Saline infusion

Option C: Respiratory alkalosis

  • Patients who receive multiple transfusions develop metabolic alkalosis due to the conversion of citrate (present in stored blood) and lactate (accumulated due to hypoperfusion) to bicarbonate.

Option D: Respiratory acidosis

  • Respiratory acidosis occurs as a compensatory response to metabolic alkalosis as a result of multiple blood transfusions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of abdominal pain for the last 3 months. She has experienced significant weight loss during this period. The patient has no chronic medical condition and takes no medications. On examination, palpable left axillary lymph nodes and periumbilical lymph nodes are found. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gastric cancer

  • This patient, with a history of abdominal pain, weight loss, and palpable left axillary and periumbilical lymph nodes, most likely has gastric cancer.
  • Gastric cancer spreads to some particular sites, as seen in this patient:
  • The left axillary lymph node is known as the Irish node.
  • Periumbilical lymph nodes are referred to as the Sister Mary Joseph nodule.

Option A: Ovarian cancer

  • The most common sites for the spread of ovarian cancer are as follows:
    • Liver
    • Spleen
    • Brain
    • Intestine

Option C: Colon cancer

  • It most commonly spreads to the liver, but the involvement of periumbilical or left axillary lymph nodes is more associated with gastric carcinoma rather than the carcinoma of the colon.

Option D: Pancreatic cancer

  • It most commonly spreads to the following sites:
    • Liver
    • Peritoneum
    • Lung

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presented to the outpatient clinic with a lump  in her left breast. Her family history includes breast carcinoma in her sister and ovarian carcinoma in her aunt. Physical examination revealed a 2cm fixed solid mass in the upper outer quadrant, and ultrasound revealed a high suspicion of malignancy. The diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma was confirmed by biopsy. Which of the following is a risk factor for breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Option B: Positive Family History 

  • Breast cancer is uncommon in young females, but the risk increases after age 30. 
  • In middle age, triple-negative breast cancer and HER2 mutations plateau, but the risk of ductal carcinoma increase with age. 
  • The most common cause is increased estrogen exposure, which causes breast proliferation. 
  • The common risk factors with relative risks are 
    • Relative risk > 4 
      • Female gender 
      • Advanced age
      • Family history ( > 1 first-degree relative)
      • History of breast cancer
      • High breast density 
    • Relative risk = 2.1 - 4 
      • Moderative penetrance germline mutation 
      • Family history (1 first-degree relative)
    • Relative risk = 1.1 - 2.0
      • Early menarche (< 12 years)
      • Late menopause (> 55 years)
      • Late pregnancy (> 35 years)
      • Absent breastfeeding 
      • Nulliparity 
      • Obesity 
      • Physical inactivity 
      • High alcohol consumption 

Option A: Breastfeeding

  • Breastfeeding reduces the effect of estrogen stimulation on the breast. 
  • Breast cancer risk increases in the absence of breastfeeding. 

Option C: Multiparity 

  • Multiparity reduces the effect of estrogen stimulation on the breast. 
  • Nulliparity raises the risk of breast cancer. 

Option D: Physical activity 

  • Physical inactivity raises the risk of developing breast cancer. 
  • Exercising lowers the overall risk of morbidity.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents with fever and cough for four days. The cough produces yellowish sputum, and she has no chronic illnesses. Respiratory auscultation reveals bilateral coarse crackles. She took paracetamol for fever relief. If used therapeutically, what's true about the drug's termination of action?

choices.text: Paracetamol must only be excreted from the body to terminate its action
Metabolism of drugs always abolishes their pharmacologic activity
Hepatic metabolism and renal excretion are the two most important mechanisms involved
Distribution of the drug out of the bloodstream terminates its effects

questions.solution:
Option C: Hepatic metabolism and renal excretion are the two most important mechanisms involved

  • This is a case of pneumonia in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and productive cough for four days. She further explains that she coughs up yellowish-coloured sputum.
  • On respiratory auscultation, the patient has bilateral coarse crackles.
  • Acetaminophen is a commonly used over-the-counter NSAID medication for pain due to various etiologies. When given in the therapeutic dosage range, it undergoes hepatic metabolism into glucuronides & sulphates and later is excreted outside the body via the renal system. On overdose, there is noted hepatotoxicity due to the metabolite NAPQI.
  • The action of a drug can be terminated either by hepatic metabolism or by renal excretion. Other pathways, like excretion in sweat or saliva, play minor roles.

 

Option A: Drugs must be excreted from the body to terminate their action

  • Acetaminophen has renal excretion.
  • But its action is terminated after hepatic metabolism.
  • So, it doesn't require excretion from the body for the termination of its action.

 

Option B: Metabolism of drugs always abolishes their pharmacologic activity

  • Most of the drugs are inactivated by metabolism. However, some drugs may be activated from inactive form (prodrugs), and others may produce active metabolites.

 

Option D: Distribution of a drug out of the bloodstream terminates the drug’s effects

  • Some drugs may act away from blood, e.g. digoxin leaves the bloodstream and enters the heart to produce its action.

questions.text: A 8-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with blurred near vision for two weeks. No other medical history is reported. The doctor administers a topical medication with cycloplegic effects for an eye examination. Which drug could have been used?
questions.solution:
In the case of the 8-year-old male child with blurring of near vision, the doctor would want to perform a detailed examination of the child's eyes to evaluate the cause of the problem. To achieve this, a topical medication with a cycloplegic effect is used. Atropine is commonly used in ophthalmology for its potent and long-acting cycloplegic effect. It temporarily paralyzes the ciliary muscle in the eye, allowing for a more accurate assessment of refractive errors.

Incorrect options:

a. Hyoscine: Hyoscine, also known as scopolamine, is primarily used as an antiemetic (to prevent nausea and vomiting) and for motion sickness. It is not commonly used for ophthalmic examinations or to induce cycloplegia.

b. Homatropine: Homatropine is another medication used in ophthalmology for its cycloplegic and mydriatic effects. However, it has a shorter duration of action compared to atropine. Given that the question does not specify the duration required for the examination or the need for a short-acting medication, homatropine could be a possible option, but atropine is a more commonly used cycloplegic agent.

d. Cyclopentolate: Cyclopentolate is also a cycloplegic medication used in ophthalmology. However, it has a shorter duration of action compared to atropine and is commonly used for shorter-term cycloplegic effects. Given that the question asks for a topical medication with a cycloplegic effect, atropine is a more appropriate choice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency with vomiting, dizziness, and abdominal cramps for 8 days. His relatives also told the doctor that he has been going for urination very infrequently and has had frequent loose, watery stools for 4 days. On examination, his BP is 80/50, and his lips and eyes are dry. The doctor prescribes a medicine to the patient. What was the medicine, and what is its dose in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Dopamine 15mcg/kg/min

  • This scenario indicates that the patient has oliguria due to hypovolemic shock.
  • Hypovolemic shock is an urgent medical condition in which severe loss of blood or fluids can cause multiple organ failure. Hypovolemic shock leads to inadequate circulating volume and subsequent inadequate perfusion.
  • Oliguria is a condition which presents with low urine output due to various reasons. In this case, the patient is in hypovolemic shock due to diarrhoea and dehydration, which is causing oliguria.
  • Dopamine is an endogenous catecholamine with neurotransmitter activity. If given in a dose of 15mcg/kg/min, it will act on alpha receptors of the smooth muscle of blood vessels, causing vasoconstriction, which helps in oliguria and hypovolemic shock. It is the first line of medicine in patients with shock.

Option A: Dopamine 1mcg/kg/min

  • Dopamine is a neuromodulatory molecule which can help in oliguria in low doses.
  • If dopamine is given in a concentration of less than 2mcg/kg/min will cause vasodilation of renal, cerebral, and splanchnic blood vessels due to stimulation of dopaminergic receptors on their smooth muscle.

Option C: Nor epinephrine 2mcg/kg/min

  • Nor epinephrine is an endogenous neurotransmitter which stimulates alpha 1, 2, and beta 1 adrenoreceptors.
  • 2-4mcg/kg/min is the maintenance dose in case of acute hypotension and cardiac arrest. It induces vasoconstriction and a decrease in renal and visceral blood flow.

Option D: Nor epinephrine 10 mcg/kg/min

  • In the case of cardiogenic shock, 8-12 mcg/kg/min is the initial dose given.
  • It is used to treat shock because it increases vascular resistance and therefore increases blood pressure. Other actions of norepinephrine are not significant.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man, a known smoker, presents to the cardiology ward with a complaint of chest pain radiating to the left arm for the last 2 hours. After examination and investigation, he is prescribed organic nitrates. After using this medicine, he again presents with the same complaint after two months; the attending cardiologist suggests that the medication he is using for his previous condition can lead to the development of tolerance when used chronically. Which of the following preparations is least likely to develop tolerance which could be prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Amyl nitrite

  • Based on the symptoms of chest pain in the past, for which he was prescribed organic nitrates patient is likely suffering from angina pectoris.
  • Amyl nitrite is a potent vasodilator, thus resulting in the lowering of blood pressure. It is used by inhalation to relieve the severe pain in angina attacks.
  • Tolerance is a person's decreased response to a drug, which occurs when the drug is used repeatedly and the body adapts to the continued presence of the drug.
  • Tolerance develops to nitrates when these are constantly present in the blood.
  • Longest acting is PETN (pentaerythritol tetranitrate). While the shortest acting is amyl nitrite.
  • So, Amyl nitrite is least likely to develop tolerance.

 

 

Option A: Isosorbide mononitrate

  • Heart-related chest pain, heart failure, and oesophagal spasms can all be treated with isosorbide mononitrate.
  • It has a very high affinity for developing tolerance.

 

Option B: Isosorbide dinitrate

  • Continuous nitrate therapy quickly leads to tolerance and a loss or reduction in the circulatory, antivenom, and anti-ischemic effects.

 

Option D: Glycerol trinitrate

  • Administration of large dosages of Glyceryl Trinitrate (GTN) three times per day resulted in tolerance to the drug's effect on blood pressure (s.c.).
  • After stopping the pretreatment with GTN, it was discovered that tolerance induction was time- and dose-dependent and gradually reversed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents to the Gynaecology outpatient department with complaints of frequent headaches associated with nausea and lightheadedness for the last 3 weeks. She is primigravida and has gestational amenorrhea of 25 weeks. She has a positive family history of hypertension. Her blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg and her pulse rate is 90 beats per minute. She is commenced on a centrally acting anti-hypertensive agent. Which of the following is a centrally acting anti-hypertensive agent?
questions.solution:
Option A: Methyldopa

  • Based on the clinical scenario, the centrally acting anti-hypertensive drug is methyldopa and is safe in pregnancy.
  • Methyldopa lowers blood pressure by causing central inhibition of alpha-adrenergic receptors, false neurotransmission or reduction of plasma renin activity.
  • It is used in both hypertension and hypertensive crisis.
  • Other centrally acting anti-hypertensives are:
    • Clonidine
    • Guanfacine
    • Guanabenz
  • There are 4 different classes of anti-hypertensive drugs, which are given below:
    • Diuretics: Thiazides and congeners, Loop diuretics, Potassium-sparing diuretics.
    • Sympatholytic drugs: Centrally acting antiadrenergic agents, Alpha-adrenergic blockers, Beta-adrenergic blockers, Alpha-beta adrenergic blockers.
    • Vasodilators: Nitric oxide, Potassium channel openers, Calcium channel blockers, D1-dopamine receptor agonists.
    • Angiotensin inhibitors and antagonists: Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, Angiotensin receptor antagonists.

Option B: Indapamide

  • Indapamide is a thiazide-like diuretic drug and does not act centrally.
  • It increases the Na, Cl and water excretion by interfering with the transport of Na+ ions across the renal tubular epithelium at the proximal segment of the distal tubule.
  • It is used in the treatment of hypertension as well as in decompensated heart failure and oedema but is not safe in pregnant women.

Option C: Metoprolol

  • Metoprolol belongs to a beta-blocker class of antihypertensive agents.
  • It blocks the response to beta-adrenergic stimulation and is not centrally acting
  • It is cardio-selective for beta1 receptors at low doses.
  • It is used in the following conditions.
    • Hypertension
    • Angina
    • Cardiac arrhythmias
    • Congestive heart failure

Option D: Triamterene

  • Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic drug and is not among the centrally-acting anti-hypertensive drugs
  • It has a direct effect on the distal renal tubule to inhibit Na+ reabsorption.
  • It Inhibits the Na/K-ATPase, and thus decreases the Ca+2, Mg+2 and hydrogen excretion from the body
  • It is used in the following conditions.
    • Hypertension
    • Oedema

questions.text: A 44-year-old male has come into your clinic complaining of an occipital headache. After examination, BP is elevated at about 170/90 mmHg, and the importance of starting medication immediately is explained. He mentions that he is a known diabetic but is not compliant with medication. Which of the following diuretics, if given, can cause metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acetazolamide

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, they enzyme which catalysis the formation of carbonic acid (H2CO3) from CO2 and H20 from H+ and HCO3-
  • Acetazolamide causes metabolic acidosis by reducing the absorption of bicarbonate ions from proximal convoluted tubules.
  • Thus, it increases the bicarbonate excretion by preventing its absorption and ultimately decreases the blood pH.

Option A: Indapamide

  • Indapamide is a type of thiazide diuretic; it causes contraction alkalosis by increasing the secretion of aldosterone in response to volume depletion caused by the diuresis effect of indapamide.
  • Aldosterone increases the excretion of H+ ions by increasing H+ATPase activity on α-intercalated cells, thus causing metabolic alkalosis.

Option B: Furosemide

  • Furosemide causes contraction alkalosis by increasing the secretion of aldosterone in response to volume depletion caused by the diuresis effect of furosemide.
  • Aldosterone increases the excretion of H+ ions by increasing H+ATPase activity on α-intercalated cells, thus causing metabolic alkalosis.

​​​​​​​

Option C: Hydrochlorthiazide

  • Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic; it causes contraction alkalosis by increasing the secretion of aldosterone in response to volume depletion caused by the diuresis effect of hydrochlorothiazide.
  • Aldosterone increases the excretion of H+ ions by increasing H+ATPase activity on α-intercalated cells, thus causing metabolic alkalosis. ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman attending her 4th antenatal appointment reports gastric discomfort persisting for two weeks despite natural remedies and dietary changes. Which medications should be avoided during her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Misoprostol

  • The use of any drug that results in the termination of pregnancy or affects the fetus during the antenatal period should be contraindicated.
  • Teratogens, including medication like folate antagonists, warfarin, and substance abuse, are all avoided during pregnancy because they affect the fetus, but Misoprostol and Mifepristone are abortifacients.
  • Misoprostol is a Prostaglandin E1 analogue and increases the production and secretion of gastric mucous barrier and decreases the acid production.
  • Misoprostol can cause abortion; it is, therefore, contraindicated in pregnancy. It is mostly used with Mifepristone to terminate the pregnancy (Abortifacient).
  • The commonest side effect of PG analogues is diarrhoea and colicky abdominal pain.

Option A: Proton-pump inhibitor

  • Proton-pump inhibitor causes irreversible direct inhibition of proton pump
  • It can be used during pregnancy; especially, Rabeprazole is much safer during pregnancy.

Option B: H2-Antagonists

  • H2-Antagonists include cimetidine and other "-tidiness".
  • Used in Peptic ulcer disease, GERD, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
  • Cimetidine causes a decrease in Androgens and causes gynecomastia and decreases in libido.

Option D: Sucralfate

  • Sucralfate forms polymers on GI luminal surfaces to form a protective gel coating on ulcers.
  • Requires Acidic pH.
  • PPIs, H2 blockers, and antacids may interfere and decrease their optimal action and cannot be given in combination with these drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following insulin is used in the management of a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Regular Insulin

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment with insulin by the I/V route.
  • Insulin available in the I/V route is regular insulin (short-acting, soluble, crystalline zinc insulin).
  • Regular insulin is DOC for diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • Regular insulin is a type of human insulin with a short half-life. It is a protein hormone, exactly like endogenous insulin, which is produced spontaneously in the body, and it has the same broad range of physiological effects as endogenous insulin. The capacity of insulin to reduce levels of serum glucose is the primary reason for its application in clinical settings.
  • When it is given intravenously, the patient's serum potassium level and blood glucose level should be carefully monitored throughout the procedure. Do not use the solution if it is thick or hazy; it should only be given to patients if it is colourless and clear.
  • When performing intravenous infusions, it is important to flush the intravenous tube with a priming infusion of 20 mL of insulin drawn from a 100 mL polyvinyl chloride bag each time new intravenous tubing is added to the insulin infusion container. This will help to reduce the amount of insulin that is absorbed by the plastic IV tubing.

Option B: NPH insulin

  • NPH insulin is given subcutaneously, and it can not be used as an immediate measure.

Option C: Insulin glargine

  • Insulin glargine is given subcutaneously, and it can not be used as an immediate measure.

Option D: Insulin lispro

  • Insulin lispro is given subcutaneously, and it can not be used as an immediate measure.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has a high affinity for 5-HT2 receptors in the brain, does not cause extrapyramidal dysfunction or hematotoxicity, and is reported to increase the risk of significant QT prolongation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ziprasidone

  • Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic used in the management of bipolar mania and agitation in patients with Schizophrenia.
  • Ziprasidone binds to dopamine D2 and  serotonin-2A (5-HT2A) receptors similarly to other atypical antipsychotics; however, one key difference is that ziprasidone has a higher 5-HT2A/D2 receptor affinity ratio.
  • Ziprasidone can cause QT prolongation leading to torsades de pointes, especially in the presence of predisposing factors/drugs.
  • It does not cause extrapyramidal dysfunction and hematotoxicity.

Option A: Chlorpromazine

  • Chlorpromazine is first-generation (typical) antipsychotic drug. It competitively blocks D2 receptors in the brain and can cause extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • First-generation antipsychotics such as Chlorpromazine are more likely associated with movement disorders known as extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS).

Option B: Clozapine

  • Clozapine is an atypical (Second-generation) antipsychotic commonly used to manage treatment-resistant Schizophrenia.
  • Clozapine has a high affinity for D1, D4, and 5-HT2 receptors, but it is a weak dopamine D2 receptor antagonist.
  • Therefore, it decreases the risk of extrapyramidal symptoms but can cause life-threatening agranulocytosis and seizures.
  • As a result, strict monitoring of WBCs through blood tests is recommended.

Option C: Olanzapine

  • Olanzapine is also an atypical antipsychotic that blocks 5-HT2A receptors more than D2 receptors.
  • Olanzapine causes weight gain (has the highest metabolic risk).
  • It does not cause extrapyramidal dysfunction and hematotoxicity.

questions.text: A physician prescribes a drug that is a full agonist at opioid receptors, has excellent oral bioavailability, and a longer duration of action than morphine, with milder withdrawal symptoms on abrupt discontinuation. What is the name of that drug?
questions.solution:
Option C: Methadone

  • Methadone is a long-acting opioid agonist that has equal potency to morphine.

  • It can be used orally for opioid replacement and opioid rotation therapy.

  • Due to a longer half-life, it produces mild withdrawal symptoms.

  • It is used for treating chronic pain and addiction to heroin or other opioids.

Option A: Fentanyl

  • Fentanyl, commonly known as fentanil, is a powerful synthetic opioid used to treat pain. Fentanyl is used for anaesthesia in conjunction with other medications.

  • Illicitly, it is also taken as a recreational drug, sometimes in combination with heroin, cocaine, benzodiazepines, or methamphetamine.

  • Fentanyl is 100 times more potent than morphine.

Option B: Buprenorphine

  • Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at the mu receptor with kappa and delta antagonistic properties.

  • It is useful as an analgesic and an alternative to methadone for managing opioid withdrawal.

Option D: Nalbuphine

  • Nalbuphine is a k agonist and μ receptor antagonist.

  • These drugs can produce psychomimetic effects with hallucinations, nightmares and anxiety.

questions.text: In a 55-year-old man with symptoms including anorexia, weakness, shortness of breath, and paraesthesia, the investigation revealed hemoglobin of 6.8 g/dl, macrocytes and neutrophils with hypersegmented nuclei on peripheral smear, sluggish tendon reflexes, and atrophic gastritis on endoscopy. What drug is likely to be prescribed?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cyanocobalamin

  • In this case, a 55-year-old man presented with signs and symptoms of anaemia.
  • Endoscopy revealed atrophic gastritis. Haemoglobin is 6.8 g/dl and the peripheral smear showed the presence of macrocytes and neutrophils having hyper-segmented nuclei. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of Pernicious anaemia can be made.
  • Pernicious anaemia is associated with atrophic gastritis leading to decrease vitamin B12 absorption in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Intrinsic factor is released by parietal cells in the stomach. In atrophic gastritis, parietal cells are damaged by auto-antibodies.
  • Intrinsic factor is required for vitamin B12 absorption in the small intestine.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia along with neurological symptoms.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause sub-acute combined degeneration of the spinal cord and peripheral neuritis—diminished vibration and position sense, paresthesia and depressed stretch reflexes

Option A: Folic acid

  • Folic acid absorption occurs in the small intestine, and it does not need an intrinsic factor for its absorption.
  • Its deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia without any neurological symptoms.

Option C: Ferrous Sulphate

  • It is indicated in iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia presents with microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells on peripheral smear report.

Option D: Erythropoietin

  • Erythropoietin is used in chronic renal failure-induced anaemia and bone marrow suppression-induced anaemia.
  • It is released by the kidney's interstitial cells that stimulate the production of erythrocytes in the bone marrow.

questions.text: Which of the following is an appropriate treatment regimen for Mycobacterium Avium Complex infection?

choices.text: Select an antibiotic regimen based on the drug susceptibility of the cultured organism
Start treatment with isoniazid and rifampicin
Treating the patient with clarithromycin, ethambutol, and rifabutin

questions.solution:
Option C: Treating the patient with clarithromycin, ethambutol, and rifabutin

  • The mycobacterium avium complex comprises of Mycobacterium intracellulare and Mycobacterium avium. 
  • These are grouped together because they commonly cause infections in humans together.
  • They usually cause respiratory illness in immunocompromised people.
  • In the later stages of AIDS, the disease may be very severe.
  • The regimen used for treating Mycobacterium avium complex in AIDS patients is REC (Rifabutin, ethambutol, and clarithromycin).
  • These drugs are given once daily.
  • Clarithromycin can be replaced with azithromycin, which is long-acting and can be administered once a week.

Option A: Select an antibiotic regimen based on the drug susceptibility of the cultured organism

  • The regimen used for treating Mycobacterium avium complex in AIDS patients is REC (Rifabutin, ethambutol, and clarithromycin).
  • The response to treatment can be assessed using blood cultures.
  • These are performed every 4 weeks during initial therapy.
  • Patients responding to therapy show substantial clinical improvement in the first 4–6 weeks.
  • Elimination of the organism from blood cultures takes longer, usually around 4–12 weeks.

Option B: Start treatment with isoniazid and rifampicin

  • These drugs are used for the treatment of Tuberculosis.
  • Mycobacterium Tuberculosis is the bacteria causing the disease.

Option D: Treating with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (co-trimoxazole)

  • Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole treats and prevents pneumocystis pneumonia in AIDS patients.
  • The infection of Pneumocystis jirovecii causes Pneumocystis pneumonia.
  • This usually affects patients with a CD4 cell count of <200cells/uL.

questions.text: A 38-year-old homosexual man with HIV presented with multiple extensive necrotic lesions with an abundant purulent secretion that covered his face, lips, scalp, and torso. The doctor suspected a coinfection and used Smith Noguchi’s media to culture. Smith Noguchi’s media is used for:
questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option C: Spirochetes

  • Smith Noguchi’s media is used for Spirochetes.

  • Smith-Noguchi Medium (by using living tissue):

    • Anaerobic media

    • Used for the cultivation of nonpathogenic treponemes

    • E.g. Reiter strain of Treponema phagedenis - Spirochetes

Other Options

Option A: Salmonella

  • Salmonella - Wilson and Blair bismuth sulfite medium is the best selective medium

Option B: Klebsiella

  • Klebsiella - On MacConkey Agar, these are lactose fermenters

Option D: Bacillus

  • Bacillus - PLET media is best for culture

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents in the dermatology outpatient clinic with complaints of pus-filled boils on his face, fever, and pain for 3 days. The dermatologist suggests the culture of boils to identify organisms for better treatment. On culture examination, Gram-positive cocci in clusters were seen. Which other infection is caused by the organism specified in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Bullous impetigo

  • The above case is most likely of impetigo
  • Impetigo is of 2 main types
  1. Non-bullous impetigo (Impetigo contagiosum) which is caused by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes and bullous impetigo.
  • Non-bullous type is more common.
  • Infection can be primary (normal skin), or it may be secondary impetigo (after any other skin disorder or breakage).
  • Some strains of pyogenes that cause impetigo have also been found associated with glomerulonephritis, known as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • Treatment is by antibiotics. Topical therapy is preferred if lesions are few. Otherwise, dicloxacillin or cephalexin are appropriate.
  • Honey-coloured crust lesion is found in non-bullous type, as shown in the picture below.

2. Bullous impetigo is caused by Staphylococcus aureus. See the image below.

  • Other skin infections caused by Staphylococcus:
    • cellulitis
    • carbuncles
    • furuncles

Option A: Erythrasma

  • Caused by: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Under examination with ultraviolet A light from a Wood's lamp, Coral red fluorescence is seen.
  • Appears in the folds of the skin.
  • occurs more frequently in warm or humid climates.

                     

Option B: Necrotizing fasciitis

  • Caused by Streptococcus pyogenes and polymicrobes, mainly Gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes.
  • Very painful with rapid progression to necrosis.

Option C: Acne vulgaris

  • Staph aureus doesn’t cause acne vulgaris.
  • Acne is caused by Propionibacterium acnes.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with a chief complaint of fever, severe chest pain and dry cough for three weeks. The patient denied any history of diabetes, hypertension, and asthma. The patient underwent chest radiography which was suggestive of Pneumonia. The microbiologist cultured the sample with the paraffin bait technique and confirmed the causative organism. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of the pathogen involved?
questions.solution:
Option B: It is an acid-fast organism

  • This is a case of pulmonary nocardiosis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, chest pain and dry cough for three weeks.
  • It is caused by Nocardia, which is a culture by the paraffin bait technique.

Nocardia:

  • Obligate aerobe.
  • Acid-fast organism (1%): Appears as branching filamentous red-colored bacilli. Refer to the image below.
  • Cultured by Paraffin bait technique.
  • The causative agent of Actinomycetoma.
  • Pneumonia in immunodeficient individuals, Eg: AIDS/Lymphomas/Post Transplantation.
  • C/F -- fever, cough (with thick sputum).
  • Extrapulmonary nocardiosis: Most common is brain abscess. Then skin, kidney, bone and muscle.
  • Rx -
    • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: is used as an effective therapy.
    • Severe cases – Combination – TMP-SMX, Amikacin, ceftriaxone/imipenem.

Option A: It is an anaerobe

  • Nocardia is not an anaerobe; it is an obligate aerobe.

Option C: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is contraindicated

  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is not contraindicated in the treatment of cases of infections caused by Nocardia.
  • It is used as an effective treatment for such cases.

Option D: Causative agent of TB

  • Nocardia doesn’t cause TB.
  • It is a causative agent for actinomycetoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the physician with complaints of profuse watery diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting for 5 days. The patient specified that his stools looked like rice water. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The condition was diagnosed as cholera by the physician. Which of the following serotype causes the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: V. cholerae O1 and O139

  • This is a case of cholera in which the patient presents with complaints of profuse watery diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting for 5 days.
  • V. Cholerae O1 and O139 cause cholera.
  • Cholerae is serotyped based on 'O' antigen into several 'O' serotypes.
  • V. cholerae O139 has clinical features similar to O1.
  • Known as Bengal V. cholerae, it was isolated from Bengal in 1992.
  • Features of V.cholerae O1 and O139:
  • O1 and O139 produce the cholera toxin (Mechanism is shown in the image below):
  • O1 and O139 cause cholera, with the following features:
  • Rice watery stool.
  • Shortest incubation period: 1-2 days
  • Infective dose: 106-8 bacilli.
  • Transmission: Feco-oral, direct contact.

Option A: V. Cholerae O1

  • Has 2 Biotypes: Classical and El Tor.
  • Three subserotypes: Ogawa, Inaba, and Hikojima.

Option C: V. Cholerae O139

  • Clinical features are similar to O1.
  • Known as Bengal V. cholerae, it was isolated from Bengal in 1992.

Option D: NAG vibrios

  • Non Agglutinable Vibrio ,Not agglutinated in 01 serum ,Does not cause cholera.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of recurrent fevers (>39.4°C) characterized by headaches, myalgia, and chills for 2 weeks. The febrile episodes began during a trip to Jordan∼3 weeks before presentation, where the patient reported receiving medical care and completing a 3-day dose of azithromycin. Other general physical examinations of the patient revealed no abnormalities. The peripheral blood smear of the patient seven days after remittance is shown. Which of the following is the true statement regarding the etiological agent involved in the patient's current pathology?

choices.text: Vector is a hard tick or body louse
It is non-cultivable on cell-free media.
Soft tick or body louse cannot transmit the disease

questions.solution:
Option B: Vector is a hard tick or body louse

  • This is a case of relapsing fever in which the patient presents with complaints of recurrent fevers characterized by headaches, myalgia, and chills for 2 weeks.
  • Loosely wound spiral forms on peripheral blood smear show Borrelia recurrentis. The diagnosis is relapsing fever.
  • The vector for this infection can be a hard tick or a body louse.
  • Relapsing fever is a bacterial infection that can cause fever, headache, malaise, joint pain, and nausea.
  • In this infection, there are recurrent episodes of fever.
  • Fever is usually relieved by medication, but it reoccurs within a short interval of time.
  • Relapsing fever is of 3 types:
    • Tick-borne relapsing fever (TBRF)
    • Louse-borne relapsing fever (LBRF)
    • Borrelia miyamotoi disease

Option A: The only reservoir is humans

  • The reservoir of relapsing fever is not only humans.
  • The rodents and other mammals are also reservoirs.
  • For louse-borne relapsing fever, the human is the only reservoir.

Option C: It is non-cultivable on cell-free media

  • Borrelia recurrentis causes relapsing fever.
  • It can be cultivated on cell-free media.

Option D: Soft tick or body louse cannot transmit the disease

  • For the transmission of the disease mentioned above, the vectors are body louse or soft tick.
  • So, it can be transmitted from the bite of a soft tick or body louse.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient complains of mental confusion, vomiting, and raised temperature. The doctor suspected meningitis and a CSF sample confirmed Cryptococcus neoformans. Which of the following is false regarding Cryptococcus neoformans?
questions.solution:
Option C: Urease negative

  • The urease test is used to identify bacteria capable of hydrolyzing urea using the urease enzyme.
  • The urease agar medium is used for performing the urease test.
  • Pathogens capable of producing urease enzyme test positive and develop magenta to bright pink colour in 15 minutes to 24 hours.
  • Cryptococcus neoformans is urease positive.
  • Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus.
  • Cryptococcus neoformans is an oval, or round budding yeast found most commonly in the faeces of pigeons and other birds.
  • The fungus is usually acquired by inhalation.
  • A urease test is also used to determine the virulence of the pathogen. 

Urea hydrolysis test Positive for Cryptococcus:

Option A: Grows at temperature 37o C

  • Cryptococcus neoformans culture can be inoculated in Sabouraud’s dextrose agar.
  • The fungus grows readily at 37 degrees Celsius. This differentiates it from other species of the genus Cryptococcus.
  • Cryptococcus neoformans grown at 37 degrees Celsius form smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.

Option B: It has 4 serotypes

  • Cryptococcus neoformans has a thick polysaccharide capsule.
  • Based on the antigenic specificity of the polysaccharide capsule, the species is divided into four serotypes- A, B, C, and D.
  • CSF specimen stained with Indian ink shows capsulated, budding yeast cells.

Option D: Infection in an immunocompromised patient.

  • Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus.
  • It causes infection in immunocompromised individuals.
  • It may cause:
  • Pulmonary cryptococcosis
  • Disseminated infections
  • Cutaneous cryptococcosis
  • Cryptococcal meningitis and meningoencephalitis

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, headache and vomiting for 1 week. He had recently gone diving during his vacation. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. His CSF on wet mount microscopy revealed a motile unicellular microorganism. What is the most likely organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option A: Naegleria fowleri

  • This is a case of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, headache, confusion and vomiting.
  • The most likely organism is Naegleria fowleri:
  1. Acute and fulminating primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) is caused by Naegleria fowleri.
  2. Clinical features of N. fowleri are typical of meningitis with rhinitis. The key to diagnosis is clinical suspicion based on the recent history of swimming or diving in warm waters.

Other Options:

Option B: Acanthamoeba castellani

  • Acanthamoeba species have been isolated as etiologic agents in Acanthamoeba keratitis, A. castellanii, and A. polyphagia.

Option C: E.histolytica

  •  E. Histolytica usually causes diseases such as granulomatous amebic encephalitis and ulcerative keratitis.

Option D: Ent. Coli

  • E. histolytica and Entamoeba coli do not cause meningoencephalitis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old farmer presents to the OPD with a complaint of abdominal pain associated with diarrhoea for the last two days. He also reports loss of appetite and fatigue. His examination reveals a blood pressure of 100/80mmHg with a regular pulse rate of 70 beats per minute and pallor++. Apart from that, he has a localized rash. His laboratory investigation reveals iron deficiency anaemia. A stool analysis is requested. His clinical features and investigation results are suggestive of hookworm infection. What is the most likely mode of entry of the infective larvae in the farmer?
questions.solution:
Option C: Penetration of skin

  • The patient has Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) infestation based on the clinical scenario.
  • Filariform larva enters the human body by penetration of the skin.
  • It causes iron deficiency anaemia [0.2 ml/day/worm blood sucked].
  • Host – Man.
  • Infective form – 3rd stage filariform (L3) larva.
  • Mode of transmission- penetration of the skin by 3rd stage filariform (L3) larva (by walking barefoot in dampened soil).
  • Habitat- small intestine.

EGG - Segmentation is seen [Blastomeres]:

  • Using a microscope, the standard method for diagnosing hookworm infestation is by identifying hookworm eggs in a stool sample.

Chandler Index:

  • Used for hookworm.
  • The average number of hookworm eggs per gram of faeces for the entire community.
  • Below 200 -Hookworm is not much significant.
  • 200 – 250 -May be regarded as a potential danger.
  • 250 – 300 -Minor public health problem.
  • Above 300 -Important public health problem.

Option A: Ingestion

  • The ingestion of pathogenic organisms may occur due to contaminated food or water and by licking or chewing on contaminated objects or surfaces.
  • The following diseases are caused by ingestion worldwide:
    • Norovirus
    • Salmonella
    • Clostridium perfringens
    • Campylobacter
    • Staphylococcus aureus (Staph)

Option B: Inhalation

  • The following diseases are caused by inhalation worldwide:
    • Asbestosis
    • Coal worker's pneumoconiosis or black lung disease
    • Silicosis
    • Byssinosis or brown lung disease
    • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
    • Work-related asthma

Option D: Inoculation

  • The following diseases are caused by inoculation worldwide:
    • Chickenpox (Varicella)
    • Diphtheria
    • Flu (Influenza)
    • Hepatitis A
    • Hepatitis B
    • Hib (Haemophilus influenzae type b).
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus)

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the medical outpatient department with complaints of fever, fatigue, and sore throat. She has no family history of asthma or tuberculosis. She also denies close contact with the covid-19 positive patient. On examination, there is splenomegaly, and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy was present. What is the most rapid and clinically useful test to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: IgM antibody to viral core antigen (VCA)

questions.solution:
Option A: IgM antibody to viral core antigen(VCA)

  • In the above-given case, the fever, fatigue, sore throat with splenomegaly and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy is suggestive of the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.
  • Infectious mononucleosis is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus.
  • Highly contagious disease and is spread by body secretion, especially saliva.
  • The virus has an incubation period of four to six weeks.
  • It is characterized by fever, sore throat, fatigue, and myalgias.
  • On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy, oedema of the upper lid (Hoagland sign) and splenomegaly can be present.

  • Diagnosis is confirmed by antibody testing.
  • The Monospot test is a heterophile antibody test used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis.
    • In the monospot test, heterophile antibodies are detected, which are produced in response to EBV infection by using RBCs from horses or sheep.
    • The test is positive if agglutination occurs between heterophile antibodies and horse or sheep RBCs.
    • The test is negative if no agglutination is seen.
    • IgM antibody appears early in infection and persists 2-3 months after infection.

Option B: IgG antibody to VCA

  • Appears 2-4 weeks after infection.
  • IgG VCA is used to diagnose the previous infection.

Option C: Antibody to Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen(EBNA)

  • It appears after 4 weeks of infection.
  • It persists for life.

Option D: Culture

  • Culture is not useful clinically.
  • Monospot test is used to detect the antibodies in infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with a 10-day history of flu-like symptoms, including anorexia, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and malaise. She is sexually active with multiple partners. On examination, there is right upper quadrant pain, yellow discolouration of skin and sclera of the eyes, and dark urine. Her LFTs are deranged, and AST and ALT are markedly elevated. The causative agent was found to be a DNA virus on molecular diagnosis. Which of the following serological marker best correlates in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anti HBc (IgM)

  • Acute Hepatitis B is indicated by Anti HBc (IgM).
  • 10-day history of flu-like symptoms indicates acute infection.
  • Anti-HBc 
    • IgM anti-HBc is a marker of ‘acute Hepatitis B’.
    • Anti-HBc is a marker of ‘chronic Hepatitis B’.

Look at the following graph for an understanding of Hepatitis B antigens:

  • Hepatitis B is a preventable liver infection mostly transmitted through blood, semen, or body fluids.
  • HBV infection symptoms include fever, anorexia, abdominal pain, vomiting, and jaundice. Acute hepatitis might present as fulminant liver failure.
  • Hepatitis B results in injury to hepatocytes and deranged liver function, raising liver enzymes.
  • The treatment of acute cases includes supportive management and Hepatitis B immunoglobulins, while chronic carriers are given antiviral drugs like adefovir, entecavir, interferon alpha, lamivudine, and tenofovir.
  • Hepatitis B vaccination is given at 0, 1, and 6 months.
  • Chronic cases usually complicate Cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option A: HBsAg

HBsAg:

  • Epidemiological marker of hepatitis B infection.
  • The earliest marker is seen in infection.
  • since it is seen in chronic infection, it is ruled out
  • It is present in the serum of patients, and antibodies against this antigen indicate that the patient is non-infectious.

Option B: HBcAg

HBcAg:

  • It is the virus's core protein.
  • It indicates that the infected person has the potential for transmission of disease.
  • HBcAg can’t be detected in serum, but antibody against it can be.

Option C: HBeAg

  • It is a soluble viral protein.
  • Indicates active viral replication.
  • Marker of infectivity for Hepatitis B
  • In acute hepatitis, it disappears soon after ALT peaks.
  • While chronic hepatitis-positive HBeAg indicates a high level of infectivity.

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios is more likely to cause a whiplash injury?

choices.text: Pedestrian is hit and moves over the vehicle.

questions.solution:
Option C: Occupant of a car

  • Whiplash injury is sustained commonly by occupants of the front seat in a motor vehicle.

Option A: Pedestrian hit from front

  • If the victim is struck from the front, he may sustain injuries to the chest and abdomen with fractures of ribs or vertebrae.
  • The victim can also sustain a fracture of the pelvis or fracture-dislocation of the sacroiliac joint from the impact of a mudguard, and a fracture of the tibia and fibula of one or both legs can be sustained from impact by a bumper.

Option B: Pedestrian hit from behind

  • When the pedestrian is knocked down from behind with both feet fixed to the ground: There will be fractures of the bones of the lower limbs, the buttocks and the back of the pedestrian on being hit by headlamps or the radiator of the car.
  • It may result in fracture dislocation of the lumbar or thoracic spine, and this injury may drive the femoral head through the acetabulum.

questions.text: The defending team had appealed to the court to pronounce the evidence invalid as the investigating team had not followed protocols as defined under CrPC 174. Which type of inquest does fall under CrPC 174?
questions.solution:
Option B: Police inquest

  • 174 CrPC: Police inquest.

Option A: Magistrate inquest

  • 176 CrPC: Magistrate inquest.

Option C: Medical examiner inquest

  • 53 CrPC: Examination of the accused by a medical practitioner at the request of the police officer (a doctor can examine the arrested person even without his consent).

Option D: None of the above

  • Incorrect.

questions.text: The body of the 28-year-old television actress has been found in the hotel room where she had been staying. Initial findings by the forensic team include glove & stocking hypostasis, bruises around the neck, protrusion of the tongue, and dribbling of saliva. What is the dribbling of saliva is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antemortem hanging

  • Dribbling of saliva: Surest sign of antemortem hanging.
  • Excessive salivation occurs when the person is alive, due to pressure and friction caused by ligature material on the submandibular glands.
  • Dribbling of saliva occurs from the angle of the mouth which is at a lower level, i.e. from the angle opposite to the side of the knot.
  • When the knot is on the nape of the neck, it occurs across the middle of the lower lip.

Option B: Strangulation

  • It is a form of violent asphyxial death caused by constriction of air passage at the neck by means of a ligature or by any means other than suspension of the body.
  • Classification: Ligature strangulation, manual strangulation or throttling, mugging, Bansdola, Garroting, etc.

Option C: Postmortem hanging

  • Dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of antemortem hanging, not postmortem hanging.

Option D: Throttling

  • Throttling or Manual Strangulation: Asphyxia produced by compression of the neck by human hands.
  • Inward compression fracture of the hyoid bone is the most diagnostic finding of throttling.

questions.text: The forensic team has concluded the autopsy of the 35-year-old clerk who had suddenly collapsed during his night shift. The final report states that it was a Negative autopsy. What does the team mean when using that term?

choices.text: No cause of death is found on gross as well as histopathological examination
Cause is apparent on gross examination but not on histopathological examination
Cause is apparent on gross examination but not found because of constrains on the part of doctor

questions.solution:
Option A: No cause of death is found on gross as well as histopathological examination

  • Negative autopsy: In about 2–5% of all postmortem examination cases, the cause of death remains unknown, even after all laboratory examinations including biochemical, microbiological, virological, microscopic and toxicological examination.

Option B: Cause is apparent on gross examination but not on histopathological examination

  • If the cause is apparent on gross examination, it is not a negative autopsy.

Option C: Gross findings are minimal

  • If the gross findings are minimal, it is termed an obscure autopsy.
  • Additional tests are done to determine the cause of death i.e,
    • Histopathological examination [HPE].
    • Microbiological examination.
    • Chemical/ Toxicological examination etc.

Option D: Cause is apparent on gross examination but not found because of constraints on the part of the doctor

  • If the cause is apparent on gross examination, it is not a negative autopsy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has been accused of rape by his 26-year-old female friend. The woman allegedly was lured by the man on a pretext of helping with an assignment but had later spiked her drink and raped her while she was unconscious. The team has taken swabs of his urethral lining to test for the presence of vaginal cells. The test that would be done for the same is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lugol’s iodine test

  • Lugol’s iodine test is to detect vaginal epithelial cells containing glycogen.

Option B: Takayama test

  • Takayama test is to detect blood stains.

Option C: Florence test

  • Florence test is a test for seminal stain.

Option D: Precipitin test

  • Species identification is done by the precipitin test.

questions.text: Specimens for toxicological (Chemical) analysis are commonly preserved using a solution, which is easily available and cheap. It can be used for all poisons except corrosive acids. Which among the following is being described here?
questions.solution:
Option D:Saturated solution of common salt

  • Saturated solution of common salt is easily available and cheap and it can be used for all poisons except corrosive acids.

Option A: Rectified spirit

  • 95% pure ethanol is referred to as the rectified spirit, with 5% water.
  • Rectified spirit is the best preservative for chemical analysis.

Option B: Alcohol

  • Rectified spirit contraindicated in: Alcohol, Formaldehyde & Formic acid.

Option C: 10% Formaldehyde

  • 10% Formaldehyde is used as a preservative for chemical analysis

questions.text: A man presents with fever and chills 2 weeks after a louse bite. There was a maculopapular rash on the trunk, which spread peripherally. What would be the cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Option D: Epidemic typhus

  • The above-given clinical features point toward the diagnosis of epidemic typhus.

Epidemic Typhus:

  • It is a type of rickettsial disease of the typhus group:
    • Recrudescent form of Epidemic typhus: Brill Zinsser Disease.
    • Was the ‘most formidable rickettsial disease in past.
  • Causative agent: R. prowazekii
  • Vector: Louse (P. capitis, P. corporis).
  • Clinical picture: Prolonged febrile illness, vasculitis.
  • Drug of choice: Tetracycline

Option A: Scrub typhus

  • Scrub typhus and Rickettsialpox are transmitted by mites.

Option B: Endemic typhus

  • Endemic typhus is transmitted by the rat flea.

Option C: Rickettsial pox

  • Rickettsialpox is transmitted by mites.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presented to the OPD with discharge from eyes containing mucus and pus, itching in eyes, eye pain, and light sensitivity. The clinical diagnosis of trachoma was made by the physician. Which of the following is the single drug treatment recommended for Trachoma control in India?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option C: Azithromycin

  • Treatment of choice for Trachoma: Azithromycin 20mg/kg oral stat.

Other options

Option A: Tetracycline

  • Earlier, Tetracycline was the Drug of Choice for trachoma.
  • Drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis in plague: Tetracycline 500 mg QID × 5 days
  • Antibiotic of choice for Brucellosis: Tetracycline
  • Cholera chemoprophylaxis: Tetracycline/ Furazolidone
  • Drug of choice for Rickettsial diseases: Tetracycline

Option B: Doxycycline

  • Drug of choice for Lympho granuloma venereum: Doxycycline
  • Malaria < 6 WK: Doxycycline

Option D: Penicillin

  • Penicillin (First antibiotic): Alexander Fleming
  • Prophylactic treatment of Rheumatic heart disease: Benzathine penicillin
  • TOC for Endemic Treponematoses: Benzathine Penicillin G
  • Drugs of Choice for Severe Pneumonia: Benzyl Penicillin.

questions.text: A community health guide is a resource to help you select interventions to improve health and prevent disease in your community. Which of the following authority is responsible for the selection of the Community health guide?
questions.solution:
Option D: Medical officer-in-charge

  • The medical officer of PHC is responsible for the selection of the Community health guide.
  • Final selection is made by the Medical Officer of PHC, and joint selection is made by the Medical Officers of PHC and field staff of several government organizations.

Option A: Block Development Officer

  • Community Development Blocks (Each under a Block Development Officer; a block comprises 100 villages and 80,000-1,20,000 population).

Option B: ASHA

  • ASHA is located at the Village level.
  • One ASHA worker is for 1000 population.
  • Selection criteria of ASHA:
    • A woman resident of the local community.
    • Preferably 25-45 years of age.
    • Literate with formal education up to VIII class.
  • Responsibilities of ASHA:
    • Act as a depot holder for essential provisions like ORS, IFA tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral pills & condoms.
    • Provide primary medical care and act as DOTS provider.
    • Counsel women on aspects of reproductive and child health.
    • Help develop a comprehensive village health plan.
    • Arrange to escort/ accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment/ admission to the nearest health facility.
    • Be a part of JSY (Janani Suraksha Yojana) and help reduce MMR.

Option C: Zila Parishad

  • All the presidents of the Panchayat Samiti are members of the Zilla Parishad.
  • The Chairman of the Zilla Parishad should be the District Collector and Magistrate, and one of the district officers will have to act as the Secretary of the Zilla Parishad.
  • The functions of the Zilla Parishad are enumerated below:
    • It has to approve the budgets of samitis in the district.
    • It must distribute funds given by the government to the Panchayat Samiti.
    • It has to coordinate and consolidate the block plans in the district.
    • It has to process the request for grants to the state government.
    • It has to supervise the functions of Panchayat Samiti in the district.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from a rural village presented to the PHC with fever, chills, muscle aches, vomiting, and diarrhea. The condition was diagnosed as malaria. Which of the following is an anti-adult mosquito insecticide?
questions.solution:
Option D: DDT

  • DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-trichloro ethane) is an anti-adult mosquito insecticide.
  • Mechanism of action:
    • Contact poison: Nerve poison that inhibits the acetylcholinesterase enzyme.
    • It takes several hours to kill Q (No immediate death).
    • Residual action lasts for 18 months.
    • No repellent action.

Other options

Option A: Paris green

  • It is an inorganic substance.
  •  It is sometimes referred to as Vienna green, emerald green, or Schweinfurt green when used as a green pigment. It is an emerald-green, crystalline powder that is extremely poisonous and has been employed as an insecticide and rodenticide.
  • Paris green is an anti-larval measure.

Option B: Mineral oil

  • Mineral oil is also an anti-larval measure.

Option C: Fenthion

  • Fenthion is an acaricide, avicide, and organothiophosphate insecticide.
  • Its route of action is by cholinesterase inhibition, like the majority of other organophosphates.

questions.text: A 10-year-old mentally retarded child presented to the hospital. To check his intellectual disability level the physician is checking his reading and writing skills. The reading and writing skills of a moderately mentally retarded child are?
questions.solution:
Option B: Basic

  • A child with Moderate Mental retardation have basic reading and writing skill.
  • Moderate Disability:
    • IQ level in Moderate disability is 49-35.
    • For self-care, they need some help.
    • They have basic reading and writing skills.
    • They can do unskilled but supervised work.

Option A: Reasonable

  • The reading and writing skill is reasonable in mild mental retardation.

Option C: Minimal

  • The reading and writing skill is mild in severe mental retardation.

Option D: None

  • The reading and writing skill is mild to none in severe mental retardation.

questions.text: Dietary modification (PRUDENT DIET) is the principal preventive strategy in preventing CORONARY HEART DISEASE. As per the WHO recommended Goal of a Prudent diet, the Total Cholesterol: HDL ratio should be less than?
questions.solution:
Option C: 3.5

  • As per the WHO recommended Goal of a Prudent diet, the Total Cholesterol: HDL ratio should be less than 3.5.
  • Reduction in dietary cholesterol to < 200 mg/day.
  • Reduction of salt intake to < 5 gms per day.

questions.text: The uppermost line of the card depicted above is equivalent to:
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option C: 50th percentile for boys

  • Weight for Age growth chart is the single best indicator for growth in children.
  • The upper line of the ‘Road to health card’ is equivalent to the 50th percentile for boys.
  • The lower line of the ‘Road to health card’ is equivalent to the 3rd percentile for girls.

Other options

Option A: 80% For boys

  • It is an incorrect choice because the Upper reference curve is at the 50 percentile for boys.

Option B: 50% for girls

  • It is also an incorrect choice because the Upper reference curve at the 50 percentile is for boys.

Option D: 3rd percentile for girls

  • This would be correct for the Lower reference curve in weight for the age chart.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented to the hospital with a lump in her breast. On examination, there is the presence of a dimpling sign. Mammography was performed by the physician. Which of the following is a characteristic of a Diagnostic test as compared to a Screening test?

choices.text: Test results are arbitrary and final
Based on one criterion or cut-off point
Done on those with indications or sick

questions.solution:
Option D: Done on those with indications or sick

  • A diagnostic test is done on those with indications or who are sick. Whereas, a screening test is done on an apparently healthy individual.
  • Diagnostic test characteristics:
    • A diagnostic test's goal is to determine whether a disease is present (or absent) so that treatment choices can be made in cases when a person has symptoms or tests positive (confirmatory test).
    • When a patient has medical indications or is sick, this needs to be performed.

Other options

Option A: Test results are arbitrary and final

  • The results of a screening test are final and arbitrarily determined. 
  • Screening test characteristic:
    • The main goal of screening tests is to find early disease or risk factors for disease in a wide population of people who appear to be healthy.
    • The test's results are final and arbitrarily determined.
    • The outcomes are determined by a single criterion or cut-off point.

Option B: Based on one criterion or cut-off point

  • The screening test is based on one criterion or cut-off point.
  • The diagnostic test is based on the evaluation of a number of symptoms.

Option C: Less accurate

  • Compared to screening tests, diagnostic tests are more accurate.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most logical sequence?
questions.solution:
Disease - Impairment - Disability - Handicap

  • According to WHO definitions, Disease - Impairment - Disability - Handicap is the most logical sequence.

Learning Objective

Spectrum of Disease:

  • According to WHO definitions:
    • Disease: Any abnormal condition of an organism that impairs function.
    • Impairment: Any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological or anatomical structure or function.
    • Disability: Inability to perform routine activity (According to age & sex).
    • Handicap: Limits / prevents fulfillment of a role considered normal (depending on age, sex, social, cultural factors) for that individual.
  • For Example,
Event Classification InterpretationQ
Accident Disease Impairs function of a person
Loss of foot Impairment Loss of anatomical structure in the form of foot
Cannot Walk Disability Walking is a normal routine daily activity of a human being
Unemployed Handicap Loses out his job because he cannot walk, so cannot fulfill his role in the society, i.e., earning for his family members

questions.text: Eight months old child had history of unusual crying and convulsions following previous vaccination after BCG, DPT & OPV (first dose) and Hepatitis B. Now parents have brought child for next doses of vaccination. Which vaccine is contraindicated in this situation?
questions.solution:
DPT

  • Unusual crying following DPT is most likely to be Persistent Inconsolable Screaming.
  • Similarly, convulsions are most likely to be d/t DPT.
  • Hence, DPT should not be given subsequently.
  • It can be replaced by DT.

Learning Objective: Following DTaP vaccination, it is very uncommon for symptoms to include soreness or swelling where the injection was administered, fever, fussiness, fatigue, lack of appetite, and vomiting. Less frequently, after receiving the DTaP vaccine, people experience more severe responses such as convulsions, non-stop sobbing for three hours or more, or high temperature (above 105°F).

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of fever, severe watery diarrhea, vomiting, and decreased urination. On history taking the mother revealed that she is not been able to follow the vaccination schedule for the baby correctly. The baby is infected with rotavirus as per the physician. Rotavirus vaccine schedule can be given till the age of?
questions.solution:
Option D: 12 months

  • Routine rotavirus vaccination recommended for all infants begins at 6 weeks of age (1 dose), followed by 1 dose each at 10th & 14 weeks of age.
  • Rotavirus vaccine can be given up to 1 year of age according to the National Immunization Schedule.

questions.text: In a study, it was found that eating vegetables rich in beta-carotene could reduce cancer. But there can be other factors like a high-fiber diet, which could also be responsible for this. This is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Confounding factor

  • High fiber diet is associated with vegetables rich in beta-carotene.
  • Also, a high-fiber diet is associated with decreased incidences of certain cancers, especially colonic cancers.
  • Now, since the high-fiber diet is present with both the cause and the effect independently and is distributed unevenly in the case and the control group, it can be called a confounding factor.

Option B: Multifactorial causation

  • Also, it can be due to multifactorial causation, if both carotene and a high-fiber diet are associated with reduced cancer incidence.
  • Since we have to select only one option, and from other studies, we do know that vitamin doesn’t decrease the risk of cancer, the best option will be a confounding factor.

Option C: Causal association

Temporal association

  • It implies ‘cause precedes effect’ or ‘effect follows cause'.
  • It is the most important criterion of a causal association.
  • It is best established by a cohort study (Especially by a concurrent cohort study) as a cohort study is a forward study.

Option D: Common association

  • In the given question there is no common association between carotene and a high-fiber diet.
  • Therefore this option is also incorrect.

questions.text: The hemoglobin level of pregnant females in a community was found to have a mean of 10.6 g/dL and a standard deviation of 2 g/dL. What is the minimum hemoglobin level below which 5% of the pregnant females will have their hemoglobin levels?
questions.solution:
Option A: 7.32

  • 2.5% of the population will have a Hb less than (Mean – 2SD) = (10.6) – 2(2) = 6.6
  • Since we need a value below which 5% values will lie, we need a value between –1SD and –2SD i.e., between 6.6 and 8.6,
  • Hence, 7.32 is the only available value in this range.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain, Bartonian lines on gums, facial pallor, wrist drop, and colic. The condition was diagnosed as lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most common mode of absorption of Lead?
questions.solution:
Option B: Inhalation

  • The most common mode of absorption of Lead is by inhalation.
  • Most commonly seen with Occupational exposure · i.e Paint industries, pipe industries, plumbing industries, etc. 

Option A: Ingestion

 

  • Oral ingestion 
    • Children accidentally eat lead paint.
    • Consuming contaminated water stored in lead cisterns.

Option C: Direct skin contact

 

  • Percutaneous [through the skin]- People working in chemical factories, particularly jet fuels, and gasoline.

Option D: None of the above

  • This is not the appropriate answer to the above-given question.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented to the hospital 5 days after getting bitten by a street dog with complaints of headache, fever, agitation, and confusion. Which of the following is the best specimen for the diagnosis of this condition in a living person?

choices.text: Biopsy of skin follicles on the neck

questions.solution:
Answer

Option B: Biopsy of skin follicles on the neck

  • Rabies can be confirmed in patients early in the illness by antigen detection using immunofluorescence of skin biopsy.
  • A biopsy of skin follicles on the neck is the best specimen for the diagnosis of rabies in a living person

Other options

Option A: Corneal smear

  • The fluorescent antibody technique can be performed on a corneal smear. However, it has been reported to have low sensitivity and limited accuracy for antemortem rabies diagnosis. Additionally, due to the risk of corneal scarification, the fluorescent antibody technique on corneal impressions is not advised as a routine test, particularly in patients with encephalitis rather than rabies.

Options C: CSF

  • Neutralizing antibodies are not usually detectable in serum or CSF before the eighth day.

Option D: Saliva

  • Saliva is disregarded due to its low sensitivity.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male came to the OPD with a chief complaint of jaw discomfort and inability to open his mouth fully for 3 days. He also said he had struck his right shin with a hammer 10 days ago. On examination, he was unable to open his jaw wider than 1 inch. The clinical diagnosis of tetanus was made by the physician. Which of the following statements are true regarding Tetanus?

choices.text: One dose of TT gives Life long immunity

questions.solution:
Option A: No period of communicability

  • Period of communicability: NONE (Not transmitted from person to person).

Other options

Option B: India eliminated tetanus in 2010

  • India declared maternal and neonatal tetanus elimination on July 2016.

Option C: Also known as 2nd-day disease

  • 8th Day Disease: Tetanus neonatorum

Option D: One dose of TT gives Life long immunity

  • One dose of TT does not give lifelong immunity.
  • The primary course of tetanus immunization: 3 doses of DPT at intervals of 4-8 weeks starting at 6 weeks age (to be followed by boosters at 18 months, 5-6 years, 10 years, and 16 years age).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy, adequately vaccinated according to his age, was brought to emergency with a 3-day history of fever, rash, irritability, and poor feeding.
