After a few days, the baby developed non-purulent conjunctivitis and foot edema. Her mother also complained of his tongue turning into a deep red tongue and appearing swollen. A differential diagnosis of Kawasaki disease was made. What is the cardinal feature of Kawasaki disease apparent on blood reports?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thrombocytosis

Diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease 

The diagnosis of Kawasaki disease requires the presence of fever lasting at least five days without any other explanation combined with at least four of the five following criteria: 

  • bilateral bulbar conjunctiva injection 

  • oral mucous membrane changes, including infected fissured lips, infected pharynx, or strawberry tongue 

  • peripheral extremity changes, including erythema of plasma or soles, edema of hands or feet (acute phase), and periungual desquamation (convalescent phase)

  • polymorphous rash 

  • cervical lymphadenopathy (at least one lymph node >1.5 cm in diameter)

  • Kawasaki disease is acute inflammatory vasculitis of the middle and small arteries.
  • It is associated with coronary artery weakening and aneurysms in about 15-25% of untreated cases.
  •  Thrombocytosis is a characteristic finding in Kawasaki disease that occurs in 2nd to 3rd week of illness.
  • It has been reported that platelets are not only activated but also hyperactive, which increases the chance of thrombosis in already weakened vessels. 
  • Giant cell arteritis is inflammation of specific arteries near the temples.
  • The most common symptoms of giant cell arteritis are:
    • Severe head pain and tenderness, which usually affects both temples.
    • Head pain can worsen over time, come and go, or subside briefly.

Treatment:

  • Platelet-lowering medications, primarily hydroxyurea (Droxia, Hydrea) or interferon alfa (Intron A).
  •  Platelets can be removed from your blood via a dialysis-like procedure.

Other options

Option B: Thrombocytopenia

  • Thrombocytopenia is a temporary uncommon feature of Kawasaki disease.
  • It is usually seen in the acute phases of the disease.
  • It is usually apparent on blood reports and doesn't appear clinically. 
  • Thrombocytopenia is a condition in which the platelet count in your blood is abnormally low.
  • Platelets are tiny blood cells that develop from larger cells in the bone marrow
  • Platelets stick together to form a plug to seal your wound when you are injured.
  • This plug is known as a blood clot.

Option C: Increased hemoglobin

  • A high hemoglobin count occurs most commonly when your body requires more oxygen-carrying capacity, usually due to smoking.
  • Because you live at a high elevation, your red blood cell production naturally increases to compensate for the lower oxygen supply.
  • There is no effect on hemoglobin in the case of Kawasaki disease.

Option D: Decreased hematocrit

  • Hematocrit lower than normal can indicate: an insufficient supply of healthy red blood cells (anemia)
  • Many white blood cells result from chronic illness, infection, or a white blood cell disorder such as leukemia or lymphoma.
  • Deficiencies in vitamins or minerals Blood loss, recent or long-term
  • There is no effect on hematocrit in the case of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency with a sudden onset of weakness on the right side of her body and the left side of her face. She has hypertension, dyslipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. Examination shows decreased motor tone and power on the right side. On eye examination, she has diplopia on the left lateral gaze. The plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the right side. A CT scan of the head and neck shows a brainstem lesion. What will be the site of the lesion found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Left pons

  • The pons is part of the brainstem located midway between the midbrain and medulla oblongata. The structure of pons is as follows:

  • It carries contralateral corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts and ipsilateral cranial nerve nucleus.
  • Damage to one side of the pons will produce symptoms of ipsilateral cranial nerve damage and contralateral motor weakness.
  • Millard-Gubler syndrome (ventral pontine syndrome):
  • Symptoms result from the functional loss of several anatomical structures of the ventral pons, including the sixth and seventh cranial nerves and fibres of the corticospinal tract.
  • Causes of it include:
  1. Stroke
  2. Demyelination disease
  3. Tumours
  • It affects the following structures:
  1. Facial nucleus
  2. Abducens nucleus
  3. Pyramidal tracts
    • Its symptoms include:
  2. Contralateral weakness of the body
  3. Ipsilateral facial weakness
  4. Diplopia

Option A: Right pons

  • The lesion in the right pons results in
  • Right-sided facial weakness
  • Diplopia on the right lateral gaze
  • Left-sided motor weakness of the body

Option C: Right midbrain

  • The lesion in the midbrain may present as:
  • On the side of the lesion:
  • Eye "down and out" secondary to unopposed action of fourth and sixth cranial nerves, with
  • Dilated and unresponsive pupil due to damage to the third cranial nerve
  • Contralateral to the side of the lesion:
  • Paralysis of the face, arm, and leg (corticobulbar and corticospinal tract)

Option D: Left midbrain

  • Medial left midbrain lesion will present as ipsilateral down and out an eye with contralateral paralysis of the face, arm and legs

questions.text: A 67-year-old male complained of generalized fatigue associated with difficulty breathing. On examination, pallor & gingival hypertrophy is noted. Initial investigations revealed hyperleukocytosis. Follow-up investigations showed leukostasis. This feature is most predominantly seen in which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML)

  • Leukostasis (also called symptomatic hyperleukocytosis) is a medical emergency most commonly seen in patients with acute myeloid leukaemia. 
  • It is characterized by an extremely elevated blast cell count and symptoms of decreased tissue perfusion.
  • The most common symptoms are dyspnea and hypoxia, usually accompanied by visual changes, headache, dizziness, confusion, somnolence and coma.
  • Hyperleukocytosis and leukostasis syndrome are commonly associated with a complication of acute leukaemia (particularly myeloid leukaemia).
  • It can occur when the peripheral blast cell count is >100,000/mL.
  • The frequency of hyperleukocytosis is 13% in acute myeloid leukaemia (AML); however, leukostasis is rare in lymphoid leukaemia.

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

  • Leukostasis is seen primarily in myeloid leukaemia and is very rare in lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Chronic myelocytic leukaemia (CML)

  • Leukostasis is seen very rarely seen in Chronic myeloid leukaemia
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL)

  • Leukostasis is seen primarily in myeloid leukaemia and is very rare in lymphocytic leukaemia.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male came with complaints of 1 episode of bloody vomiting suggesting acute upper GI bleeding. Which of the following would be the least common cause in patients with acute upper GI bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option D: Vascular ectasia

  • GAVE (Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia), also known as “Watermelon Stomach”, is a condition in which the blood vessels in the lining of the stomach become fragile and become prone to rupture and bleeding.
  • The stomach lining exhibits the characteristic stripes of a watermelon when viewed by endoscopy.
  • Endoscopic therapy, particularly with Argon Plasma Coagulation, has shown to be as effective and safer than surgery and should be considered the first-line treatment for patients with GAVE-related bleeding.

Source of bleeding

The proportion of patients, %

Vascular ectasia

0-6%

 

Option A: Mallory Weiss tear

  • A Mallory-Weiss tear is a tear of the tissue of the lower oesophagus. It is most often caused by violent coughing or vomiting.
  • A Mallory-Weiss tear can be diagnosed and treated during an endoscopic procedure.
  • If the tear is not treated, it can lead to anaemia, fatigue, shortness of breath, and even shock.
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome is most commonly characterized by abdominal pain, severe vomiting, vomiting of blood (hematemesis), and the involuntary effort to vomit (retching).
  • The blood is often clotted and appears as "coffee grounds". The stools may be as dark as tar (melanic).

 

Option B: Ulcer

  • A peptic ulcer is a sore on the stomach lining, small intestine or oesophagus.
  • A peptic ulcer in the stomach is called a gastric ulcer.
  • A duodenal ulcer is a peptic ulcer that develops in the first part of the small intestine (duodenum).
  • An oesophageal ulcer occurs in the lower part of the oesophagus.
  • Stomach ulcers are usually caused by an infection of Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) bacteria or from taking anti-inflammatory medicines (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen and aspirin.

 

Option C: Varices

  • Varices are dilated veins in the distal oesophagus or proximal stomach caused by elevated pressure in the portal venous system, typically from cirrhosis.
  • They may bleed massively but cause no other symptoms. Diagnosis is by upper endoscopy.
  • Treatment is primarily with endoscopic banding and IV octreotide.
  • Gastric varices (GV) are a bunch of vessels in the mucosa/submucosa of the stomach and part of a complex collection of vascular shunts between the portal and systemic circulation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with diazepam and alcohol overdose. She is comatose. The temperature is 34.5°C. BP is 100/80 mmHg. Creatinine is 2.4mg/dL, AST-500, GGT-35 IU. The urine dipstick showed 3+ for blood, but urine analysis was normal. USG abdomen was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rhabdomyolysis

  • In the setting of a drug overdose, the patient has presented with hypothermia and deranged kidney function.
  • The keyword in the question is “urine dipstick is 3+ for blood, but urine microscopy is normal”. This implies that myoglobin in urine is giving a false positive report for blood detected by urine dipstick.

Rhabdomyolysis causes:

  • Traumatic crush injuries
  • Alcohol intoxication with prolonged immobility
  • Prolonged seizures activity
  • Excessive exercise
  • Heatstroke
  • Myopathies, drug-induced, metabolic or inflammatory

Clinical Manifestations

In adults, Rhabdomyolysis is characterised by the triad of:

  1. Muscle weakness
  2. Myalgia
  3. Dark urine

Lab findings:

  • Elevation of creatinine kinase.
  • Myoglobin is not protein bound and can easily be detected in urine (half-life: 2-3 hours).
  • Other manifestations include hepatic dysfunction, AKI, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia and hyperuricemia (release of purines from damaged muscles).

Option A: Hypothermia

  • Hypothermia can cause AKI and LOC but rarely cause myoglobin in the urine

Option B: Alcoholic Hallucinosis

  • Alcoholic hallucinosis is characterised by auditory hallucinations, paranoid symptoms and fear.
  • Overdose can cause AKI but does not cause myoglobinuria and rhabdomyolysis

Option D: Acute interstitial nephritis

  • Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) is a renal lesion that typically causes a decline in kidney function and is characterised by an inflammatory infiltrate in the kidney interstitium.
  • Although diazepam and alcohol can cause it, but due to this, myoglobin does not appear in the urine.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presents to the clinic and complains of blood in urine, nausea, weakness and swelling of both legs and puffiness of the face. Her blood pressure is 150/110 mmHg, and her pulse is 80 beats/min. She does not recall getting sick in the recent past. Urine analysis is done, which shows nonselective proteinuria and red cell casts. Her BUN and creatinine are 70 mg/dl and 3.0 mg/dl, respectively. Renal biopsy showed glomerular crescents. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis

  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is an inflammatory condition causing rapid destruction of glomeruli, leading to end-stage renal disease.
  • It is characterised by hematuria and nephritic range proteinuria ( <3.5g/day)
  • Patients can rapidly progress to renal failure leading to anuria and anasarca.
  • Crescents on renal biopsy are an affirmative sign of RPGN.
  • It can be treated with steroids and cyclophosphamide.

Option A: Membranous Nephropathy

  • Membranous nephropathy is the most common nephrotic syndrome in adults.
  • It is characterised by nonselective proteinuria ( > 3.5g/day), which can manifest as oedema, a prothrombotic state, and increased susceptibility to infections.
  • It is usually associated with autoimmune conditions (e.g. SLE), infections (e.g. hepatitis B, hepatitis C) or solid organ malignancies (e.g. lung, breast, etc.)
  • It does not cause hematuria.

Option B: Minimal Change Disease

  • Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in children and presents with selective proteinuria.
  • The patient presents with hyperlipidemia and oedema.
  • It is usually idiopathic but can be caused by secondary conditions, including immunisations, infections, and malignancies.
  • It can be treated with steroids.

Option D: Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis

  • Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN) usually occurs 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or skin infection.
  • PSGN will have nephritic range proteinuria, deformed RBCs, and RBC casts in urine.
  • The diagnosis can be confirmed by looking for evidence of streptococcal infection (ASO titers, throat culture for pharyngitis, wound culture for skin infection) and complement levels.
  • However, this patient does not mention any recent illnesses in history, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant was brought to you with a history of hypotonia, seizures, failure to thrive & growth retardation. He is noted to have the appearance of the characteristic sparse, fragile, kinky hair and hypo-pigmented skin. Initial investigations revealed anaemia & neutropenia. A probable diagnosis of Menke’s kinky (Steely) hair disease was made. Which of the following results would usually be seen in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option A: Low copper levels.

  • Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disease that occurs due to a mutation in the ATP7A gene leading to defective Menkes protein.
  • The defective Menkes protein causes abnormal absorption and transport of copper.
  • Low copper levels lead to decreased lysyl oxidase activity, as copper is an essential enzyme cofactor.
  • The decreased activity of lysyl oxidase causes defective collagen production, leading to various clinical features.

Clinical Features

  • Progressive cerebral degeneration, growth retardation.
  • Hypotonia, seizures.
  • Hypo-pigmented skin and hair.
  • Sparse, brittle, kinky hair.
  • Scurvy-like bone changes.
  • Anemia and neutropenia.
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Pili torti, trichorrhexis, and monilethrix may occur.

Other options

Option B: Low zinc levels

  • Low zinc levels do not cause Menkes disease.
  • Symptoms of low zinc levels include delayed wound healing, suppressed immunity, male hypogonadism, hair loss, and loss of taste and smell.

Option C: Low iron levels

  • Low iron levels do not cause Menkes disease.
  • It causes iron deficiency anaemia as fatigue, conjunctival pallor, koilonychia and pica.

Option D: Low ceruloplasmin levels

  • Low ceruloplasmin is seen in Wilson’s disease and not in Menkes disease.

questions.text: What is the reason for the increased bilirubin level in prehepatic jaundice?

choices.text: Decreased bilirubin production in the liver.
Bilirubin cannot be excreted from the liver.
Increased hemolysis of red blood cells.

questions.solution:
Here are four options to consider:

Option 1: Decreased bilirubin production in the liver. Explanation: This is not the correct answer. In prehepatic jaundice, the liver is functioning normally in terms of bilirubin production. The issue is primarily due to an increased breakdown of red blood cells, leading to an excess of unconjugated bilirubin.

Option 2: Liver dysfunction impairs bilirubin processing. Explanation: This is not the correct answer. In prehepatic jaundice, the liver itself is not dysfunctional; it's the excessive breakdown of red blood cells that results in increased unconjugated bilirubin levels. The liver's ability to process bilirubin is not impaired.

Option 3: Bilirubin cannot be excreted from the liver. Explanation: This is not the correct answer. In prehepatic jaundice, bilirubin can be produced and processed by the liver. However, the problem lies in the increased production of unconjugated bilirubin due to hemolysis, and this bilirubin cannot be efficiently excreted by the liver.

Option 4: Increased hemolysis of red blood cells. Explanation: This is the correct answer. In prehepatic jaundice, the main reason for increased bilirubin levels is the increased breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis), which leads to an excess of unconjugated bilirubin in the bloodstream. The liver is not the primary cause of the problem, as it is still capable of processing bilirubin, but it cannot keep up with the excessive production due to hemolysis.

So, the correct answer is option 4: Increased hemolysis of red blood cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with complaints of intermittent headaches and palpitations for the past 8 months. He is noted to have profuse sweating. On examination, his blood pressure is 180/95 mmHg. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 108 beats/min. The physician suspects this is a case of Pheochromocytoma. Which is the best imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: MRI abdomen

Imaging

Sensitivity

Specificity

CT

++++

+++

MRI

++++

+++

MIBG scintigraphy

+++

++++

Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy

++

++

Fluoro – DOPA PET/CT

+++

++++

  • Imaging studies such as CT scans and MRIs are diagnostic tests of choice for pheochromocytomas.

  • CT and MRI are the most sensitive tests to diagnose this disease.

  • CT scans may be more advantageous over MRI, but the latter has no exposure to ionising radiation.

Option A: MIBG Scintigraphy

  • MIBG Scintigraphy is highly specific but not as sensitive as an MRI. The quality of the image is also subjective, depending on the centre carrying it out.

Option B:  Somatostatin Scintigraphy

  • Somatostatin scintigraphy is used to diagnose carcinoid tumours and not Pheochromocytoma.

Option C: PET DOPA

  • PET DOPA is the most advanced imaging technique to diagnose Pheochromocytoma. However, it is not as widely available.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the clinic complaining of short height, fatigue, and weight gain. An order is made for blood tests of TSH and T4 levels.  Her Free T4 was low, and her TSH was increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Primary hypothyroidism

  • The clinical picture of short stature with low T4 and elevated TSH suggests primary hypothyroidism. 

Other options

Option A: Pituitary adenoma

  • Pituitary adenoma can produce any hormone, and if it produces TSH, then T4 should be elevated

Option B: TSH-secreting pituitary tumour

  • Both TSH and T4 levels should have been elevated if it was TSH secreting tumour

Option C: Thyroid target receptor insensitivity

  • It is characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels and inappropriately normal or elevated TSH.
  • The clinical features of Resistance to Thyroid Hormone include goitre, attention deficit disorder, mild reduction in I.Q., delayed skeletal maturation, tachycardia, and impaired metabolic responses to thyroid hormone.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient who recently underwent lobectomy for bronchogenic carcinoma has come to OPD for a follow-up. Which of the following finding will you expect in the Pulmonary function test/Spirometry?
questions.solution:
Option C: Increased dead space ventilation

  • In the case of lobectomy, since the remaining lung tissue is lesser, all parameters like vital capacity, residual volume, and closing volume will reduce.
  • Hence, post-operative lobectomy patients will take rapid shallow breaths due to hypoxic stimulus.
  • This will lead to increased Dead space ventilation.

Option A: Increased residual volume

  • After lobectomy, residual volume decreases.

Option B: Increased vital capacity

  • After lobectomy, vital capacity decreases

 Option D: Increased closing volume

  • After lobectomy, closing volume decreases

questions.text: A 64-year-old female patient presents to the clinic complaining of acute cough, purulent sputum production, and fever. He has a medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. CT image is given below. Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Mycobacterium Avium Intercellulare- Upper lobe bronchiectasis
End-stage fibrotic lung disease- Lower lung bronchiectasis

questions.solution:
Option A: Mycobacterium Avium Intercellulare- Upper lobe bronchiectasis

  • CT image reveals bronchiectasis and peribronchial infiltration on the left lower lobe of the lung.
  • Bronchiectasis is a disease characterized by progressive, irreversible dilation of the bronchial trees resulting in permanently dilated airways.
  • Clinical manifestations include cough with mucopurulent sputum lasting for months to years.
  • Other symptoms include shortness of breath, hemoptysis, chest pain, and recurrent pulmonary infections.
  • Causes and association of bronchiectasis based on lobes of the lung are:
Upper lobe bronchiectasis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Post-radiation fibrosis
Mid lung bronchiectasis
  • M.A.I ( Mycobacterium Avium Intercellular)
  • Immotile Cilia Syndrome
Lower lung bronchiectasis
  • Chronic recurrent aspiration
  • End-stage fibrotic lung disease
  • Recurrent immunodeficiency-associated infections
Central bronchiectasis
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA)
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Mounier Kuhn Syndrome (cartilage deficiency leading to tracheomegaly)
  • William Campbell syndrome
  • Ct scan is the most important modality for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis.
  • It demonstrates the airways and, to some degree, can help distinguish the underlying cause.
  • The treatment of bronchiectasis is medical, and treatment is aimed at sputum clearance.
  • Surgical resection of the affected lobe and lung transplantation may be considered in some cases.

Option B: ABPA - Central bronchiectasis

  • Central bronchiectasis is characterized by the involvement of bronchi within the central third of lung parenchyma.
  • Some of the causes are ABPA, cystic fibrosis, etc.

Option C: End-stage fibrotic lung disease- Lower lung bronchiectasis

  • The lower lobe is the most common zone for bronchiectasis development.
  • It is mostly idiopathic but can be seen in end-stage fibrotic lung disease, chronic recurrent aspiration, recurrent childhood infections, etc.

Option D: Immotile Cilia syndrome- Mid-lung bronchiectasis

  • Mid-lung bronchiectasis is when the bronchiectasis is confined to the middle lobes.
  • It is seen in immotile cilia syndrome and non-tuberculous mycobacterial infections.

questions.text: A 20-year-old sailor presents to the emergency with symptoms of atypical pneumonia. Which of the following would be the best test to rule out Mycoplasma infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: PCR of respiratory secretions

  • Acute Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection can be diagnosed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) by detecting the organism in respiratory tract secretions.
  • Oropharyngeal, nasopharyngeal, and pulmonary specimens are acceptable for diagnosing M. pneumoniae pneumonia.

Option B: Gram stain of trans-tracheal aspirate

  • M. pneumonia is gram indeterminate because it lacks a cell wall stained by the dye in gram staining.

Option C: Culture of trans-tracheal aspirate

  • M. pneumoniae culture requiring special media is not recommended for routine diagnosis because the organism may take weeks to grow and is often difficult to isolate from clinical specimens.
  • In contrast, PCR allows rapid, specific diagnosis earlier in clinical illness.

Option D: CXR

  • A chest radiograph of atypical pneumonia would be no different from any other organism that causes pneumonia.
  • X-ray alone cannot determine the causative organism of pneumonia.

questions.text: A 49-year-old human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive patient with no history of diabetes, hypertension, or renal disease visited the clinic for his regular check-up. His routine labs show creatinine of 4.5mg/dl. The physician suspects HIV-induced nephropathy (HIVAN). Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Shrunken kidneys

  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-associated nephropathy is a serious disorder that can cause lifelong kidney damage.
  • It can cause thrombotic microangiopathy and HIV-immune-complex kidney disease. It mostly affects the glomerulus.
  • The injury is distinguished by significant podocyte foot process effacement caused by direct HIV infection of renal epithelial cells, intrarenal viral gene expression, and host gene dysregulation.
  • Histology may reveal collapsing glomerulopathy and accompanying tubulointerstitial illness, including tubular microcysts and interstitial inflammation.
  • Proteinuria is a defining feature of this illness. A sonogram shows larger, hyperechogenic kidneys.
  • Renal biopsy provides a reliable diagnosis. Patients with HIV-associated nephropathy should be treated for their HIV infection regardless of CD4+ T cell level, along with ACE inhibitors and prednisone.
  • A shrunken kidney is not a feature of HIV-induced nephropathy.

Option A: Proteinuria

  • HIV-associated nephropathy classically presents a swift decline in GFR and proteinuria in the nephrotic range.
  • Other manifestations of nephropathy, such as peripheral oedema of the lower extremities and hypertension, are uncommon in this population.

Option C: 15% of cases show mesangial proliferation

  • Renal biopsy and Light microscopy of HIV nephropathy patients usually reveal different degrees of capillary collapse (collapsing glomerulopathy) and enlarged mesangial matrix, suggesting that mesangial hypercellularity is a feature of this condition.

Option D: Develops when CD4 < 200 cells/cu.mm

  • HIVAN is frequently associated with advanced HIV-1 infection. 
  • Patients usually present with high viral load, low CD4 count, and heavy proteinuria.
  • 80%-90% of HIVAN patients have a CD4-positive T-cell count of 200 cells/mm.

questions.text: A 70-year-old hypertensive patient presented to the outpatient department complaining of sudden onset of palpitations, dizziness and loss of consciousness. On examination, his heart rate was 72 beats/minute, and his Blood pressure was 150/100 mmHg. ECG was done, which showed the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Atrial flutter

  • The common right atrial flutter (also called cavotricuspid isthmus dependent atrial flutter) occurs due to a circuit around the tricuspid valve annulus, bounded anteriorly by the annulus and posteriorly by the functional conduction block in the crista terminalis. The wavefront passes between the inferior venacava and the tricuspid valve annulus, known as the cavotricuspid isthmus.
  • It is associated with atrial fibrillation and often with an atrial scar from senescence or prior cardiac surgery.
  • ECG in the lead II, III and aVF shows the presence of flutter waves (Negative saw tooth pattern).
  • 3-4 flutter waves before every narrow QRS complex.
  • The positive p wave is visible in the lead V1.
  • Since the ventricular rate is 75 bpm (RR interval), the atrial rate shall be obtained by multiplying the ventricular rate by 4, which is 300 bpm (240-350 bpm)
  • The presence of risk factors for hypertension also gives a clue to the diagnosis of atrial flutter.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation

  • Atrial fibrillation's atrial rate is around 300 to 600 beats per minute.
  • Because the arterial rate is high, the action potential produced is low amplitude.
  • In patients with Atrial fibrillation, P wave will not be seen
  • Irregular R-R interval

Option C: Multifocal atrial tachycardia

  • The transient rhythm between atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter
  • ECG findings include
    1. Irregular R-R interval
    2. Variable P wave morphology: ≥ 3 different P wave morphology
    3. Variable P-R interval: Usually variable P-R interval is seen with Brady arrhythmias
    4. Right axis deviation will be present

Option D: PSVT

  • Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia
  • ECG findings of PSVT
    1. Narrow QRS complex
    2. R-R interval decreased
    3. Hidden P waves due to the merging of P and the T waves
  • ST segment depression: Because of the mismatch between demand and supply of oxygen the will be some magnitude of ST-segment depression

questions.text: A 45-year-old female tourist to India presents with a complaint of diffuse chest pain. There is no personal history and no family history of heart disease, hypertension, and diabetes. She is admitted for observation, and the next morning she has a recurrence of chest pain, and ECG shows ST elevation in V1 to V4. Troponin is normal, and pain is promptly relieved by sublingual nitroglycerine. Which of the following is the best management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Exercise stress testing and long-acting nitrates
Coronary angiography with long-acting nitrates and CCB

questions.solution:
Option C: Coronary angiography with long-acting nitrates and CCB

  • The clinical features in these cases are most suggestive of vasospastic angina or Prinzmetal angina.
  • Prinzmetal or vasospastic angina is caused by the transient spasm of coronary arteries. There is no direct association with atherothrombotic occlusion; however, these spasms usually occur close to the areas of coronary stenosis.
  • The clinical features that suggest the diagnosis of vasospastic angina, in this case, are transient chest pain with transient ST elevation, occurring at rest or without known precipitant, and relieving by nitrates. Moreover, the relatively younger age, along with the absence of typical risk factors of heart disease (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia) and the absence of a family history of heart disease, point towards the diagnosis of vasospastic angina.
  • In vasospastic angina, the ECG shows evidence of ischemia during pain, sometimes with ST-segment elevation. The cardiac enzymes are not elevated.
  • On coronary angiography, vasospastic angina is characterized by the demonstration of no significant obstruction of major coronary vessels. The angiography can help reveal coronary vasospasm during the acute attack (the spasm can be provoked using acetylcholine or ergonovine).
  • The treatment of vasospastic angina comprises long-acting nitrates along with calcium channel blockers.

Option A: Echocardiography and anti-inflammatory therapy

  • Echocardiography will offer no diagnostic help in the setting of acute chest pain suggestive of vasospastic angina.
  • There is no role of anti-inflammatory therapy in vasospastic angina. It is mainly treated by nitrates and calcium channel blockers.

Option B: Exercise stress testing and long-acting nitrates

  • Exercise stress testing and long-acting nitrates are done for chronic stable angina. In the case of vasospastic angina, the initial goal is to control the coronary spasm with a calcium channel blocker. Nitrates can be added to provide symptomatic control.

Option D: Thallium scan and long-acting nitrates

  • Thallium scans and long-acting nitrates are used for chronic stable angina. In vasospastic angina, the goal is to control the coronary spasm with a calcium channel blocker. Nitrates can be added to provide symptomatic control.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the emergency room complaining of chest pain, palpitations and shortness of breath. ECG shows P wave is tall in lead II and upright in V1 along with right axis deviation. Based on the information provided, what appropriate auscultatory findings will be noted?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above:

  • The first heart sound (S1 ) is usually accentuated in the early stages of the disease and slightly delayed.
  • The pulmonic component of the second heart sound (P2 ) also is often accentuated with elevated PAPs, and the two components of the second heart sound (S2 ) are closely split.
  • The mitral valve's opening snap (OS) is most readily audible in expiration at, or just medial to, the cardiac apex.
  • This sound generally follows the sound of aortic valve closure (A2 ) by 0.05–0.12 s.
  • The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with the severity of the MS.
  • The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, diastolic murmur, heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position; it is accentuated by mild exercise (e.g., a few rapid sit-ups) carried out just before auscultation.
  • In general, this murmur's duration correlates with the stenosis's severity in patients with preserved CO.
  • The S1 sound is initially narrow split and then heard as a single sound which then progresses to reverse splitting.
  • In patients with sinus rhythm, the murmur often reappears or becomes louder during atrial systole (presystolic accentuation).
  • Soft, grade I or II/VI systolic murmurs may be heard at or medial to the apex and signify mixed mitral valve disease with regurgitation.
  • Hepatomegaly, ankle oedema, ascites, and pleural effusion may occur in patients with MS and RV failure, particularly in the right pleural cavity.

Option A: Narrow split S1

  • In the initial stages of the disease, there is a narrow splitting of S1.

Option B: Single S1

  • In moderate cases, S1 becomes single.

Option C: Reverse split S1

  • In severe MS, there is often the reverse splitting of S1.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of fever, altered sensorium and purpuric rash for two days. On examination, the patient is found stuporous. He has a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and extensive palpable purpura over the legs. Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial choice of antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ceftriaxone

  • The clinical features are suggestive of Meningococcal sepsis.
  • Usually, asymptomatic nasopharyngeal colonisation
  • Early symptoms
    • Fever, headache and myalgia accompanied by vomiting and abdominal pain.
    • Non-blanching rash (>80%), if present, may appear to be early in the course until petechiae or purpuric lesions develop.
    • Purpura fulminans occur in severe cases with multiple large purpuric lesions and signs of peripheral ischemia.
  • Late symptoms
    • Meningitis (30% -50%)
    • Septicemia (20%)
  • Empirical antibiotic therapy for suspected Meningococcal disease consists of a third-generation cephalosporin such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime.

Option A: Vancomycin

  • Vancomycin can be used to treat penicillin- and cephalosporin-resistant S. pneumonia.

Option B: Penicillin G

  • Ceftriaxone and cefotaxime are the best initial antibiotics for meningococcal meningitis.
  • Penicillin G is the antibiotic of choice for susceptible strains of meningococcal meningitis.

Option C: Ciprofloxacin

  • Fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin are not adequate to treat meningococcal meningitis

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient presents to the emergency floor after a road traffic accident. He is unconscious and has a very low respiratory rate. He is immediately admitted to the ICU. His ABGs reveal respiratory alkalosis. Which type of ventilation is most likely associated with respiratory alkalosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Assisted control ventilation

  • In assisted controlled mechanical ventilation, the programming is done to initiate ventilator-associated breaths after a fixed interval, for example, every 5 seconds.
  • However, in between this 5-second interval, if there is a spontaneous breathing effort on the part of the patient, then the ventilator will kick in and aid the patient in taking a breath.
  • This can lead to hyperventilation and the development of respiratory alkalosis.

Option B: Non-invasive ventilation

  • It provides oxygen to the patient without passing an endotracheal tube.
  • There are different non-invasive ventilation methods like face masks, non-rebreather masks, BiPAP and CPAP.
  • There are fewer chances of respiratory alkalosis compared to assisted control ventilation.

Option C: Pressure-controlled ventilation

  • This type of ventilation is given in cases of severe respiratory failure like ARDS and lung atelectasis.
  • A fixed positive airway pressure is provided to inflate the lungs. The ventilator does not determine the tidal volume.
  • This type of ventilation does not lead to respiratory alkalosis.

Option D: SIMV

  • Synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV) is a type of assisted control ventilation.
  • It also provides a fixed tidal volume at a fixed respiratory rate while allowing spontaneous breaths.
  • However, in SIMV, the patient determines the tidal volume in triggered breaths which may be smaller than in non-triggered breaths.
  • Consequently, there are fewer chances of hyperventilation and developing respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the pulmonary outpatient department with the symptoms of a non-productive cough and low-grade fever associated with night sweats for the last 2 months. He has a 20-year smoking history. His blood pressure is 140/90mmHg, his pulse rate is 90 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute. His examination reveals bilaterally decreased breath sounds. The chest x-ray shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates suggestive of miliary tuberculosis. The picture of the chest x-ray is shown below. This military pattern can occur due to spread from?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lymphatics

  • Mycobacterium Tuberculosis causes pulmonary tuberculosis (TB).
  • Miliary tuberculosis is a potentially fatal form of disseminated disease.
  • Miliary tuberculosis occurs due to the hematogenous spread of tubercle bacilli to the lungs and other organs.
  • It results in the formation of millet seed-sized (1 to 2 mm) tuberculous foci.

Miliary pulmonary disease

Miliary systemic disease

It occurs in primary progressive pulmonary TB when organisms in the draining lymph nodes erode into the pulmonary arteries. This distributes the infection to both lung fields.

Once the infection in the lung reaches the pulmonary vein, the bacteria can reach the left side heart. Subsequently, they can seed organs like the liver and spleen.
  • The clinical features include low-grade fever, weight loss, and non-productive cough.
  • Focused patient history, microscopy for acid-fast bacilli, Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT), chest imaging, and mycobacterium culture are used to confirm the diagnosis.
  • TB spreads by lymphatics, pulmonary artery, and bronchial vein.
  • Treatment ensures the reduction of disease severity and eradication of acid-fast bacilli by anti-tuberculous drugs.

Option B: Pulmonary Vein

  • Pulmonary vein disorder includes pulmonary hypertension.
  • It is not involved in the spread of pulmonary tuberculosis.
  • Pulmonary tuberculosis spreads via the bronchial vein, not the pulmonary vein.

Option C: Alveoli

  • Alveoli are involved in pneumonia.
  • Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi.
  • The infection causes the alveoli to become inflamed and fill up with fluid or pus.
  • Alveoli have no role in the seeding of tuberculous infection in the lungs 

Option D: Trachea

  • The windpipe or trachea splits into two bronchi that enter the lungs
  • Problems with the trachea may include narrowing, inflammation, and some inherited conditions.
  • In chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), the trachea gets narrower.
  •  The cartilage that makes up the trachea is weaker in some people with COPD.
  • The trachea is not involved in the spread of tuberculous infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complaints of chronic cough, dyspnea on exertion & purulent, foul-smelling sputum. He has a history of  smoking for 15 years. He is subsequently diagnosed with bronchiectasis. He states that he has had a history of recurrent chest infections. Which of the following is the most likely precursor to his current diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Necrotizing pneumonia

  • Bronchiectasis is a progressive respiratory disease characterized by permanent dilation of the bronchi and associated with cough, sputum production, and recurrent pulmonary infections.
  • Bronchiectasis may be the sequela of various necrotizing infections that are either inadequately treated or not treated.
  • Primary infection is a particularly common cause of bronchiectasis.
  • The most widely cited mechanism of infectious bronchiectasis is the “vicious cycle hypothesis,” in which susceptibility to infection and poor mucociliary clearance result in microbial colonization of the bronchial tree.
  • Some organisms, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, exhibit a particular propensity for colonizing damaged airways and evading host defense mechanisms.
  • Impaired mucociliary clearance can result from inherited conditions such as cystic fibrosis or dyskinetic cilia syndrome.
  • The presence of the microbes incites persistent chronic inflammation with consequent damage to the airway wall, continued impairment of secretions and microbial clearance, and ongoing propagation of the infectious/inflammatory cycle.
  • Other than infection, airway obstruction, and peribronchial fibrosis are important mechanisms that contribute to the pathogenesis of bronchiectasis.

Option A: Tuberculosis

  • Bronchiectasis as a sequel to pulmonary tuberculosis is not rare, but among the varied causes of bronchiectasis, necrotizing pneumonia is a common cause.

Option B: Carcinoma

  • Bronchiectasis has positively associated with malignancies, including lung cancer.
  • However, patients with bronchiectasis have a 2.36-fold increased risk of developing lung cancer.

Option C: Bronchial adenoma

  • Bronchial adenoma can result in bronchiectasis, but this type of neoplasm is rare.

questions.text: A woman comes to a psychiatrist with a history of spending a lot of time in washing her hands. She is distressed about it but says that she is not able to stop washing. This has started to affect her social life as well. What is the best mode of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
• OCD is characterized by the presence of obsessions and/or compulsions. Obsessions are recurrent and persistent thoughts. urges or images that are experienced as intrusive or unwanted. Compulsions are repetitive behaviour or mental acts that the patient feels driven to perform in response to an obsession.
  • Treatment
    • According to American Psychiatric Association guidelines, the first line of treatment for OCD are Cognitive behavioural therapy that relies on the behavioural technique of 'Exposure and response preventionand Selective Serotonin re-uptake inhibitors (SSRIs).
    • Also few studies have found, that Exposure and response prevention has more lasting effect than pharmacological agents.
    • Having said that, the choice of treatment between ERP and pharmacological agents depends on patients' characteristics, which have not been provided, hence it's tough to choose.
    • However in this case, Exposure and response prevention appears to be the best answer.

questions.text: The therapist asks the contamination phobia patient to follow behind him and touch everything he touches. Throughout the process, the therapist speaks to the patient quietly and politely. The technique must be repeated twice a day by the patient. Which of the following term best describes this technique?
questions.solution:
Option B: Modeling

This is an example of participant modeling in which the patient learns by observing and imitating the therapist.

  • Modeling is a method used in certain cognitive-behavioral psychotherapy techniques whereby the client learns by imitation alone, without any specific verbal direction by the therapist, and a general process in which persons serve as models for others, exhibiting the behavior to be imitated by others.
  • This process is most discussed concerning children in developmental psychology.

Option A: Flooding

  • Flooding is a type of behavioral therapy in which maximum stimuli are given in the first response

Option C: Positive reinforcement

  • Positive reinforcement increases the frequency of behavior because of positive consequences.

Option D: Aversion therapy

Aversion therapy-

  • It uses classical Conditioning
  • Helpful in the treatment of unwanted behaviors such as paraphilias

questions.text: Erectile dysfunction is present in a 30-year-old man who comes to OPD. The standard screening assessment is unremarkable. The following should be the next step in the evaluation/management process:
questions.solution:
• In a young patient with negative screening, the most likely cause of erectile dysfunction is psychogenic erectile dysfunction.
  • He should be given a trial of oral sildenafil.
  • Alternatively, other drugs can also be used like Oral Phentolamine ,Alprostadil (intraurethral/ injectable)
  • Psychotherapy can also be given specifically Dual Sex therapy ( Masters and johnson technique): In this couple is treated as a unit.

questions.text: Batman works a lot. He takes zero vacations and won't get married because his job comes first. He doesn't tolerate failure,he's a perfectionist and chooses to work alone because he believes he's smarter than everyone else. He/ she can be best described as:
questions.solution:
• Type A personality is characterized by competitiveness, time urgency, hostility and anger. The people with Type A personality are ambitious, impatient and hard working workaholics.
  • Do not confuse type A, B, C,D personality with Custer A, B and C personality disorders. Both of these are different classifications
  • Apart from Type A Personality there are also Type B and D Personalities
  • Type B Personality - Easy going and relaxed (lower chances of CAD)
  • Type D Personality- Negative affectivity and social inhibition.
  • Type A and D have higher risk of CAD.
  • How to remember : similar to A, B, C grades. A for competitors, B for Bindass (easy going), D for Death (negativity and socially inhibited)

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who underwent a mastectomy for breast cancer 2 years ago presents to the emergency department with headache, backache, and frequent vomiting. She is extremely thirsty and confused. Which of the following tests is most likely to identify the cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option D: Serum Calcium Concentration

  • Hypercalcemia is defined as a serum calcium level above the normal range of 8.5 to 10.5 mEq/L or an increase in the ionized calcium level above 4.2 to 4.8 mg/dL.
  • This patient is a known case of breast cancer operated on 2 years ago and now presents with symptoms of bone metastasis such as backache, headache, and frequent vomiting.
  • The metastasis to the bone causes increased osteoclastic activity in the bone, leading to hypercalcemia. Increased thirst sensation and confusion are symptoms of hypercalcemia. Hence the investigation needed to be done now is Serum Calcium Concentration.
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy or secretion of the parathyroid hormone-related protein account for most cases of symptomatic hypercalcemia.
  • Multiple myeloma, lymphoma, and solid tumors metastasis to bone (particularly breast, lung, and prostate cancer) cause hypercalcemia by excessive osteoclastic activity
  • Symptoms of hypercalcemia
    • Gastrointestinal -Anorexia, nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain
    • Neuromuscular - Weakness, confusion, coma, bone pain
    • Cardiovascular - Hypertension, arrhythmia, polyuria, worsening of digitalis toxicity. ECG changes include shortened QT interval, prolonged PR and QRS intervals, increased QRS voltage, T-wave flattening and widening, and atrioventricular block
    • Renal - Polydipsia
  • Definitive management of hypercalcemia depends on the correction of the primary problem. Patients with a malignant neoplasm and hypercalcemia may respond to surgical excision, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy.
  • Symptomatic patients with severe hypercalcemia related to the malignant disease can be quickly and effectively treated by saline infusion followed by the administration of a loop diuretic to induce saline diuresis with associated urinary calcium clearance.
  • Severe hypercalcemia, referred to as hypercalcemic crisis, occurs with serum calcium concentration above 14mg/dL and is related to the release of calcium from bone by tumor; it can be managed by administration of bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid, pamidronate disodium, and etidronate disodium). They have a potent capacity to reduce the osteoclast-mediated release of calcium from bone.

 

Option A: CT Brain plain

  • CT brain plain is ordered to look at the structures of the brain and evaluate for the presence of pathologies such as:
    • Mass/tumor
    • Fluid collection (abscess)
    • Ischemic injury (stroke)
    • Hemorrhage
    • Hydrocephalus
    • The trauma of fracture of the skull
  • However, this patient's backache and history of breast cancer are concerning for hypercalcemia. CT would be in line with the management of this patient, but it is not the next best step in the evaluation of this patient's symptoms.

Option B: X-ray of the spine

  • X-ray of the spine is performed to diagnose:
    • Back pain
    • Fractures of the spine
    • Arthritis
    • Spondylolisthesis
    • Degeneration of the disks
    • Tumors
    • Abnormalities in the curvature of the spine, like kyphosis or scoliosis
    • Congenital abnormalities

 

Option C: Serum sodium concentration

  • Low serum sodium levels also cause nausea, vomiting, headache, and confusion.
  • However, this patient's history of breast cancer and backache are more concerning for hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was admitted to the post-op unit following a total thyroidectomy for medullary carcinoma 3 days ago. During the morning round, a junior resident in the surgical department noticed the finding shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Parathyroid insufficiency

  • The image above shows a Carpopedal spasm that inflates the sphygmomanometer above systolic blood pressure for 3 minutes (Trousseau's sign). It is due to hypocalcemia caused by parathyroid insufficiency in a patient with total thyroidectomy.
  • Parathyroid glands are the two sets of glands located at the upper and lower poles of the thyroid gland. Total thyroidectomy leads to loss of parathyroid glands. This results in decreased effects of parathyroid hormone - Hypocalcemia
  • It most commonly occurs on the second to the fifth day of surgery.
  • The incidence of permanent hypoparathyroidism is less than 1%
  • The patient has the following manifestations:
    • Carpopedal spasm
    • Tingling/numbness over the perioral region
  • Carpopedal spasms are frequent and involuntary muscle contractions in the hands and feet with associated pain. It involves the adduction of the thumb, flexion of the metacarpophalangeal joint, extension of the interphalangeal joint, and flexion of the wrist. It occurs due to underlying hypocalcemia, which causes nerve and muscular hyperexcitability causing these involuntary muscle contractions.
  • Another sign of hypocalcemia is Chvostek’s sign which is the contraction of ipsilateral facial muscles elicited by tapping the facial nerve just anterior to the ear.

Option A: Hypothyroidism

  • Total thyroidectomy leads to hypothyroidism, and the patients are to take thyroxine for the rest of their lives. However, these patients do not show features of hypocalcemia; instead, hypothyroidism presents as follows:
    • Bradycardia
    • Cold intolerance
    • Constipation
    • Periorbital edema
    • Weight gain
    • Myopathy

Option C: Nerve damage during surgery

  • During total thyroidectomy, the nerve at risk of injury is the recurrent laryngeal nerve. As a result, the patient develops hoarseness of voice or total loss of speech. However, nerve damage does not cause carpopedal spasms; such findings are due to hypocalcemia from the underlying hypoparathyroidism.

Option D: Infection

  • Post-surgery infection occurs within 3 days of surgery, and the patients present with fever, tachycardia, and signs of infection/inflammation at the incision site. This patient is afebrile and has no worth mentioning signs at the surgery site

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female underwent parathyroidectomy for parathyroid hyperplasia. On the 2nd postoperative day, the patient developed a carpal spasm when her blood pressure was measured. She developed facial twitching when her face was tapped anteriorly to the ear. Her serum chemistry report:


	
		
			
			Sodium
			
			138 mEq/L
		
		
			
			Potassium
			
			4.5 mEq/L
		
		
			
			Chloride
			
			104 mEq/L
		
		
			
			Calcium 
			
			7 mg/dL
		
		
			
			Bicarbonate
			
			22 mEq/L
		
		
			
			Blood urea nitrogen
			
			20 mg/dL
		
		
			Creatinine
			1.1 mg/dL
		
	


 

Which of the following best explains this patient's lab abnormalities and physical exam findings?
questions.solution:
Option B: Increased Calcium uptake by bones

  • The patient underwent parathyroidectomy, after which he developed signs of hypocalcemia: Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign. This suggests the diagnosis of hungry bone syndrome.
  • Hypocalcemia is due to increased bone uptake in the immediate postoperative period following parathyroidectomy. Hypocalcemia after parathyroidectomy is generally transient when the bone disease is mild. However, postoperative hypocalcemia can be prolonged and severe in patients with end-stage renal disease. This is called the “hungry bone syndrome.”
  • This syndrome is especially common in patients with osteitis fibrosa. In addition to hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperkalemia can also manifest.
  • The underlying pathogenesis is the acute reversal of the PTH effects on bone. In hyperparathyroidism, PTH increases both bone formation and resorption. Sudden reductions of circulating PTH after parathyroidectomy cause an imbalance between osteoblast-mediated bone formation and osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, leading to a marked net increase in bone uptake of calcium, phosphate, and magnesium. Thus, the hungry bone syndrome requires an abrupt decrease in PTH release that upsets the equilibrium between calcium efflux from bone and influx into the skeleton during bone remodeling.
  • The graph shows the course of development of hypocalcemia in hungry bone syndrome.

Option A: Increased urinary loss of calcium

  • Although the urinary loss of calcium can cause hypocalcemia and the resulting Chvostek and Trousseau sign, this is not the case here. This patient has a hungry bone syndrome which is mediated by the abrupt reversal of the PTH, leading to increased calcium uptake by the bones.

 

Option C: Increased calcitonin levels

  • Although increased calcitonin levels can cause hypocalcemia and the resulting Chvostek and Trousseau sign, this is not the case here. This patient has a hungry bone syndrome which is mediated by the abrupt reversal of the PTH, leading to increased calcium uptake by the bones.

 

Option D: Increased calcium binding with phosphorus

  • Although Increased calcium binding with phosphorus can cause hypocalcemia and the resulting Chvostek and Trousseau sign, this is not the case here. This patient has a hungry bone syndrome which is mediated by the abrupt reversal of the PTH, leading to increased calcium uptake by the bones.

questions.text: A 42-year old female came to the OPD complaining of pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen since yesterday. On palpation, tenderness in the right hypochondrium was elicited. The patient was suspected of having gallstones. What is the investigation of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option A: Ultrasound

  • Ultrasound is considered the most useful initial radiological test of choice for diagnosing cholelithiasis and acute cholecystitis, with a sensitivity and specificity of 70% to 90%
  • Ultrasound is effective in documenting the presence or absence of stones, and it can show gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid, both of which are highly suggestive of acute cholecystitis.
  • Most of the gallstones are radiolucent and hence cannot be detected in X-rays

Other Options

Option B: X-ray

  • Because only 10% of stones are calcified, this imaging study has limited usefulness.
  • However, porcelain gallbladder can also be seen in plain X-rays.

Option C: Barium study

  • Barium study is used to highlight the gastrointestinal tract.
  • It is not useful to study gallbladder.

Option D: Oral cholecystography

  • Oral cholecystography is a procedure used to image the gallbladder.
  • Although rarely performed now, following oral administration, the contrast agent gets absorbed by the bowel and concentrated in the gall bladder.
  • Radiolucent gallstones may then be outlined as filling defects on fluoroscopic imaging.

questions.text: What is the name of this investigation shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option C: T-tube cholangiogram

  • The name of the investigation given is T-tube cholangiogram.
  • T-tube cholangiogram is a special X-ray investigation carried out using X-ray dye to visualize the bile ducts after cholecystectomy or after common bile duct exploration with supra-duodenal choledochotomy.
  • It provides external bile drainage into a controlled route while the healing process of cholecystectomy matures and the original pathology resolves.
  • Common bile duct T-tubes should remain in for 10 days. 
  • However, once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is a free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones, some surgeons like to clamp the T-tube prior to removal.
  • The 10-day period is required to minimize the risk of biliary peritonitis after removal. 

Option A: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

  • ERCP is used both as a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure. 
  • It helps in determining the cause and level of obstruction.
  • During ERCP, bile aspirates can be sent for cytological and microbiological examination, and endoluminal brushings can be taken from strictures for cytological examination
  • Therapeutic interventions such as stent placement or stone removal to relieve the obstruction can be performed.

Option B: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

  • MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique to visualize the intra and extrahepatic biliary tree and pancreatic ductal system.
  • It can provide diagnostically-equivalent images to ERCP and is a useful technique in high-risk patients to avoid significant morbidity.

Option D: Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram (PTC)

  • PTC demonstrate the intrahepatic biliary tree, identifies the location of the injury, provides drainage of bile, and possibly even allows the leak to close.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with diffuse abdominal pain. On laboratory investigation, amylase was normal, but CEA was raised. CT scan showed a hypodense lesion in the pancreas, which had internal septation and wall calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Mucinous cystadenoma

  • CECT showing peripheral egg-shell calcification suggesting the diagnosis of mucinous cystadenoma
  • Mucinous cystadenoma:
    • Mucinous cystadenoma is the most common pancreatic cystic neoplasm
    • Females are more prone to it (perimenopausal women). Men are rarely impacted.
    • Columnar epithelial lining
    • The body and tail of the pancreas are the most commonly used locations.
    • Premalignant
    • The mucin-producing epithelium is present, and mucin-rich cells and ovarian-like stroma distinguish them histologically.
    • In most cases, oestrogen and progesterone staining are positive.
    • Linked to an increase in CEA
    • Normal amylase levels
    • The cyst has strong walls and does not connect with the main pancreatic duct on imaging. The cyst wall may contain nodules or calcifications.
    •  CECT shows egg-shell calcification of the periphery ( solitary cyst with fine septations surrounded by a calcification rim).
    • Malignancy is indicated by peripheral egg-shell calcification, and greater tumour size.
    • FNA reveals mucin-rich aspirate and high CEA values (>192 ng/mL).
    • Amylase levels in cyst fluid are low.
    • Distal pancreatectomy is the treatment.

Option A: Serous cystadenoma

  • Pancreatic serous cystadenoma is a benign pancreatic tumour. It is commonly seen in the pancreas' tail and is linked to von Hippel-Lindau disease.
  • A CT scan often reveals a multicystic, lobulated tumour in the pancreatic head, commonly referred to as a "bunch of grapes."

Option C: Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm

  • Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) is a form of tumour that can develop within pancreatic duct cells. IPMN tumours produce mucus, and this mucus can develop pancreatic cysts. Although intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms are benign tumours, they can develop into pancreatic cancer.
  • They appear as single or many pancreatic cystic hypodense lesions on CT imaging. For the primary type IPMN, dilatation of the main duct greater than 5 mm is cause for worry. On CT, connection with the pancreatic ducts, particularly side branch lesions, may be difficult to see. They are not calcified.

Option D: Acinic cell tumour

  • Acinar cell carcinoma is a rare malignant exocrine pancreatic tumour. It accounts for 5% of all pancreatic exocrine tumours, making it the second most frequent kind of pancreatic cancer.
  • On contrast-enhanced CT, the tumour is often shown as an enhancing, ovoid, solid pancreatic tumour. Variable hypo/hyperattenuating mass relative to the pancreas, with distinct borders, can be seen along with dilation of non-biliary ducts.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe gastritis. Her endoscopy is performed on the doctor's recommendation. During the procedure, the patient suddenly develops severe pain and swelling in the neck, with crepitus suggestive of iatrogenic esophageal perforation. Which part of the esophagus is most susceptible to this type of injury?

choices.text: Above the arch of the aorta
Below the arch of the aorta

questions.solution:
Option B: Cervical portion

  • The cervical portion of the esophagus is most susceptible to iatrogenic esophageal perforation

Common sites of esophageal perforation

Anatomic landmark Description
Piriform sinus Trumpet players, manual labourers, and singers are prone to develop piriform sinus perforations.
Killian triangle Pharyngoesophageal diverticula occur here, and inadvertent cannulation of the diverticulum results in perforation.
Cricopharyngeous muscle Most common site of iatrogenic perforation.
Aortic arch/bronchus Esophagus is in direct contact with the aortic arch and bronchus, which both create a small indentation on the esophagram.
Gastroesophageal junction Most common site of perforation in Boerhaave’s syndrome.

Etiology:

Esophageal perforation
Iatrogenic Spontaneous
  • Most common type(60%)
  • Caused by endoscopy
  • The most common site is the cervical esophagus (cricopharyngeal area)
  • Esophageal rupture after vomiting
  • Most common site: the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus

 

 

Option A: Abdominal portion

  • It is the most common site of perforation in Boerhaave’s syndrome.

Option C: Above the arch of the aorta

  • Iatrogenic perforation rarely develops above the arch of the aorta.

Option D: Below the arch of the aorta

  • Iatrogenic perforation rarely develops below the arch of the aorta.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the emergency department with complaints of recurrent episodes of vomiting and failure to consume adequate food.. The child's barium meal reveals a string sign. Which of the following contains the string sign?
questions.solution:
Option D: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

  • Infants are normal at birth; symptoms appear between 3-6 weeks after birth.
  • First-born male child is commonly affected.
  • Infants with HPS typically present with projectile non-bilious vomiting.
  • Palpation of the pyloric tumour or olive in the epigastrium or right upper quadrant by a skilled examiner is pathognomonic of the diagnosis of HPS.
    • If the olive is palpated, no additional diagnostic testing is necessary.
  • Barium Meal:
    • A string Sign indicating a narrowed elongated pyloric canal that does not relax is seen.
    • The shoulder Sign is caused by the hypertrophied muscle indenting the antrum.
    • Double-track sign is Caused by the redundant mucosa

 

Option A: Duodenal atresia

  • String sign is not seen with duodenal atresia.
  • On abdominal X-ray, a double bubble appearance is seen

Option B: Intestinal obstruction

  • String sign is not seen with Intestinal obstruction.

Option C: Jejunal atresia

  • On abdominal X-ray, a triple bubble appearance is seen in jejunal atresia

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of vaginal bleeding. After an extensive workup, a diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma is made. A hysterectomy is advised. She has a hysterectomy after a month. Postoperatively, the patient developed an ileus. Which of the following parts of the gastrointestinal tract is first to recover from postoperative ileus?
questions.solution:
Option A: Small intestine

POSTOPERATIVE ILEUS

  • Following most abdominal operations or injuries, the motility of the GI tract is transiently impaired.
  • Proposed mechanisms responsible for this dysmotility are surgical stress-induced sympathetic reflexes, inflammatory response mediator release, and anesthetic/analgesic effects; each of which can inhibit intestinal motility
  • The return of normal motility generally follows a characteristic temporal sequence:
    • Return of normal motility: Small intestine (within 24 hours) > Gastric (48 hours)>Colonic(3-5 days)
    • Postoperative ileus is most pronounced in the colon.
  • Because small bowel motility is returned before colonic and gastric motility, listening for bowel sounds is not a reliable indicator that ileus has fully resolved
  • Functional evidence of coordinated gastrointestinal motility in the form of passing flatus or bowel movement is a more useful indicator

Option B: Stomach

  • The return of gastric activity takes more than 48 hours.
  • The small intestine is first to restore the activity.

Option C: Colon

  • Colon activity returns after a couple of days.
  • It usually takes 3-5 days to restore normal colonic activity.
     

Option D: Esophagus

  • Esophagus is rarely involved in the ileus.
  • The main part of the intestine involved is the esophagus.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presented to the clinic with hematochezia and abdominal pain for three months. He reports a change in bowel habits, weight loss, and fatigue. The patient has a history of familial adenomatous polyposis. On a complete blood count, hemoglobin is 11.5g/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
Option A: Colonoscopy with biopsy

  • According to the clinical features, this is a case of colorectal cancer. 
  • Diagnostic tests for colorectal cancer:
    • Colonoscopy with biopsy: It is the gold standard for the diagnosis of colorectal cancer
    • On barium enema x-ray, an Apple core lesion is seen.

Option B: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen

  • The gold standard test for colorectal cancer diagnosis is colonoscopy with biopsy.
  • CT scan of the abdomen is used in case of intestinal obstruction, kidney stones, or Crohn's disease.
  • CT scan of the abdomen is also performed in case of injuries following trauma, mass in the abdomen.

Option C: X-ray of the abdomen

  • An abdominal x-ray is performed in case of an abdominal aorta aneurysm or pancreatitis.
  • It is also performed in case of gut perforation, ureter injury, and intussusception.
  • It is not used for the diagnosis of colorectal cancer.

Option D: Serum tumour marker

  • The serum level of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) increases in colorectal cancer.
  • It is used for monitoring colorectal cancer recurrence.
  • It should not be used for diagnosis due to poor sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the gastroenterologist with complaints of diarrhoea for more than one month and colicky abdominal pain for five days. On examination, the patient is a thin and lean man with a blood pressure of 115/70 mmHg and a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. The doctor has advised a few blood tests and a colonoscopy, which indicate the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. Which of the following findings is consistent with the above diagnosis?

choices.text: The disease is confluent, there are no skipareas in the colon, and the rectum is involved
The full thickness of the bowel wall is involved
Microscopic examination of the mucosa reveals granulomas

questions.solution:
Option B: The disease is confluent, there are no skip areas in the colon, and the rectum is involved

  • Based on the clinical symptoms of chronic diarrhoea and abdominal pain and the colonoscopic findings, the likely diagnosis, as given in the scenario, is ulcerative colitis.
  • Ulcerative colitis disease is confluent without any skip areas and almost always involves the rectum.
  • The inflammation observed in ulcerative colitis begins at the anal verge and spreads proximally, as ulcerative colitis always affects the rectum.
  • Ulcerative colitis is a chronic disease that causes large intestine and rectum inflammation.
  • Ulcerative colitis affects the lining of the large intestine, the colon, and the rectum.
Ulcerative Colitis (UC)  
Wall involvement Mucosal and submucosal ulcers
Location Begins in the rectum and can extend proximally up to the cecum, the remainder of the GI tract is unaffected
Symptoms Left lower quadrant pain (rectum) with bloody diarrhea
Inflammation Crypt abscesses with neutrophils
Gross appearance Pseudopolyps; loss of haustra 
Complications Toxic megacolon and carcinoma (risk is based on the extent of colonic involvement and duration of disease, generally no a concern until >10 years of disease)

Option A: Rectum is not involved

  • Ulcerative colitis disease is confluent without any skip areas and almost always involves the rectum.
  • In ulcerative colitis, inflammation generally starts in the rectum and spreads to the colon.
  • Rectal lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis.

Option C: The full thickness of the bowel wall is involved

  • In ulcerative colitis, only mucosa and submucosa membranes are involved instead of the full-thickness bowel wall.
  • In Crohn's disease, all the layers of the bowel walls are affected, while ulcerative colitis only affects the colon's innermost lining.

Option D: Microscopic examination of the mucosa reveals granulomas

  • Granulomas are not seen in ulcerative colitis. They are seen in Crohn's disease.

questions.text: What would be the management of a middle-aged female with three finger test revealing positive cough impulse in the femoral region?
questions.solution:
Option D: McVay repair

  • Given the clinical scenario and examination findings, the patient most likely suffers from an inguinal hernia and femoral ring defects.
  • In such cases, McVay repair is indicated.
  • McVay repair addresses both inguinal and femoral ring defects.
  • The McVay repair uses autologous tissue to close the inguinal canal floor.
  • McVay repair is shown in the picture below:

  • It is indicated for femoral hernia and where prosthetic material is contraindicated.
  • After reaching the preperitoneal space, the superior transversalis flap is fastened to the cooper's ligament to occlude the femoral ring.

Option A: Bassini repair

  • This procedure is done for inguinal hernia only. It is a triple-layer repair.
  • Internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and transversalis fascia are fixed to the inguinal ligament and pubic periosteum with interrupted suture.

Option B: Hunters repair

  • Hunter's repair does flexor tender reconstruction.
  • It is not indicated in treating inguinal and femoral ring defects.

Option C: Shouldice repair

  • This is indicated for inguinal hernia repair.
  • It is a four-layer repair for an inguinal hernia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor of the spleen?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lymphoma

  • The patient has left hypochondriac pain with anemia and weight loss. Investigations also show a solid splenic mass with low haemoglobin and abnormally high white cell count. The most common malignant neoplasm of the spleen is lymphoma (non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma).
  • Tumours of the spleen may be lymphoid or nonlymphoid.
  • Lymphoid tumours of the spleen are mainly Hodgkin disease or non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Non-lymphoid tumours may be either primary or secondary (metastatic).
  • The most common nonlymphoid primary tumours are vascular tumours.

Option B: Sarcoma

  • The most common primary nonlymphoid malignant spleen tumour is angiosarcoma (Hemangiosarcoma).

Option C: Hemangioma

  • The most common benign tumour of the spleen is hemangioma.

Option D: Metastasis

  • Secondary or metastatic tumours are most commonly from melanoma, lung and breast cancers
  • Isolated splenic metastases are extremely unusual but may occur in the setting of a concomitant carcinoma
  • Lung cancer is the tumour that most commonly spreads to the spleen, although colorectal, ovarian and melanoma may also metastasize to spleen

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida with 5 weeks of amenorrhea presented with right iliac fossa tenderness, guarding, and rebound tenderness. Urine analysis showed leukocytosis. An abdominal ultrasound was performed but the appendix was not visualized. What would be the diagnostic tool to proceed further in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Abdominal Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan

  • The patient is most likely suffering from acute appendicitis based on the features of right-side abdominal pain associated with vomiting. The investigation of choice is ultrasonography, but the appendix could not be visualized in this case. So, Magnetic resonance imaging is indicated.
  • Appendicitis occurs in 1 in 800 to 1 in 1000 pregnancies, mostly in the first and second trimesters.
  • Pregnancy may alter the presentation of the disease and laboratory values like WBC count (leukocytosis as high as 16000 cells/μL is common in pregnancy), making diagnosis difficult.
  • Its symptoms typically consist of right lateral abdominal pain, nausea, and anorexia, yet typical presentation accounts for only 50% to 60% of cases.
  • Ultrasonography is the preferred imaging modality, although non-visualization can occur. Sensitivity can vary from 67% to 100%, and specificity from 93% to 96%.
  • MRI is an alternating imaging modality in case of non-visualization of the appendix in ultrasound, with a sensitivity of 94% and specificity of 97%.

Option A: Diagnostic laparoscopy

  • The risk of fetal loss is up to 36% if appendicular perforation occurs. Therefore, a lower threshold remains to operate on such patients with an acceptable negative exploration rate of as high as 30%.
  • In the case of non-operative management, treatment failure rates have been reported to be as high as 25%.

Option B: Abdominal CT scan

  • Plain abdominal films and CT scans can be done, but there is a fear of radiation exposure to the developing fetus.

Option D: Serial clinical observations

  • The risk of fetal loss is up to 36% if appendicular perforation occurs.
  • Serial clinical observations are not indicated in a pregnant lady.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman has been experiencing lower abdominal pain and frequent urination for seven months. She has no other symptoms, and tests have been inconclusive. Cystoscopy revealed a finding, what is true about the management of this condition?

choices.text: Conservative management; Has a good prognosis
Application of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder

questions.solution:
Option B: Application of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder

  • The patient disguised is suffering from interstitial cystitis, and the treatment is the instillation of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the distended bladder under anaesthesia. Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition causing bladder pressure, bladder pain and pelvic pain.
  • The pain can be very uncomfortable or very mild.
  • The ailment is a member of the painful bladder syndrome group of illnesses.
  • Interstitial cystitis is also called Hunner’s ulcer.
  • Chronic Pancystitis characterize it.
  • There is Infiltration of lymphocytes and macrophages.
  • It is more common in females.
  • Its aetiology is unknown.
  • There is the presence of a linear bleeding ulcer in the fundus (involving mucosa).
  • Clinical features:
    • Initial symptom - Increased frequency
    • The pain increased by distention of the bladder & relieved by micturition.
    • Bladder capacity is reduced to 30 – 50ml.
    • Diagnosis
      • On Cystoscopy – the presence of a linear bleeding ulcer in the fundus.
  • To rule out malignancy:
    • Urinary cytology
    • Biopsy
  • Treatment
    • Difficult and unsatisfactory.
    • Bladder distention under anaesthesia.
    • Installation of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder.

Option A: Conservative management; has a good prognosis

  • Interstitial cystitis is not managed conservatively. Its treatment is difficult and unsatisfactory, involving the distention of the bladder and the instillation of dimethyl sulfoxide.

Option C: Surgery followed by chemotherapy

  • The treatment of hunger ulcers is the instillation of dimethyl sulfoxide into the bladder. The bladder is distended under anaesthesia.
  • No surgery followed by chemotherapy is needed.

Option D: Bladder resection under anaesthesia

  • The bladder is distinct under anaesthesia but not rejected; dimethyl sulfoxide is instilled into the blood, but the treatment is difficult and unsatisfactory.
