questions.text: A 68-year-old male with benign prostate hyperplasia presents with blood in urine and severe pain. Recent tests showed multiple bladder stones. He's been taking alpha-blockers for 6 years and is prepared for surgery. During surgery, he developed vomiting and altered sensorium. What's the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dilutional hyponatremia

  • Trans urethral resection of the prostate (TURP) is the surgical procedure for benign prostate hyperplasia. The indications of surgery in this patient are :
    • Failure of medical treatment
    • Bladder stones are a complication of BPH    
  • Cysto-urethroscopy is done. It is the procedure in which a 26Fr resectoscope with a 30-degree telescope is introduced per-urethra into the bladder. The prostate is visualized and assessed for size. The bladder is seen for stones. Tissues are cut from the bladder neck by a diathermy loop mounted in front of the scoop. First median lobe and then lateral lobes are resected. Chips of a prostate pass to the bladder, and these pieces and stones are evacuated by the Ellik evacuator.
  • For continuous irrigation, a three-way Foley catheter is passed. The irrigation is done with normal saline to avoid clot retention.
  • This continuous irrigation with fluid (glycine) may be absorbed into the circulation, leading to dilutional hyponatremia. This condition is called TURP syndrome. It is the most common complication of TURP surgery.
  • The treatment is:       
    • Fluid restriction
    • Diuretics
    • Hypertonic saline 3% infusion
  • The risk of TURP syndrome increases with resection time > 90 minutes or gland size > 75 gm.

Option B: Dilutional hyperkalemia

  • By irrigation of saline, hyponatremia occurs, which causes altered sensorium.

Option C: Rupture of bladder

  • It can be a complication of surgery, but it is not associated with vomiting and altered sensorium.

Option D: Hemorrhage

  • Hemorrhage can be a complication during this surgery, but to a less extent, that can be tolerated by this patient.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man came to the OPD complaining of severe pain in his both legs for the past 20 days. On history-taking, the patient complained of cramp-like pain felt in the muscles after walking along with redness and swelling, but for the past one day, he's had severe pain in his foot even while he's resting, which is exacerbated even by lying down and by touching his bed sheet. With a positive sunset foot sign, there are no pedal pulses. Which of the following patient complaints will necessitate emergency intervention to prevent limb amputation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Resting pain

  • Bilateral pain, severe pain in the legs associated with cramp-like pain felt in the muscles after walking (intermittent claudication), redness and swelling with absent pedal pulses and positive sunset foot sign indicate peripheral arterial stenosis and occlusion in the limb. The dangerous sign in this patient is resting pain, and it is an indication of emergency intervention to prevent limb amputation.
  • Resting pain means that the blood supply to the organ is so compromised that the muscles cannot even fulfill their metabolic demands at rest and have to switch to anaerobic respiration.
  • This means that the blood supply is getting critical, and if necessary measures are not taken, it will eventually lead to limb amputation.

Option A: Intermittent claudication

  • Intermittent claudication means cramp-like pain in the foot while doing any movement like walking or running.
  • This indicates that the blood supply is sufficient during the resting period, but when the metabolic demands are increased due to some activity, the blood supply is insufficient.

Option C: Swelling

  • It is an indication that there is some obstruction and inflammation, which has led to the leaking of fluid from the vessels to the extracellular compartment.
  • It is a sign of disease, but it is not a danger sign.

 

Option D: Redness

  • Redness indicates that there is an inflammatory process going on in the organ.
  • The presence of inflammatory mediators has led to vasodilation and increased blood supply, thus, redness and warmth.
  • It is not a dangerous sign of arterial stenosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a burn injury 2 hours ago. Examination reveals second-degree burns covering 20% of the total body surface area. The patient is immediately resuscitated with fluids. Which of the following fluids is most commonly used in the patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ringer lactate

  • Ringer Lactate is the most commonly used fluid in burn patients.
  • Some centres use human albumin, fresh frozen plasma (FFP), or hypertonic saline
  • Intravenous resuscitation is appropriate for any child with a burn greater than 10% of total body surface area (TBSA) and 15% TBSA for adults
  • Rule of 9 is used to calculate the body surface area with a burn.
  • The most widely used and simplest formula to calculate fluid requirement is the Parkland formula

Volume = total percentage body surface area x weight (kg) x 4

Half this volume is given in the first 8 hours, and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 hours

Option A: Dextrose 5%

  • Dextrose 5 % is a hypotonic fluid.
  • It is used to cover the free water deficit. It is not the best choice for burn patients.

Option B: Normal saline

  • Normal saline is not used in burn patients as it contains chloride in an increased amount, and it can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
  • Normal saline also increases the risk for hypercoagulability.

Option D: Albumin 5%

  • Albumin 5% is a colloid. It is used in patients with hepatorenal syndrome and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • Although it can be used in burn patients, it is not the fluid of choice

questions.text: A 73-year-old male patient presents to the physician because of a lesion on his eyelid for six months. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. He initially dismissed it as a "skin tag," but the lesion has increased in size over the past three months. He retired three years ago from his job as a construction contractor. Examination shows a 1-cm (0.4-in) flesh-colored, nodular, non-tender lesion with rolled borders. There is no lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option D: Mohs micrographic surgery 

  • This patient with a nodular, nontender lesion with rolled borders on the eyelid and occupational sun exposure is most likely suffering from basal cell carcinoma (BCC).
  • It is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • Typically, basal cell carcinoma develops in sun-exposed areas as a pearly, indurated, nodular, nontender lesion with a rolled border and central ulceration, as illustrated in the image below:

  • The subtypes of basal cell carcinoma include nodular basal cell carcinoma and superficial basal cell carcinoma.
  • Nodular basal cell carcinoma mostly involves the face, especially the nose, as shown in the image below:

  • The flat eczematous plaque characterises superficial basal cell carcinoma with a pearly border lesion.
  • The superficial basal cell carcinoma variant mostly involves the trunk. This variant is illustrated in the image below:

  • The patient with basal cell carcinoma (BCC) should undergo a full-thickness biopsy of the edge of the lesion for histopathological confirmation of BCC.
  • The standard treatment options include surgical excision with a safety margin and  Mohs micrographic surgery.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is a procedure in which the tumour is removed layer by layer, and each layer is examined for tumour cells, is the standard treatment for BCCs that are not located on the trunk or extremities.
  • It is especially advantageous for functionally or cosmetically sensitive tumour locations such as the eyelid because it ensures complete tumour removal while sparing unaffected skin.

Option A:  Wide local excision  

  • The wide local excision is a surgical procedure in which the tumour and a small margin of normal tissue are removed after establishing the diagnosis.
  • This technique is mainly used for the treatment of early-stage melanoma.
  • Although this procedure may also be used to treat BCCs located on the trunk or extremities, the location of this patient's BCC requires a different technique that minimises the removal of normal tissue.

Option B: Cryotherapy 

  • Cryotherapy can be used for the treatment of superficial BCC.
  • However, it is not widely accepted as a first-line therapy because the recurrence rates after cryotherapy are often higher than in other therapies.
  • Further, cryotherapy does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, so assessing the extent of tumour removal is impossible.

Option C: Localised radiotherapy

  • Radiotherapy is an alternative treatment for BCC, usually indicated in the case of large tumours or tumours located in hard-to-reach locations.
  • It can also be used if the prior treatment has failed.
  • However, it is not the first-line treatment option.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the neurology department with complaints of severe headache associated with blurred vision and vomiting for the last 1 hour. He is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg, a pulse rate of 47 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute. His GCS is 12/15, and he has classical features of Cushing's Triad. His MRI brain reveals a posterior fossa lesion leading to raised intracranial pressure. What would be the management of the raised ICP in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Decompressive craniectomy

  • Based on the case discussed above, the patient has classical symptoms (nausea, vomiting, and severe headache) of raised intracranial pressure (ICP), and management would be decompressive craniectomy.
  • Stepwise approach to the treatment of elevated Intracranial pressure:
    • Insert ICP monitor - Ventriculostomy or Parenchymal device.
    • General goals: Maintain ICP < 20 mmHg and CPP 60 mmHg.
    • For ICP > 20-25 mmHg for > 5 min:
      • Elevated head of the bed, midline head position
      • Osmotherapy - mannitol
      • Sedation (e.g., Morphine, Propofol, or Midazolam); add neuromuscular paralysis, if necessary (patient will require endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation at this (point, if not before).
      • Hyperventilation to PaCO2 30-35 mmHg
      • Pressor therapy - Phenylephrine, Dopamine, or Norepinephrine to maintain adequate MAP to ensure CPP 60 mmHg.
  • Consider second-tier therapies for refractory elevated ICP:
    • High-dose barbiturate therapy ("Pentobarb coma”)
    • Aggressive hyperventilation to PaCO2 < 30 mmHg
    • Hypothermia
    • Hemicraniectomy (decompressive craniectomy)

Option A: Hyperthermia

  • Management of raised ICP includes hypothermia, not hyperthermia.
  • Hypothermia reduces cerebral metabolism and cerebral blood flow, decreasing intracranial pressure.

Option B: Hypercapnia

  • ICP is lowered by inducing hypocapnia, not by hypercapnia.
  • Inducing hypocapnia via hyperventilation reduces the partial pressure of arterial carbon dioxide (PaCO2), inciting vasoconstriction in the cerebral resistance arterioles.
  • This constriction decrease cerebral blood flow, reduces cerebral blood volume, and decreases ICP.

Option D: Opioids

  • High-dose barbiturate therapy ("Pentobarb coma") is given in cases with increased intracranial pressure.
  • Barbiturates reduce ICP by suppressing cerebral metabolism, leading to reduced cerebral blood volume.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker male presented complaints of left-sided facial swelling for the past 4 years. On examination, a marble-sized firm and non-tender mass is noticed beneath his left ear. A diagnosis is made by biopsy, and the mass is eventually excised. Which of the following is this patient's most likely benign parotid gland disease?

choices.text: Glandular hypertrophy, secondary to vitamin A deficiency

questions.solution:
Option D: Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum

  • This 60-year-old male, who has a 40-pack-year history of smoking, presented with a marble-sized mass beneath his left ear. This diagnosis is consistent with papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, also known as Warthin's tumour.
  • Warthin's tumour, called Adenolymphoma or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is the second most common benign salivary gland tumour (after pleomorphic adenoma). It represents 10-15% of the total salivary gland neoplasms.
  • They are commonly seen between the fifth and seventh decades of life.
  • It has an apparent male predilection for their occurrence. 
  • Histologically, it is composed of an oncotic epithelium and a lymphoid stroma.
  • It consists of an encapsulated mass containing numerous irregular cystic spaces lined by bilayered oncotic epithelium growing in the cystic spaces as papillary projections.
  • The underlying stroma separating the oncotic epithelium is typically a large lymphoid matrix with germinal centres.
  • Warthin's tumour and oncocytoma are the two tumours that show a 'hot spot' on the Tc-99m pertechnetate scan. It is because of the high mitochondrial content within the oncocytes.
  • Treatment is superficial parotidectomy, although they can be enucleated without danger of recurrence.

Option A: Glandular hypertrophy, secondary to vitamin A deficiency

  • Parotid gland hypertrophy can occur during malnutrition due to vitamin A deficiency. It is a reversible condition that returns to normal after adequate nutrient intake. There is no history of malnutrition in this patient.

Option B: Cystic dilation

  • Sialectasis is the cystic dilatation of the parotid duct. It is associated with ascending infections and gland destruction.

Option C: Mikulicz’s disease

  • It is an autoimmune disorder of bilateral salivary and lacrimal glands, resulting in infiltration of the glands with round cells.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with gradually progressing swelling and pain over the upper tibia for six months. He has no previous medical history except high-grade fever, swelling, tenderness, warmth, and erythema, which started seven months back and was partially treated. These symptoms subsided except for gradually progressive pain and swelling. On physical examination, he has a right-sided antalgic gait. A radiographic image of the tibia is given. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical symptoms of high-grade fever, swelling, tenderness, warmth, and erythema suggest subacute Osteomyelitis.

Option B: Subacute Osteomyelitis

  • Also known as Brodie's abscess
  • Seen in immunocompetent Host
  • Long-standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long-standing because of the intense defense mechanism of the body).
  • It involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis), e.g., the Upper-end tibia.
  • Classical Brodie's abscess looks like a small walled-off (Sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.
  • The usually isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative).

Option A: Subungual infection

  • Bacterial infections in the Distal fingernail or toenail ( due to crushing injury in the nail).
  • Subungual infections are due to dermatophytes, which occur in unhygienic conditions and can lead to skin scarring around nails.

Option C: Webspace infection
 

  • Infection in the mid-palmar or hypothenar space.
  • If untreated, it may result in cellulitis.

Option D: Infected hematoma

  • If the hematoma is left untreated, it leads to infection.
  • The given image doesn't show a hematoma.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with the complaint of leg swelling for the past few weeks. He denies any trauma. He also states that the swelling is painful and is slowly enlarging. On examination, swelling at the upper end of the tibia is noted. The margins of the swelling are irregular, and it is warm to the touch. The imaging shows the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Osteogenic sarcoma

This boy with irregular leg swelling, which is warm to the touch along with the characteristic radiologic findings, most likely has osteogenic sarcoma.

The clinical presentation in question can occur both in Ewing’s sarcoma and osteosarcoma.

However, swelling is around the knee joint at the upper end of the tibia, which favors the diagnosis of osteosarcoma (metaphyseal lesion).

  • Definition: malignant, osteoid, and bone-forming tumor arising from mesenchymal stem cells (osteoblasts) located in the periosteum
  • Etiology:
  • Primary osteosarcoma: unknown
  • Secondary osteosarcoma: Paget disease of bone, radiation injury, bone infarction Increased incidence in individuals with retinoblastoma and Li-Fraumeni syndrome
  • Incidence: bimodal distribution:
  • Primary osteosarcoma: in puberty/adolescence (peak incidence age 10-30 years)
  • Secondary osteosarcoma: advanced age.
  • Clinical features:
  • Frequently first manifests with pain (progressive, worsens at night and with activity)
  • Progressive swelling (tissue mass that is tender to palpation and accompanied by erythema)
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Limping, decreased range of motion
  • Possible B symptoms.
  • Radiology:
  • Sunburst appearance of lytic bone lesions and/or Codman triangles
  • Signs of osteolysis adjacent to osteosclerosis (moth-eaten appearance)
  • Treatment:
  • Neo-adjuvant Chemotherapy followed by Surgery with a 3 cm margin followed by Adjuvant Chemotherapy

Option A: Giant cell tumor

  • Giant cell tumor site- Epiphysis (lower end femur).
  • X-ray: multicystic osteolytic lesions (soap-bubble appearance)
  • Usually occurs between 20-40 years of age

Option B: Ewing's sarcoma

  • Ewing’s sarcoma usually occurs in the diaphysis of the bone (middle of the shaft).
  • Origin: Marrow cells (marrow biopsy useful to see the extent of the disease)
  • Localizes in the diaphysis
  • Age: second decade> First decade
  • Pain: universal complaint
  • Present like osteomyelitis

Option D: Secondary metastasis

  • Secondary metastasis occurs in old age usually.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He sustained an injury to the wrist and complained of wrist pain. On examination, he is vitally stable. Hands deformities are noted as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ulnar claw hand

  • Also known as Partial claw hand

The following are important points of ulnar nerve injury at the wrist:

Option B: Median claw hand

  • Also known as Partial claw hand
  • Involving only Lateral two lumbricals as in isolated median nerve palsy

Option C: Total claw hand

  • Medial two lumbricals: Ulnar nerve
  • Lateral two lumbricals: Median nerve
  • The action of lumbricals: Extension of the interphalangeal joint and flexion of the metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • Also seen in klumpky’s paralysis.

Option D: Pointing index

  • If the functioning of flexor pollicis longus, flexor digitorum profundus, and flexor digitorum superficialis is lost, the index finger can't flex upon making a fist. This results in the Pointing Index.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with a neck injury 30 minutes ago. He was enjoying himself in a swimming pool and got injured after diving into shallow water. A cervical collar is applied on site. Examination reveals painful restriction of neck movement. There are no focal neurological deficits. A cervical spine x-ray shows a stable burst fracture of the C1 vertebra. What is the mechanism of injury in this case?

choices.text: Fall of weight on the neck
Abrupt flexion movement of the neck

questions.solution:
Option C: Vertical compression force

  • Jefferson fracture is a burst fracture of the ring of the atlas (C1) vertebrae.
  • It occurs due to vertical compression force.
  • It is a combined fracture of anterior and posterior arches.
  • It can present with:
    • Pain
    • Restriction in neck movement
    • Hematoma
    • Neurological deficits
  • Two types depending on stability:
  • Stable fractures: Anterior column fracture without any compromise in the stability of the spine
  • Unstable fractures: Posterior column fracture,
  • Spinal cord injury is common, and neurological deficits are usually present.

Management of burst fractures:

  • Management is conservative or surgical, depending upon the stability of the fracture.

Option A: Whiplash injury

  • Whiplash is a neck injury due to forceful, rapid back-and-forth movement of the neck, like the cracking of a whip.
  • Most cervical spine fractures occur predominantly at two levels - at the level of C2 or at C6 or C7.

Option B: Fall of weight on the neck

  • Fall of weight on the neck in the C1 vertebra leads to complete paralysis of legs and arms.
  • Whereas, this patient is having no neurological defect.
  • Hence, a fall in weight is unlikely.

Option D: Abrupt flexion movement of the neck

  • Abrupt flexion of the neck causes whiplash injury.
  • Common in automobile injuries.
  • Most cervical spine fractures occur predominantly at two levels - at the level of C2 or at C6 or C7.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought in an unconscious state to the Emergency Department with a sustained head injury following a road traffic accident. He is admitted in casualty. His Glasgow coma scale was 6/15, with a blood pressure of 90/60mmHg, a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute and SpO2 of 81% at room air. He is posted to secure a definitive airway device. Which of the following airway device could be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Endotracheal tube

  • In the case mentioned above, the patient needs a definite airway device to secure his airway. Tracheal intubation is best suitable in such cases.
  • Tracheal tube intubation is a process wherein a tube is inserted through a mouth or nose (avoided in case of head injuries until basal skull fractures are ruled out) and then down into the trachea (airway/windpipe).
  • The tube keeps the trachea open so that air can get through.
  • The tube can connect to a machine that delivers air or oxygen.
  • Tracheal intubation is a definitive airway that provides maximal protection against aspiration of gastric contents.
  • It allows positive pressure ventilation with high airway pressures than via a face mask or supraglottic airway.

Option A: Laser tube

  • Laser Resistant endotracheal tubes (ETTs) are used to prevent airway fires during laser surgery.
  • In the case discussed above, it cannot be used as a definite airway-securing method.
  • Fires are located on the surface of ETT and cause thermal injury to tissues. If the fire burns through to the interior of ETT, O2 and positive pressure ventilation create a blow torch effect, blowing heat and toxic products down into the lung.

Option B: Proseal LMA

  • Proseal laryngeal mask airway PLMA is better than classical laryngeal mask airway (LMA) as it prevents aspiration.
  • It is a quick method to secure the airway but cannot be used as a definitive airway device.

Option C: Classical LMA

  • It is a temporary airway device since it cannot prevent aspiration.
  • Supraglottic airway devices have comparatively lesser seal pressures than tracheal tubes, which lead to ineffective ventilation when higher airway pressures are required.

questions.text: During anesthesia for upper limb surgery, a nerve integrity monitor is utilized to assess and prevent nerve injury. Which nerve in the arm is commonly monitored for its integrity in such procedures?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ulnar nerve

  • In principle, any superficially located peripheral motor nerve may be stimulated.
  • In clinical anaesthesia, the ulnar nerve is the most popular site; the median, posterior tibial, common peroneal, and facial nerves are also sometimes used.
  • For stimulation of the ulnar nerve, the electrodes are best applied to the volar side of the wrist.
    • The distal electrode should be placed about 1 cm adjacent to the point at which the wrist's proximal flexion fold crosses the tendon's radial side to the flexor carpi ulnaris muscle.
    • The proximal electrode should preferably be placed so that the distance between the centres of the two electrodes is 3 to 6 cm.
    • With this placement of the electrodes, electrical stimulation normally elicits only finger flexion and thumb adduction.
    • If one electrode is placed over the ulnar groove at the elbow, thumb adduction is often pronounced because of the flexor carpi ulnaris muscle stimulation.
  • An electric current is applied to stimulate a nerve. The current is usually applied transcutaneously using ECG electrodes.
  • The degree of neuromuscular blockage is monitored by applying various electrical stimulation patterns. All stimuli are 200 µs in duration, have a square wave pattern, and have equal current intensity.
  • The diaphragm, rectus abdominis, laryngeal adductors, and orbicularis oculi muscles recover from neuromuscular blockage sooner than the adductor pollicis.   

Option B: Radial nerve

  • The ulnar nerve is the preferred nerve for peripheral nerve stimulation. Other nerves are the facial, posterior tibial, and common peroneal nerves.

Option C: Median nerve

  • The median nerve can be used for peripheral stimulation of the adductor pollicis and ulnar nerve. However, the ulnar nerve is the preferred nerve. 

Option D: Palmar cutaneous branch

  • The Palmar cutaneous branch is a branch of the median nerve. However, it is less frequently used for neuromuscular monitoring via peripheral nerve stimulation than the median nerve.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents to the orthopaedic ward with a humerus fracture 3 hours back due to a road traffic accident. He has no known comorbid conditions for open reduction and internal fixation of proximal humerus fracture. What is the ideal time for the preoperative antibiotic to prevent surgical site infections in this patient?
questions.solution: Option A: Within 1 hour before the incision

questions.text: A 50-year-old female who is a case of carcinoma cervix was posted for brachytherapy planned under total intravenous anaesthesia with spontaneous ventilation assessed through a Magill circuit. Which of the following is the fresh gas flow used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Equal-to-minute ventilation

  • Minute ventilation is the total sum of volume delivered over a minute, with spontaneous as well as mechanical inflations. Typical minute ventilation for term infants is 240 to 360 mL/kg/min.
  • Alveolar ventilation is calculated by subtracting dead-space ventilation from total minute ventilation. Alveolar/saccular ventilation in the absence of intrapulmonary shunts determines Paco2.
  • Neonates with respiratory distress syndrome (R.D.S.) typically breathe over 100 times a minute, with smaller tidal volumes and unchanged dead space volume resulting in decreased alveolar minute ventilation.
  • Their increased respiratory rate in a non-compliant lung is due to the lower work of breathing required with small rapid breaths rather than with larger breaths.

Option B: Equal to Tidal Volume

  • Tidal volume is the amount of air that moves in or out of the lungs with each respiratory cycle. It measures around 500 mL in an average healthy adult male and approximately 400 mL in a healthy female.
  • It is a vital clinical parameter that allows for proper ventilation to take place. When a person breathes in, oxygen from the surrounding atmosphere enters the lungs. It then diffuses across the alveolar-capillary interface to reach arterial blood.
  • At the same time, carbon dioxide continuously forms as long as metabolism takes place. Expiration occurs to expel carbon dioxide and prevent it from accumulating in the body. The volume of inspired and expired air that helps keep oxygen and carbon dioxide levels stable in the blood is what physiology refers to as tidal volume.

Option C: Equal to Residual Volume

  • Residual volume is the amount of air that remains in a person's lungs after fully exhaling. Doctors use tests to measure a person's residual air volume to help check how well the lungs are functioning. 
  • Residual volume is measured by:
    • A gas dilution test: A person breathes from a container containing a documented amount of a gas (either 100% oxygen or a certain amount of helium in the air). The test measures how the concentration of the gases in the container changes.
    • Body plethysmography: This test measures the total amount of air the lungs can hold (total lung volume). For this test, a person sits inside an airtight booth called a plethysmograph and breathes through a mouthpiece while pressure and air flow measurements are collected.

Option D: Total Lung capacity

  • Lung capacity or total lung capacity (T.L.C.) is the volume of air in the lungs upon the maximum effort of inspiration. Among healthy adults, the average lung capacity is about 6 liters.
  • Age, gender, body composition, and ethnicity are factors affecting the different ranges of lung capacity among individuals. T.L.C. rapidly increases from birth to adolescence and plateaus at around 25 years old.
  • Males tend to have a greater T.L.C. than females, while individuals with tall stature tend to have greater T.L.C. than those with short stature, and individuals with a high waist-to-hip ratio generally have a lower T.L.C.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents in the outpatient department with a history of frequent micturition, pain while urinating and low-grade fever for five days. He has had recurrent episodes of similar symptoms for the last few years. Physical examination is normal. Which of the following should be used to visualise any congenital defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: MR urography

  • This patient is most likely suffering from a congenital urinary tract abnormality.
  • The best option for assessing pediatric urinary tract abnormalities is MR UROGRAPHY (MRU).
  • MR urography (MRU) is capable of complete urinary tract medium imaging.
  • In MR Urography, there is no need for ionizing radiation and intravenous contrast medium.
  • This is also beneficial in pregnant females and patients with renal insufficiency.
  • MRU is also very effective for imaging most pediatric lesions and anomalies.
  • MR urogram below suggests vesico ureteric reflex VUR, dilatation of ureters, and hydronephrosis.

Option A: IVP

  • Intravenous pyelography (IVP), or excretory urography (EU), is a radiographic study of the renal parenchyma, pelvicalyceal system, ureters, and the urinary bladder
  • It is an X-ray exam to outline the urinary collecting system
  • However, for assessing pediatric congenital abnormalities, an MR urogram is preferred as it is less invasive.

 

 

Option B: Xray Pelvis

  • It is an incorrect option because x ray pelvis does not help detect congenital urinary tract abnormalities

Option C: 3D CT UROGRAM

  • CT urogram is optimised for renal, ureteric and bladder examination using thin–slice, excretory-phase imaging after intravenous contrast medium administration
  • However, MR urography is superior to CT Urogram as it does not use radiation and IV contrast medium.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented with complaints of a mass in the right upper quadrant of her right breast. Mammography is performed. Which of the following findings on mammography would suggest a malignant lesion?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Microcalcifications

  • Deposits of calcium salts in the breast are referred to as breast calcifications and are radio-opaque on mammography.

  • Although the majority are benign, cancer may be connected to them.

  • The art and science of breast imaging include the capacity to identify, treat, and distinguish between serious microcalcifications and insignificant findings.

  • Microcalcifications are suggestive of a malignant lesion.

  • The pattern and shape of microcalcifications can also give radiologists clues about whether cancer may be present.

    • Linear, rod-like calcifications raise suspicion of underlying breast cancer.

    • Popcorn, eggshell, and rim-like calcifications are usually benign.

Option A: Round well-defined borders

 

  • Round and oval lumps with well-defined borders are often harmless.

  • An uneven form indicates a higher chance of cancer.

  • The edges may be circumscribed, microlobulated, obscured (partially covered by surrounding tissue), ill-defined, or spiculated (characterised by lines radiating from the mass).

Option B: Macrocalcifications

  • Popcorn calcifications, also known as macrocalcifications, are benign tumors called fibroadenomas.

Option D: Fat necrosis

  • When local fat is saponified, a degenerative condition known as fat necrosis in the breast occurs.

  • It is a benign inflammatory condition becoming more prevalent due to the increased usage of mammoplasty and breast-conserving surgery.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man underwent Emergency decompressive craniectomy for subarachnoid hemorrhage. On recovery, the patient had developed seizures .Emergency CT revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which MRI sequence is used to detect brain edema?
questions.solution:
• FLAIR stands for Fluid Attenuation Inversion Recovery Sequence
  • This sequence is similar to T2 with suppression of CSF/Fluid signal so the Brain Edema can be seen better.

Figure: FLAIR image showing edema in bilateral occipital lobe in a case of PRES(posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome).

questions.text: The arrow is pointing towards which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Axial Ct scan image with the arrow pointing to Rt Rectus abdominus muscle

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to Gynaecology OPD reporting increased vaginal discharge from two days. On examination, it is clear, slippery and stretchable between fingers. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. She has been married for 5 years, has two live children, and uses natural fertility awareness methods for contraception. What advice should be given to her?

choices.text: Avoid intercourse for the next 3 days.
Get herself checked for vaginal infection.
Can safely have intercourse from the next day.

questions.solution:
Option A: Avoid intercourse for the next 3 days

  • The cervical mucus method is also called the "ovulation method" or, more commonly ", Billings' ovulation method."
  • The method is based on recognizing the changes in cervical mucus due to the effect of estrogen and progesterone at different times of the menstrual cycle.
  • At the time of ovulation, the mucus becomes more copious, clear, and slippery, resembling the white of a raw egg, and can be stretched slowly between two fingers (Spinnbarkeit Phenomenon). This is due to estrogen, which peaks just before ovulation. The vagina and vulva feel moist or wet. This persists for about 3 days. These are called "wet days"; the last day of wet mucus is called the "peak day." These days mark the peak of fertility.
  • Post ovulation, as estrogen decreases and progesterone increases, the mucous becomes thick and non-stretchable due to the progesterone effect.
  • The ovulation method can be used for both contraception (by avoiding contact on fertile days) and to achieve a pregnancy (by having intercourse during the fertile period). Hence in this question, since the woman has thin, stretchy mucous, she must practice abstinence for the next few days.
  •  

Option B: Can safely have intercourse

  • The patient must not have intercourse for the next few days, as a thin and stretchy mucous implies a peak of estrogen, and thus ovulation is about to occur. Intercourse around this time can lead to a pregnancy.

Option C: Get herself checked for vaginal infection

  • Thin, stretchy vaginal discharge around ovulation is normal and not suggestive of infection.

Option D: Can safely have intercourse from the next day

  • The patient must not have intercourse for the next few days, as a thin and stretchy mucous implies a peak of estrogen, and thus ovulation is about to occur. Intercourse around this time can lead to a pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old young, sexually active woman presents with small pearly white vesicular lesions on the vulva with central dimpling, which started to appear a few days after a sexual encounter. Which of the following features is not associated with the patient's condition?

choices.text: It is caused by a pox virus.
It is commonly seen in HIV and immune-compromised subject
It is treated with metronidazole and doxycycline

questions.solution:
Option D: It is treated with metronidazole and doxycycline

  • Molluscum Contagiosum
  • The poxvirus causes this benign viral illness.
  • It is disseminated by close sexual or nonsexual contact, as well as through autoinoculation.
  • The incubation period might last from a few weeks to several months.
  • Clinical Characteristics: The patient has a crop of tiny domed vesicles with central umbilication ranging from 1 to 5 mm. It is possible to express a white waxy substance from it.
  • Diagnosis: The presence of intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies in the discharge (white waxy substance) is confirmed by Giemsa staining.
  • Treatment: It comprises removing the white substance, removing the nodule with a dermal curet, and treating the base with Monsel's solution (ferric subsulphate) or 85% trichloracetic acid. Alternative therapies include cryotherapy and electrocoagulation.

Option A: It is caused by a pox virus

  • A DNA poxvirus called the molluscum contagiosum virus is the causative agent for warts.
  • The average incubation time is 2 to 7 weeks, although it can be longer.
  • In reaction to the viral invasion, the host develops papular lesions with a central umbilication, giving them a distinctive look.

Option B: It is commonly seen in HIV and immune-compromised subject

  • Sex workers, those with other STDs, smokers, cocaine users with compromised immune systems, and people with contaminated blood transfusions are all considered high-risk groups.
  • The majority of HIV-positive patients are women of childbearing age.
  • HIV patients risk developing molluscum contagiosum, condylomata acuminata and basal cell carcinoma.

Option C: It is treated by cryotherapy

  • Treatment comprises removing the white substance, removing the nodule with a dermal curet, and treating the base with Monsel's solution (ferric subsulphate) or 85% trichloracetic acid. Alternative therapies include cryotherapy and electrocoagulation.

questions.text: What is the best test to differentiate between Mullerian agenesis and testicular feminization syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option C: Karyotype

  • In patients of Mullerian agenesis, the karyotype is 46 XX. Whereas in testicular feminization syndrome (androgen insensitivity syndrome), it is 46 XY.
  • Turner syndrome (gonadal dysgenesis) is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea (karyotype is XO).
  •  
  • USG would reveal the same finding and help in diagnosis, but the investigation of choice is karyotyping.

 

Option A: USG

  • Ultrasonograms will reveal absent uterus, but in Mullerian agenesis, there is the presence of an ovary, and in testicular feminisation syndrome, there will be testes (in the inguinal region).
  • However the final diagnosis can be made only with a karyotyping

 

Option B: Laparoscopy

  • Laparoscopy will reveal an absent uterus in both cases, but in Mullerian agenesis, there is the presence of an ovary, and in testicular feminisation syndrome, there will be testes (in the inguinal region).
  • But just for a diagnosis, laparoscopy is not required.

 

Option D: Hormonal assays

  • Hormonal assays will not be diagnostic because, in the case of Mullerian agenesis, FSH will be raised, and in androgen insensitivity syndrome, testosterone will be raised, but they are not diagnostic because it can happen in many other conditions

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of a vaginal discharge and a fishy odour from the vagina. The discharge is described as creamy white and watery in consistency. There is minimal itching. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gardnerella vaginalis

  • It is the most common cause of bacterial vaginosis.
  • It is also known as Gardnerella vaginalis
  • There is a fishy odour from the vagina.
  • The vaginal secretions are grey and thinly coat the vaginal walls
  • On microscopy, clue cells can be visualised, which are vaginal epithelial cells embedded with the bacteria

  • There is no pruritus in contrast with candidiasis.
  • The Whiff test: Adding KOH to the vaginal secretions releases an amine-like odour.
  • Amsel's criteria are used for diagnosis
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole,
    • Treat the female
    • There is no need to treat her partner as it does not transmit sexually.

Option B: Neisseria gonorrhoea

  • It causes by gonococcal cervicitis and vulvovaginitis.
  • The discharge is usually described as mucopurulent and yellowish.
  • In enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and direct fluorescent antibody (DFA), detection of antigens is 60%-80% and 80%-85% specific, respectively.
  • Nucleic Acid Amplification Technique (NAAT) is the most sensitive and specific (99%)
  • Treatment: It involves treatment of both partners
  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + azithromycin 1 gm oral single dose
  • Cefixime 400 mg single dose + azithromycin 1 gm oral single dose
  • A single dose of ceftriaxone (250mg IM) and azithromycin 1 gm (single dose) for both partners treat Neisseria and chlamydia.

Option C: Trichomonas vaginalis

  • Trichomonas vaginalis causes trichomonas vaginitis or trichomoniasis.
  • There is inflammation of the vagina.
  • A strawberry cervix may also be present.
  • There is a frothy, yellow-green, foul-smelling discharge.
  • There are motile pear-shaped trichomonads on microscopy.
  • The pH is usually greater than 4.5

Option D: Candida albicans

  • Candidiasis is caused by the fungi Candida albicans
  • It is a dimorphic fungus
    • Blastospores (spread)
    • Mycelia (invasive and adherent)
  • Pseudohyphae may be visualised on microscopy.
  • It occurs in acidic pH.
  • The thick, white "cottage cheese" discharge is sometimes described as Curdy white.
  • There are thick plaques on the vaginal wall, which, when removed, result in petechiae.
  • Pruritis may also present, which is out of proportion to the lesion.
  • Treatment
    • Azoles
    • Oral Fluconazole
    • Treat both partners
    • Treat both partners

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous patient with primary infertility presents to the clinic for evaluation and management of the causes of her infertility. Her abdominal and pelvic examinations are unremarkable, but an ultrasound reveals an ovarian mass of unclear aetiology. Doctor advised CA125 level, which turned out to be 90 U/L. Which of the following is the most likely cause of ovarian mass in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Endometrioma

  • Ovarian masses associated with infertility in young women are most likely endometriotic.
  • Endometrioma is a condition in which endometrial-like tissue is found on an ovary. They are found as cysts filled with blood, so commonly known as 'chocolate cysts.'
  • They are painful and affect a patient's fertility.
  • CA 125 is a marker for epithelial ovarian cancer, but since the patient here is young and has presented with infertility and the value of CA 125 is not exceptionally high, the chances of endometrioma are more.

CA 125:

  • Elevated in 80% of patients with advanced ovarian cancer.
  • It May also be elevated in pancreatic, gastric, colonic, and breast carcinoma; in non-malignant conditions such as benign cysts, endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, and ascites; and in menstruation and pregnancy.
  • Further, it may be normal in 50% of early-stage ovarian cancer.

Option A: Epithelial ovarian cancer

  • Epithelial ovarian cancer usually presents in advanced age and shows exceptionally high CA 125 values. It presents with vague abdominal complaints, menstrual irregularities, ascites or postmenopausal bleeding and rarely with infertility.

Option B: Dysgerminoma

  • Dysgerminoma usually presents with abdominal pain and a pelvic mass, and the tumour marker for dysgerminoma is LDH and PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)

Option C: Borderline ovarian tumour

  • The borderline ovarian tumour also presents in the advanced age group and does not present with infertility.

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for the mid-cycle rise in body temperature in females?
questions.solution:
Option D: Progesterone

Basal body temperature

  • Biphasic changes in BBT are characteristic of the ovulatory cycle.
  • Mediated by alterations in progesterone levels.
  • It regulates the menstrual cycle.
  • It rises after ovulation and peaks in 5-9 days after the luteal phase.
  • If fertilization doesn't occur, the corpus luteum rupture and decreases the progesterone level.
  • The progesterone secretion following ovulation causes a temperature rise of about 0.5 to 1°F over the baseline of 97°F to 98.8°F that is recorded during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.
  • Ovulation is assumed after three days of raised temperatures.
  • FSH is responsible for the stimulation and growth of the ovarian follicle.

Option A: FSH

  • FSH is responsible for the stimulation and growth of the ovarian follicle and negative feedback inhibition of estrogen.
  • It has no action on body temperature.

Option B: LH

  • LH is responsible for the final maturation of the follicle and ovulation.
  • LH surge and peak are followed by ovulation.
  • It is not responsible for the change in body temperature.

​​​​​​​Option C: Estradiol

  • Estradiol is responsible for making endometrium proliferative and making cervical mucous thin and slippery.
  • The change in body temperature is related to the progesterone hormone, not estradiol.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman gives a history of sharp pain in the lower abdomen for 2-3 days every month approximately 2 weeks before the menses. The most probable etiology for her pain is
questions.solution:
Option D : Midcycle pain or Ovulation pain is called Mittelschmerz .

This is because of the blood, fluid and cellular debris which comes out of the ruptured ovarian follicle trickles to the pelvis and causes a mild peritoneal irritation and pain, often limited to that side of ovulation.
During ovulation, the mature egg is released from the ovary, and this process can cause irritation and stretching of the ovarian tissue and surrounding structures. The pain experienced during Mittelschmerz is usually described as a sharp or cramp-like pain on one side of the lower abdomen, corresponding to the side where the ovary is releasing the egg. The pain may last for a few minutes to a few hours and can occur intermittently over 2-3 days.

Option A : Pain in endometriosis is usually sustained lower abdominal pain or congestive type of dysmenorrhea, which starts few days prior to onset of periods and ends after start of periods.

Option B : Dysmenorrhea is pain that occurs during periods

Option C : Pelvic TB is rarely associated with lower abdominal pain or with dysmenorrhea, more with hypomenorrhea or amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman with recurrent episodes of rectal bleeding underwent a sigmoidoscopy. Blackish hemorrhagic lesions were seen and biopsy was taken. Biopsy revealed endometrial glands and stroma. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A : Most common site of endometriosis is the Ovary, followed closely by the POD deposits, surfaces of the peritoneum (including broad ligament, uterosacral ligaments, surface of the uterus). These lesions are black, dark brown, or bluish nodules or small cysts containing old hemorrhage surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis Histologic confirmation of the laparoscopic impression is essential for the diagnosis of endometriosis. Biopsy reveals endometrial glands or stroma or both.

The most common site of extrapelvic endometriotic implants is intestinal tract. This may present with abdominal pain, distension, rectal bleeding, obstruction.

Other sites include: lungs, pleural cavity, skin, surgical scars

Option B : Utero-intestinal fistula is a rare entity which can occur due to iatrogenic injury during gynaecological surgery, can present with rectal bleeding but the presence of hemorrhagic lesions and endometrial glands and stroma in biopsy rules out this condition

Option C : GIST are uncommon cancers of GI tract occurring in stomach or small intestine, can present with abdominal pain, GI bleeding, on endoscopy show well circumscribed fleshy pink tumor growth with hemorrhagic or degenerative changes, on HPE show spindle cells with pale eosinophilic cytoplasm ovoid nuclei and syncitial cell borders. Here the presence of endometrial glands and stroma on biospy rules out GIST.

Option D : Accidental uterine injury can occur due to iatrogenic injury during gynaecological surgery, can present with rectal bleeding but the presence of hemorrhagic lesions and endometrial glands and stroma in biopsy rules out this condition

questions.text: A woman with known history of fibroid uterus with heavy menstrual bleeding presents for treatment. She is not willing for any form of surgery and so the doctor prescribes her Ulipristal acetate. The mechanism of action of this drug is
questions.solution:
Option B : Ulipristal acetate

  • Synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator
  • Attaches to progesterone receptor and prevents/delays ovulation and suppresses endometrium, prevents implantation.
  • Although not approved for its use in India, it is being tried for its role in medical management of fibroid uterus and as an emergency contraceptive

Option A : Ulipristal is not a GnRH agonist or antagonist.

Option C : Antiandrogens like spironolactone and finasteride are used for the treatment of PCOS and hirsutism.

Option D : SERM used in gynaecology is ormeloxifene, which is a non steroidal oral contraceptive.

questions.text: What factor is accountable for transforming the gonad into testes, leading to the development of a male?
questions.solution:
Option A: Presence of SRY gene

  • The human gonad is a bipotential gonad till 5 weeks of intrauterine development, which implies it has the potential to develop into either ovary or testes
  • Gonads acquire male or female characteristics only after 6 weeks of development, i.e., in the 7th week of development.
  • Gonadal differentiation is an active process directed by the presence or absence of the SRY gene.
  • The presence of the SRY gene will differentiate gonads into the testis.
  • Absence will lead to the differentiation of gonads into ovaries.

 

 

Option B: Lack of SRY gene

  • Lack of SRY gene or absence of SRY gene will lead to failure of the testicle formation.

 

Option C: Presence of AMH

  • The presence of the anti-mullerian hormone (AMH) is responsible for suppressing structures that would otherwise form from the paramesonephric duct.

 

Option D: Presence of Testosterones

  • The presence of testosterone during development leads to the formation of male external characteristics.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, P2, presents with complaints of a mass descending per vagina, for the last 2 months. She reports discomfort and back pain, aggravated by long hours of standing and relieved by rest. On pelvic examination, there is uterocervical descent beyond the introitus. Which of the following is the most acceptable management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fothergill's repair

  • As the patient's age is 28 years, uterine preservation is a concern.
  • Uterine Preservation surgeries for prolapse are
    • Anterior and posterior pelvic repair
    • Fothergill's repair (Manchester surgery)
    • Shirodkar's procedure
    • Abdominal sling surgeries: Shirodkar, Khanna, Purandre's abdominocervicopexy.
  • Fothergill's repair /Manchester operation
    • The principle of the procedure is to amputate the elongated cervix and approximate the cardinal ligaments anterior to the cervix to elevate and retract it backwards so that the uterus is both supported and anteverted.
    • Cervix is reconstructed, and anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy are performed.
    • Curettage is performed at the onset of the operation to exclude the presence of intrauterine pathology.
    • Indicated in the reproductive age group with the prolapse and when the patient refuses hysterectomy
    • Done only if a family is complete because it can cause problems like cervical incompetence

 

Option B: Wertheim hysterectomy

  • Wertheim hysterectomy is a radical abdominal hysterectomy used for the treatment of cervical cancer.

Option C: Perineal exercise x 3 months

  • Perineal exercises can improve the symptoms to some extent, or atleast halt the progression of symptoms, but it is not the best management option.

Option D: Vaginal hysterectomy with vault repair

  • Vaginal hysterectomy with vault repair is a good management option in postmenopausal or old patients where uterus preservation is not a concern.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida presents to the hospital with postpartum seizures. She is diagnosed with eclampsia, and magnesium sulfate is started. While on magnesium sulfate therapy, her respiratory rate falls to 10/min and her SpO2 drops to 55%. She was quickly intubated and started on invasive ventilation. Among various lab tests, the doctor orders Mg2+ levels. Which of the following are expected levels of Mg2+ in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option C: >10 mEq/L

  • This patient on magnesium sulfate therapy due to postpartum eclampsia has most likely developed magnesium toxicity. This is evident from decreased respiratory rate and SpO2, indicating respiratory depression.
  • Respiratory depression in magnesium toxicity occurs at levels >10 mEq/L.

 

  • Eclampsia is a hypertensive pregnancy disorder characterised by seizures and preeclampsia (headaches, visual disturbances, nausea, high BP, and proteinuria).
  • The first-line treatment of eclampsia is magnesium sulfate therapy.
  • While giving MgSO4, the following points should be considered:
    • Respiratory rate should be at least more than 12
    • Output should be more than 100 ml / 4hrs
    • Knee jerks should be present
  • Magnesium sulfate therapy during the management of eclampsia can result in magnesium toxicity.
  • During Magnesium toxicity, the first reflex to be lost is the patellar reflex (loss of knee jerk).
  • Clinical features of increasing blood magnesium levels are given in the table:
Serum Mg2+ levels(meq/l) Clinical effects
4-7 Normal therapeutic level
8 – 10 Patellar reflex disappears
10-15 Respiratory depression
12-15 Respiratory paralysis
25 – 30 Cardiac arrest
  • Treatment is with calcium gluconate 1 g IV

Option A: 5–7 mEq/L

  • This is the normal therapeutic range of magnesium in the blood. There will be no signs of toxicity at these levels.

Option B: 7-10 mEq/L

  • At these levels, the patellar reflex disappears due to magnesium toxicity. However, there is no respiratory depression at these levels.

Option D: >25 mEq/L

  • This is an advanced stage of magnesium toxicity characterised by cardiac and respiratory arrest.
  • The given patient has not yet developed cardiopulmonary arrest.

questions.text: A 35-year-old multigravida has had amenorrhea for about 4 months. She had an abortion 5 months back, followed by a curettage to stop bleeding. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A progesterone withdrawal test performed is negative. What is the most likely cause of amenorrhea in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D : The Patient had a second-trimester abortion, following which a curettage was done to remove the retained products leading to intrauterine adhesions called Ashermann syndrome. These adhesions make the endometrium non-functional such that it does not grow( or bleed subsequently) with endogenous E+P (as ovarian function is normal) and similarly to exogenous E+P (E+P challenge).The best diagnostic method is hysteroscopy to visualise adhesions and this is treated by adhesiolysis.

Asherman syndrome

  • Characterized by uterine synechiae, usually results from destruction on large areas of endometrium by overzealous curettage done for
    • AUB
    • MTP
    • Secondary PPH (due to retained bits of placenta)
  • Clinical features - Hypomenorrhea, amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea
  • Definitive diagnosis – Hysteroscopy
  • Preferred Rx –Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis and post operative high dose estrogen and progesterone therapy to rebuild the endometrium

Option A and B: Patients with both hypothalmo/ pituitary failure and ovarian failure will get menses with E + P. Absence of withdrawal by E + P indicates end organ failure. In both hypothalamic/ pituitary failure and ovarian failure the end defect is absence of E and P, which when overcome by exogenous E+P, must make the endometrium grow and bleed subsequently.

Option C : In patient with secondary amenorrhea, after ruling out pregnancy progesterone challenge test is to be done. Patients with anovulation will get menses with progesterone. (Progesterone acts only on estrogen primed endometrium. In patients with anovulation, estrogen is present but progesterone is absent).

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her antenatal check-up at 18 weeks of gestation. She has no active complaints. She has no history of any medical disorder. She has been a known cocaine addict for 4 years and continues to use cocaine during pregnancy despite being advised against it. A detailed anomaly scan is advised. Which fetal anomalies are most likely to be seen due to cocaine abuse in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cleft palate

  • Cocaine is a drug of abuse.
  • It is a sympathomimetic drug. It inhibits neuronal uptake of norepinephrine.
  • Drugs of abuse are an absolute contraindication during pregnancy because of their teratogenic effects.
  • Most of the adverse outcomes associated with cocaine occur due to its vasoconstrictive properties and hypertensive effects.
  • It has both maternal and fetal complications.
  • Maternal complications include:
  • Cerebrovascular haemorrhage
  • Myocardial damage
  • Placental abruption
  • Preterm labour
  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • Precipitous labour
  • Fetal complications include:
  • Cleft palate
  • Cardiovascular abnormalities
  • Urinary tract abnormalities
  • Skull defects
  • Visceral infarcts
  • Fetal-growth restriction

Children exposed to cocaine during intrauterine life are at an increased risk of behavioural abnormalities and cognitive impairments.

 

Option A: Sacral agenesis

  • Sacral agenesis is a part of caudal regression syndrome.
  • The cause of sacral agenesis is unknown.
  • Some cases have been linked with uncontrolled maternal diabetes.

 

Option B: Hydrops fetalis

  • Hydrops fetalis may occur due to Rh incompatibility between the mother and fetus.
  • Other non immune causes include parvovirus B19, cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex virus infections.
  • It is not associated with cocaine abuse.

 

Option D: Hypertrichosis

  • Hypertrichosis is excessive hair growth.
  • It has an unknown aetiology.
  • It is a genetic disorder which is inherited or results from spontaneous mutation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with fever, flu-like symptoms, rash, white plaques in the mouth and cervical lymphadenopathy. He has a history of razor blade sharing with his roommates back in college. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) testing comes out to be positive. His wife, who is pregnant at 4 months of gestation, is advised to get HIV testing, which also turns out positive. Another test confirms a positive HIV status. She is currently asymptomatic. Which of the following is true regarding antiretroviral therapy (ART) to prevent HIV transmission from the mother to child in this case?

choices.text: Given only If CD4 counts are less than 350 cells/mm3
If viral copies are more than 1000 cells/mm3
Given to all pregnant women with HIV irrespective of gestational age of presentation

questions.solution:
Option C: Given to all pregnant women with HIV, irrespective of gestational age of presentation.

  • Human immunodeficiency virus is a retrovirus, enveloped RNA virus, containing 2 molecules of RNA. It infects and replicates in CD4+ T cells and macrophages, leading to eventual immune system dysfunction, opportunistic infections and malignancy, which is also called acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
  • It is transmitted by blood, sexual fluids and breast milk.
  • Pathophysiology: HIV binds to CD4 receptors on helper T cells, macrophages and monocytes by its gp120 envelope and replicate in these cells. The new virions are released that infect new CD4 cells. The continued progress of the infection leads to decreased immune function. It has a reverse transcriptase enzyme, which produces DNA copies from viral RNA. It has no proofreading ability, so multiple mutations occur, accounting for treatment resistance.
  • HIV testing:
    • ELISA for HIV antibody and antigen (p24): Very high sensitivity and specificity.
    • Rapid point-of care-testing.
    • Viral load: Quantification of viral RNA.
    • Nucleic acid amplification test/ Viral PCR: It is a qualitative test for the presence of viral RNA. It is used to test for vertical transmission in neonates as the transfer of maternal antibodies can affect ELISA antibody testing.
    • CD4 count: Used to monitor immune system function.
  • Antiretroviral therapy:
    • It is recommended for everyone with HIV, regardless of CD4 count, and aims to reduce viral load to undetectable>It includes the following medications:
      • Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs): Include Zidovudine, Abacavir, Lamivudine, Didanosine etc. These inhibit reverse transcriptase and conversion of viral RNA and DNA.
      • Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs): Delavirdine, Efavirenz, Nevirapine etc. These also inhibit reverse transcriptase enzymes. Nevirapine is safe during pregnancy. 
      • Integrase inhibitors: Raltegravir, Bictegravir. These prevent HIV DNA integration into host DNA by blocking the integrase enzyme.
      • Protease inhibitors: Ritonavir, Indinavir, Darunavir etc. These prevent the maturation of new viruses.
      • Fusion inhibitor: Enfuvirtide. Binds gp41 and inhibits viral entry into the host cell.
      • Entry inhibitor: Maraviroc. Binds CCR5 on the surface of T-cells and inhibits interaction with gp120.
    • For treatment of a patient with HIV, consider 2 NNRTIs with one of these:
      • Ritonavir boosted protease inhibitors.
      • NNRTIs.
      • Integrase inhibitor.
    • Decreased adherence to antiretroviral therapy leads to drug resistance and disease progression. So, adherence support is mandatory.
  • Management of a pregnant woman with HIV:
    • The risks of mother-to-child transmission of HIV are related to:
      • Increased risk is associated with: advanced maternal HIV disease, high maternal plasma viral load, low CD4 lymphocyte counts, chorioamnionitis, coexisting viral infections (Hepatitis B and C), preterm delivery and breastfeeding.
      • Decreased risk is associated with: low viral counts at the time of delivery, antiretroviral therapy, delivery by Cesarean section and exclusive formula feeding.
    • Interventions that can be done to reduce vertical transmission include:
      •  Antiretroviral therapy is given antenatally and intrapartum to the mother and the neonate for the first 4-6 weeks of life.
      • Delivery by elective cesarean section in the presence of high viral load.
      • Avoidance of breastfeeding.
    • To prevent HIV transmission from mother to child, triple agent antiretroviral therapy is given to all HIV+ pregnant women irrespective of their gestational age of presentation, CD4 counts and stage of the disease.
    • A planned vaginal delivery can be done for women with viral loads less than 50 copies/ml.
  • All infants born to HIV+ mothers should be treated with antiretroviral therapy.

 

Option A: Given if CD4 counts are less than 350 cells/mm3.

  • CD4 cell counts show the progression of the disease and the condition of the immune system.
  • Antiretroviral therapy should be started in HIV+ pregnant women as soon as the diagnosis is confirmed, irrespective of the cell count.

 

Option B: If viral copies are more than 1000 cells/mm3.

  • Antiretroviral therapy is started in an HIV pregnant woman irrespective of the viral load.

 

Option D: Single agent is preferred.

 

  • Antiretroviral therapy includes using 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors and 1 drug from non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors, protease inhibitors, entry inhibitors or integrase inhibitors.
  • A single drug is not used as it leads to resistance against the drug.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with G2P1 presents to the antenatal clinic at the 20th week of gestation with a complaint of white discharge from the vagina, not associated with pain or itching. On examination, the discharge is whitish, homogenous and associated with a fishy odour. A microscopic examination shows clue cells. Which of the following is the best drug to use to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Metronidazole

  • Bacterial vaginosis is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis, a gram variable rod. It presents a non-painful, non-itchy, thin grey vaginal discharge with a fishy smell. It is due to the overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria in the vagina due to decreased lactobacilli.
  • On microscopy of the vaginal discharge, clue cells are seen, which are vaginal epithelial cells coated with Gardnerella and have stippled appearance along the outer margins.
  • Adding 10% KOH to the vaginal secretions releases an amine-like fishy odour (amine whiff test).
  • Amsel's criteria are used for diagnosis. If 3 out of the following 4 are present, the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is confirmed:
  1. Homogenous, non-clumping, grey-white vaginal discharge.
  2. Positive amine whiff test.
  3. Presence of greater than 20% clue cells/HPF on wet mount microscopy.
  4. Vaginal pH >4.5
  • Treatment of bacterial vaginosis includes metronidazole. It is not a sexually transmitted disease, so only the affected woman must be treated.
  • Metronidazole works by forming toxic free radical metabolites in the bacterial cell that damage DNA. It treats Giardia, Entamoeba, Trichomonas, Gardnerella vaginalis, and anaerobes (Bacteroides, Clostridium difficile). Adverse effects include disulfiram-like reactions with alcohol, headache and a metallic taste in the mouth.
  • Although no drug is considered completely safe in the first trimester of pregnancy, there is relative safety in using class 'B' drugs during pregnancy. Metronidazole comes under this class where the drug is safe in animal studies and most human studies.
  • If given a choice in the first trimester, it is wise to use an absolute safe agent like betadine vaginal pessary, which will buy time until the patient is in the second trimester for safe usage of category B or even C drugs.

 

Option A: Clindamycin

  • It is a bacteriostatic antibiotic that blocks translocation at the 50S ribosomal subunit in bacteria.
  • It treats anaerobic lung infections such as aspiration pneumonia, lung abscess and oral infections.
  • It is not used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

Option C: Erythromycin

  • Erythromycin is a macrolide that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.
  • It can be used to treat atypical pneumonia(mycoplasma, chlamydia, legionella), sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia, and bordetella pertussis.

Option D: Rovamycin

  • It is a macrolide antibiotic and is effective against gram-positive aerobic pathogens, N. gonorrhoeae, and staphylococci.
  • It is not used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman with no previous prenatal visits presented to the maternity emergency with labour pains at 34 weeks and delivered a premature baby vaginally. The baby had a bullous lesion on his body. The paediatrician ordered an X-ray which showed periostitis. Which of the following is the next most appropriate investigation that should be done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: VDRL for mother and baby.

  • Syphilis is a sexually acquired infection caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.
  • Primary syphilis presents as a painless genital lesion 3-6 weeks after the infection is acquired. This lesion is also known as a chancre. Dark-field or fluorescent microscopy shows treponemes in fluid from chancre. 
  • Secondary syphilis occurs about 6 weeks to 6 months after the primary infection. It presents as a maculopapular rash affecting the mucous membranes, palms and soles, condyloma lata (a smooth, painless, wart-like white lesion on genitals), lymphadenopathy, and patchy hair loss. It can also be confirmed by dark-field microscopy.
  • Some patients progress to tertiary syphilis, which has cardiovascular and neurologic complications. Gummas are formed, which are chronic granulomas, aortitis (destruction of vasa vasorum), neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis and general paresis), Argyll Robertson's pupil (constricts with accommodation but does not react to light), Charcot's joints and stroke without hypertension can occur.

In pregnant women with early untreated syphilis, 70%-100% of infants would be affected. Mother-to-child transmission of syphilis occurs in the first trimester. It is associated with fetal growth restriction, fetal hydrops, congenital syphilis (associated with long-term disability), preterm birth, stillbirth and neonatal death. The risk of congenital transmission decreases with the increasing duration of maternal syphilis before pregnancy. Treatment with benzathine penicillin (Penicillin G) improves outcomes in the fetus.

  • Pregnant women should be screened for syphilis by the following screening tests:
    • Non-treponemal tests detect non-specific treponemal antibodies, including the VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) and rapid plasma reagin(RPR) tests. The VDRL tests antibodies that are reactive to cardiolipin lecithin cholesterol and may be falsely positive in systemic lupus erythematosus, leprosy, infectious mononucleosis, pregnancy, rheumatic fever, tuberculosis and certain drugs(chlorpromazine, procainamide). It is a quantitative, inexpensive and widely available test which is sensitive but not specific.
    • Treponemal tests detect specific treponemal antibodies and include fluorescent treponemal antibody-absorbed tests (FTA-abs), Treponema pallidum haemagglutinin assay(TPHA) and enzyme immunoassays(EIA). These tests are the gold standard for the diagnosis of syphilis.
  • When the diagnosis of syphilis is confirmed, tests for other sexually transmitted diseases should also be done. Parenteral penicillin has a 98% rate of success in preventing congenital syphilis. A Jarish-Herxhiemer reaction may occur with treatment due to the release of inflammatory substances in response to dying organisms. It presents with fever and worsening symptoms after commencing treatment. It is associated with uterine contractions and fetal distress.
  • If a woman with syphilis is not treated during pregnancy, the baby should be treated after delivery. An infected baby may or may not be born with signs and symptoms of the disease. If the baby is not treated immediately, he may have developmental delay, seizures or death within a few weeks.
  • The above-mentioned clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital syphilis. Mothers who do not get appropriate antenatal care are at increased risk of transmitting infections to newborns. So we will do VDRL of both mother and baby to confirm.

Option A: ELISA for HIV.

  • An HIV positive infant born to an HIV-positive mother would present with recurrent infections, chronic diarrhoea, oral thrush and pneumonia.

Option B: PCR for TB.

  • Bullous lesions on the body and periostitis of long bones on X-ray are features of congenital syphilis, not tuberculosis.

Option D: HBsAg for mothers.

  • Pregnant women with hepatitis B can transmit the infection to the newborn. However, the recent hep B vaccine and immunoglobulin have decreased the incidence of hepatitis B infection.
  • Bullous lesions on the body and periostitis of long bones on X-ray are not seen in hepatitis B

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman, G2P0A1, is at 30 weeks gestation. Her fundal height measures 25cm. An obstetrical ultrasound examination reveals a 4 quadrant amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4cm. Which of the following fetal conditions is associated with the finding?
questions.solution:
Option D : AFI <4 cm is suggestive of Oligohydramnios

  • The only option of the provided that leads to oligohydramnios is Renal agenesis.

Oligohydramnios can be caused by -

  1. Renal anomalies
  2. Uteroplacental insufficiency: IUGR
  3. ACE inhibitors
  4. Premature rupture of membranes
  5. Amniocentesis (leak)
  6. Pre-eclampsia
  7. Amnion nodosum
  8. NSAIDs
  9. Post term pregnancy
  10. over estimated gestational age

Option A, B, C : Duodenal atresia, open spina bifida, tracheo-esophageal fistula are all causes of polyhydramnios as they are all associated with open meninges or mucosal surfaces which exude fluid and cause polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, Gravida 2, Para 2, at 38 weeks of gestation, presents in active labour. On examination, her contractions are regular, her cervix is 4 cm dilated, and she is 50 % effaced. The fetal head is at 0 stations. Which of the following is the fetal head diameter most likely engaged in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C : The commonest diameter for fetal head engagement is suboccipitobregmatic, as it leads to vertex presentation for normal vaginal delivery.

Diameters Measurement In CM (Inches) Attitude Of The Head Presentation
1. Suboccipito-bregmatic 9.5 cm (3 ¾’’) Complete flexion Vertex
2. Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
3. Occipito-frontal 11.5 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
4. Mento-vertical 14 cm (5 ½”) Deflexed head/ military position Brow
5. Submento vertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension Face
6.Submento-bregmatic 9.5 cm (3 ¾’’) Complete extension Face

Option A : Submento-vertical diameter is engaged in incomplete extension, in face presentation.

Option B : Occipito-frontal is engaded in incomplete flexion

Option D : Mento-vertical engages in brow presentation.

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman presents to the emergency with high-grade fever and left flank pain. She has a history of recurrent UTIs. There is tenderness demonstrable at the costovertebral angle. Which of the following pathogens most commonly causes such presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Escherichia coli

  • This patient with a history of recurrent UTIs presenting with flank pain, fever, and costovertebral angle tenderness most likely has acute pyelonephritis.
  • E. coli is the most common bacteria responsible for urinary tract infections in pregnancy, including acute pyelonephritis and asymptomatic bacteriuria. Other organisms are klebsiella, enterobacter, proteus, staphylococcus, and group B streptococcus.
  • Urinary tract infections in pregnancy are a risk factor for:
    • threatened abortion
    • chorioamnionitis
    • preterm labor
    • IUGR
    • increased perinatal mortality
    • maternal anaemia
    • preeclampsia

Option B: Klebsiella pneumoniae

  • Although klebsiella can cause UTIs in pregnancy, it is not the most common pathogen causing UTIs.

Option C: Proteus mirabilis

  • It is not the most common pathogen causing UTIs in pregnancy. It is responsible for a small amount of UTIs.

Option D: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

  • It is not the most common pathogen causing UTIs in pregnancy.

questions.text: An 18 month baby with poor feeding & fever since 3 days is brought with lower limb weakness. On examination, he has lethargy, abnormal movement of lower limbs & anterior fontanelle is bulging. What is the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Given case scenario suggests the diagnosis of Meningitis

BACTERIAL MENINGITIS:

  • MC organism causing Bacterial Meningitis in neonates → E.coli [India], Group B streptococci [world]
  • In Infants & older children → streptococcus pneumoniae

Clinical features in infants & Neonates:

  • Irritability
  • Shrill cry
  • Seizures
  • Tense, bulging anterior fontanelle

Diagnosis:

  • CSF examination
  • PCR to detect bacterial DNA

Treatment:

  • Empirical intravenous therapy with third generation Cephalosporin.
  • Therapy is usually administered for 3 weeks in neonates and for 7-10 days in older children.

Note: Nuchal rigidity and Kernig and Brudzinski signs are frequently seen in adults but are not present in the neonate with meningitis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl child is brought by her mother to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of poor physical growth. She looks pale, has hair loss, and frequently falls ill. Her diet is vegetarian. On examination, her sexual characteristics are delayed. Her Hb is 8 g/dL. Which element is deficient in this girl?
questions.solution:
Option C: Zinc

  • The symptoms of poor physical growth, pallor, hair loss and delayed sexual characteristics are suggestive of zinc deficiency.
  • A deficiency of zinc can lead to the syndrome of growth failure, anaemia and hypogonadism.

 

Zinc

  • Second most common trace element in the body after iron.
  • It plays a role in gene transcription, nucleic acid metabolism, and protein synthesis and acts as a major antioxidant (being part of the enzyme superoxide dismutase)
  • It is mainly derived from animal protein. Liver, oyster, meat, fish, nuts and eggs are rich sources.
  • Zinc Deficiency
    • Poor physical growth
    • Delayed sexual maturation and hypogonadism
    • Alopecia
    • Anaemia
    • Diarrhoea
    • Dermatitis
    • Impaired immune function
    • Poor wound healing
    • Skeletal abnormalities
    • Acrodermatitis enteropathica
  • Treatment: 0.5-1.0 mg elemental zinc/kg/ day

Option A: Calcium Deficiency

  • Calcium deficiency leads to Tetany and rickets.
  • In old age, a deficiency of calcium leads to osteoporosis.

Option B: Copper deficiency

  • Copper deficiency causes Microcytic anaemia and hypochromic anaemia that are nonresponsive to iron therapy.
  • It may also cause hair depigmentation, neutropenia, neurological problems and osteoporosis.

Option D: Magnesium deficiency:

  • Magnesium deficiency causes Irritability, Tetany and hypo- or hyperreflexia
  • In the heart, magnesium deficiency causes cardiac arrhythmias

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is admitted to the hospital with complaints of confusion and weakness for the past few days.
