Her medical history is significant for small-cell lung cancer, which was diagnosed two months ago. On examination, she appears disoriented and her blood pressure is within the normal range. Laboratory investigations reveal serum sodium levels of 120 mEq/L (normal range: 135-145 mEq/L) and serum osmolarity of 240 mOsm/L (normal range: 275-295 mOsm/L). Urinalysis shows a high specific gravity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Correct Option: 3. Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH)

Explanation of Options:

  1. Dehydration: Dehydration is unlikely in this case, as the patient's blood pressure is within the normal range, and the specific gravity of the urine is high, indicating concentrated urine, which is inconsistent with dehydration.

  2. Hyperaldosteronism: Hyperaldosteronism is characterized by excessive production of aldosterone, a hormone that regulates sodium and potassium levels in the blood. It would typically result in hypernatremia (high serum sodium levels) rather than hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) seen in this patient.

  3. Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH): SIADH is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH or vasopressin), leading to increased water retention by the kidneys and dilutional hyponatremia. This condition often occurs in patients with small-cell lung cancer and other malignancies, as tumors can produce and release ADH.

  4. Diabetes Insipidus: Diabetes insipidus is a condition caused by insufficient production or action of ADH, leading to excessive urine production and increased thirst. In diabetes insipidus, serum sodium levels are typically elevated (hypernatremia) due to excessive loss of water in the urine.

In this case, the patient's symptoms of confusion and weakness, along with hyponatremia, low serum osmolarity, and high urine specific gravity, strongly suggest SIADH. The underlying small-cell lung cancer is likely responsible for the inappropriate release of ADH. Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause, restricting fluid intake, and, in severe cases, administering hypertonic saline to correct the hyponatremia gradually.

questions.text: A 5-day-old child presents with intractable seizures. He had rashes all over his body. Blood examination showed hyperammonemia and lactic acidosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Organic acidemia

  • The presence of hyperammonemia and lactic acidosis in a child with neurological and cutaneous manifestations suggests a diagnosis of organic acidemia.
  • They present as lethargy, poor feeding, coma, vomiting, seizures, developmental delay, dystonia, and specific odours.
  • Investigation findings may include metabolic acidosis, lactic acidosis, ketosis, hyperammonemia, hypoglycemia, and neutropenia
  • Types of organic acidemia:
    • Maple syrupurine disease
    • Methylmalonic acidemia
    • Propionic acidemia
    • Multiple Carboxylase deficiency
    • Glutaric acidemia
    • Isovaleric acidemia

Option B: MELAS syndrome

  • Mitochondrial myopathy, encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke (MELAS) syndrome present with stroke-like symptoms, as the name implies.

Option C: Phenylketonuria

  • Phenylketonuria presents with microcephaly, epilepsy, musty body odour, and reduced skin, hair, and eye pigmentation.

Option D: Urea cycle enzyme deficiency

  • Urea cycle enzyme deficiency presents poor feeding and seizures but no rash.

questions.text: A  2 year oldchild presents with a history of high fever for 4 days and seizures. A pink maculopapular, nonpruriticrash develops on the trunk the day after the fever subsides. Sub-occipital lymph nodes are palpable. Oropharyngeal examination shows the presence of ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Roseola infantum

  • Roseola infantum is caused by human herpesvirus 6 and human herpesvirus 7 infections.

  • Human herpesvirus 6B is the most common pathogen.

  • Roseola infantum is also known as exanthema subitum or sixth disease.

  • Roseola infantum presents as acute onset of high-grade fever. The fever subsides in 3-4 days, coincident with the appearance of the rash.

  • The rash is pink or rose-coloured, non-pruritic, and appears on the trunk.

  • Morbilliform rash lasts 1-3 days.

  • Ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction are called Nagayama spots.

  • Nagayama spots are a common finding in Asian children with Roseola infantum.

  • Supportive care is given for the treatment of Roseola infantum.

Option B: Measles

  • The measles virus causes measles.

  • The measles virus is a single-stranded, negative-sense, enveloped RNA virus.

  • Measles virus infection is characterized by cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and koplik spots.

  • The rash of measles coincides with a high fever. The rash begins on the face and spreads to other body parts.

  • Red, maculopapular, pruritic rash is characteristic of measles.

Option C: Rubella

  • Rubella is caused by infection with the Rubella virus.

  • Rubella is also known as German measles.

  • Patients infected with Rubella present with a low-grade fever, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, headache and conjunctivitis.

  • The rash of Rubella is typically pink or light-red, pruritic and lasts for about three days.

  • The rash appears first on the face and then spreads to the chest and limbs.

  • Forchheimer spots are small, red papules on the soft palate and are characteristic of rubella virus infection.

Option D: Varicella

  • Varicella is also known as chickenpox and is caused by the varicella-zoster virus.

  • A low-grade fever is reported in varicella.

  • Varicella results in characteristic skin rash that forms small, itchy blisters.

  • These blisters eventually form crusted lesions.

  • Crops of lesions in different stages of development are characteristic findings in chickenpox.

  • The rash typically begins on the chest, back, and face and then spreads to other body parts.

  • Rash and fever are present simultaneously in varicella infection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old multigravid woman comes to the ED with labor pains. An emergency cesarean section is performed and a large-for-age baby is delivered. A neonatologist evaluates the baby lying uncovered in the baby cot. Which of the following factors prevents newborns from suffering hypothermia?

choices.text: Larger head size compared to rest of the body

questions.solution:
Option D: Brown fat

  • The presence of brown fat is a protective mechanism (non-shivering thermogenesis) against hypothermia in newborn babies. They are prone to hypothermia because of their large body surface area and are at more risk if large in size or pre-term.
  • Maintaining the normal temperature in the newborn is one of the major measures to be done immediately after birth. Thus, the delivered infant is first placed in a warmed towel or blanket to minimise heat loss.
  • Skin-to-skin contact with the mother is also one of the measures to keep the temperature within normal limits.
  • The normal limit of neonatal temperature is between 36.5oC and 37.5oC.

Option A: More body surface area

  • Large-sized babies and pre-term infants are particularly prone to develop hypothermia because of their large body surface area relative to their mass.
  • In particular, their head size has the largest body surface area in the entire body.

Option B: Lesser subcutaneous fat

  • In neonates, less subcutaneous fat is one of the reasons that they are prone to develop hypothermia. This subcutaneous fat is specifically less in preterm infants.
  • More brown and white fat protects them against lower core temperatures.

Option C: Larger head size compared to rest of the body

  • Large head size predisposes the newborn to hypothermia, increasing morbidity and mortality.
  • During rewarming and selective head-warming are also implied.

questions.text: A mother brings her 16-year-old daughter to gynaecology outdoors, complaining that her daughter is not having her first menstrual cycle. A doctor examines the girl and notes she has developing breasts. She also has the growth of pubic and axillary hair. The doctor reassures the mother and guides her about the time duration between breast development and initiation of the menstruation cycle. What is the normal duration that is noticed between these events?
questions.solution:
Option B: 2 years later

  • Menarche usually occurs 2-2.5 years after the thelarche. Menarche is the first menstrual period in a young female. It typically occurs between the ages of 10 and 16.
  •  Menarche usually occurs when females are undergoing Tanner stage IV
  • The average interval from the development of breast buds to the onset of menarche is 2-2.5 years.
  •  In the first years after menarche, there are anovulatory cycles which may constitute 50% of cycles. Most cycles are between 21 and 45 days and last between 2 and 7 days. 
  • Puberty and menarche result from changes in the hormone levels, mainly estrogens, androgens and progestogens. These are secreted in increasing amounts from the ovaries and adrenal glands.

Option A: 1 year later

  • The first menstrual cycle should be started after 2 to 2.5 years of thelarche.
  • It is considered abnormal if it appears within one year of breast development.

Option C: 6 months later

  • During this period, the female is going through a stage of pubarche which is the development of pubic and axillary hair.

Option D: 4 years later

  • The appearance of menarche after 4 years of breast development is quite late, and primary amenorrhea should be investigated.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child is brought to the OPD by his parents due to concerns of delayed speech, constipation, and difficulty concentrating for one month. The child has normal developmental milestones. His mother also complains that he does not play with other kids. Upon examination, he had trouble communicating and was very anxious. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in the child?
questions.solution:
Option A: Autism spectrum disorder

  • A male child presents to the doctor with delayed speech, constipation, and difficulty concentrating for 1 month. The child has normal developmental milestones. His mother also complains that he does not play with other kids. On examination, he has trouble communicating and is very anxious. This scenario suggests that the child has autism spectrum disorder.
  • Autistic disorder
    • Qualitative impairment of social behaviour.
    • Impairment of communication skills.
    • Stereotypic & restricted behaviour
    • Onset before 3 years.
    • More common in boys.
  • Most common presentations include lack of eye contact, trouble communicating, delayed speech, delayed learning skills, and seizures in some cases.
  • Since there is no cure for autism spectrum disorder, diagnosing early for better treatment is crucial.

Option B: ADHD

  • Attention, deficit hyperactivity disorder, is one of the most common neurodevelopmental disorders of childhood, and its onset is before the age of 12.
  • In this disorder, a child might have trouble focusing on something or excess movements that are not fitting to the setting. Common features include lack of concentration, impulsivity and hyperactivity.

Option C: Mental retardation

  • Mental retardation, now known as an intellectual disability, refers to sub-normal IQ.
  • It is a cognitive disorder that is present in 2% to 3% of the population.

Option D: Specific learning disability

  • It is a condition with persistent impairment in reading (dyslexia), writing (dysgraphia) and arithmetic (dyscalculia) skills in an individual with preserved cognition, vision, hearing and adequate opportunities.
  • It is typically diagnosed in early school-aged children. In some cases, it is not recognisable until adulthood.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents a firm elevated nodular lesion with a greyish crust on his pinna, as shown in the image below. On examination, the swelling has exquisite tenderness with digital compression, out of proportion to its size. What shall be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Winkler's Nodule

  • Winkler’s Nodule (Chondro-dermatitis Nodularis Chronica Helicis) is benign nodular growth usually occurring on the rim of the helix in older men.
  • It is a firm elevated nodular lesion with a greyish crust on the surface.
  • It causes exquisite tenderness with digital compression, out of proportion to its size.
  • It is caused by a combination of sun damage and pressure. Sun damage weakens and thins the skin. The thinned skin and cartilage are damaged by pressure.
  • This must be differentiated from other disorders, such as basal cell carcinomas.
  • It occurs mostly in men above 40 years of age. Standard therapy is the local excision or carbon dioxide laser vaporization. Other treatment includes corticosteroid for pain relief and requires full-thickness excision, including a wedge of cartilage.
  • The cause of chondro-dermatitis nodularis chronica helices is unknown.

Option A: Keloid

  • It may occur after trauma or piercing of the ear for ornaments. The usual sites are the lobule or helix.

  • Surgical excision of the keloid results in recurrence.

  • Recurrence of a keloid can be avoided by pre- and postoperative radiation with a total dose of 600–800 rad delivered in four divided doses. Some prefer local injection of steroids after excision.

Option B: Furuncle

  • Furuncle (Localized Acute Otitis Externa). A furuncle is a staphylococcal infection of the hair follicle. As the hair is confined only to the cartilaginous part of the meatus, furuncle is seen only in this part of the meatus.

  • Usually single, the furuncles may be multiple.

  • Patients usually present with severe pain and tenderness.

  • Preauricular lymph nodes (anterior, posterior, and inferior) may also be enlarged and tender.

  • Treatment in early cases, without abscess formation, consists of systemic antibiotics, analgesics, and local heat.

  • If an abscess has formed, there is a need for incision and drainage to be done.

Option D: Squamous Cell Carcinoma Pinna:

  • The site of preference is the helix. It can present as a painless nodule or an ulcer with raised everted edges.

  • Metastases to regional lymph nodes occur very late.

  • It is more common in males in their fifties who had prolonged exposure to direct sunlight.

  • Fair-complexioned people are more prone.

  • Treatment. Small lesions without nodal metastases are excised locally with 1 cm of the surrounding healthy area.

  • Large lesions of the pinna or those coming within 1 cm of the external auditory canal and lesions with the presence of nodal metastases may require total amputation of the pinna.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male came to ENT OPD complaining of dizziness while waking up from bed. The patient has coronary artery disease and hyperlipidemia and using statin+ ARBs. On physical examination, the patient has a pulse of 95/min with a blood pressure of 153/81 mmHg. The doctor wanted a physical exam, so he made the patient lie supine on the bed and tilted the patient’s head backward by 60°. What will be the position of the lateral semicircular canal now?
questions.solution:
Option A: Horizontal position

  • The above given is a case of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
  • In the supine position, if the patient turns his head backward by 60° lateral semi-circular canal is in a horizontal position.

Lateral semicircular canal:

  • It may be known as a horizontal canal, but it is not horizontal.
  • It is at an angle of 30° to the horizontal line.
  • In the supine position, it will turn backward further by another 90°.

The horizontal position of the lateral semicircular canal:

  • Supine- ask the patient to turn his head backward by 60°.
  • Sitting- ask the patient to bend his head forwards by 30°.

Option B: Vertical position of lateral semicircular canal

  • Supine- ask the patient to bend his head forwards by 30°.
  • Sitting- ask the patient to turn his head backward by 60°.

Option C: Lateral position

  • It may be known as a horizontal canal, but it is not horizontal.
  • It is at an angle of 30° to the horizontal line.
  • In the supine position, it will turn backward further by another 90°.

Option D: No change in position

  • This option is incorrect because option A horizontal position is the correct statement.

questions.text: An ENT professor was lecturing about the inner ear. He explained the structure and various functions of the inner ear. He emphasized the control of angular acceleration and deceleration movements. The structure involved is cristae. Where are cristae seen?
questions.solution:
Option C: Semicircular canal

  • It is a correct statement
  • The crista ampullaris is the sensory organ of rotation. They are found in the ampullae of each of the semicircular canals of the inner ear, meaning that there are three pairs in total. The function of the crista ampullas is to sense angular acceleration and deceleration. Cristae are located in the ampullated ends of the three semicircular canals.
  • These receptors respond to angular acceleration.
  • Peripheral receptors are of two types:
    • Crista: They are located in the ampullated ends of the three semicircular ducts. These receptors respond to angular acceleration.
    • Maculae: They are located in otolith organs (i.e., utricle and saccule).
  • The cristae respond to waterborne vibrations and pressure changes
  • Each canal has a terminal dilation, or ampulla, that contains a specialized surface sensory organ called the crista. In aggregate, the sensory portion is referred to as crista ampullaris. Each crista is lined by specialized sensory hair cells that send continuous tonic neural signals to the vestibular nucleus.
  • Inner ear malformations can be associated with both hereditary and nonhereditary SNHL. Sporadic malformations may occur by presumed localized teratogenesis during the early development of the inner ear as a result of putative toxic insults during the first 8 weeks of gestation. The cause is rarely determined.

Option A: Utricle

  • It is a false statement
  • The utricle lies in the posterior part of the bony vestibule. It receives the five openings of the three semicircular ducts. It is also connected to the saccule through the utriculosaccular duct. The sensory epithelium of the utricle is called the macula and is concerned with linear acceleration and deceleration.

Option B: Saccule

  • It is a false statement.
  • The saccule also lies in the bony vestibule, anterior to the utricle and opposite the stapes footplate. Its sensory epithelium is also called macula. Its exact function is not known. It probably also responds to linear acceleration and deceleration. In Ménière’s disease, the distended saccule lies against the stapes footplate and can be surgically decompressed by perforating the footplate.

Option D: Otolith membrane

  • It is a false statement.
  • On Earth, the gravitational force acts on us permanently; hence gravitational acceleration needs to be detected continuously. This is the role of the otolith organs. They additionally detect all linear accelerations. The otolith organs are designed such that they detect the accelerations and send encoded signals to the brain that processes this information. The otolith organs saccule and utricle are relatively orthogonally oriented to each other, with the utricle relatively horizontal and the saccule predominantly vertical (tangential in the head).

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to ENT OPD with complaints of facial weakness for 2 weeks. After investigation and examinations, the patient was diagnosed with Bell's palsy after excluding all other causes. He was on steroids for 2 weeks, but it showed no improvement. What would be the next best step in managing patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option D: Electrophysiological nerve testing

  • This is a case of Bell's palsy caused to due facial nerve injury.
  • For 2 weeks, the patient has been on steroids; an ENoG on day 14 can help us know if there is a faster degeneration of the nerve and predict the prognosis.
  • This test's most clinically helpful use is to objectively assess facial nerve function once spontaneous motion is lost in acquired paralysis or if it had never been seen in congenital paralysis. The test is not an absolute predictor for return of function but, when used with clinical information, makes the assessment of prognosis more rational.
  • ENoG is most useful between the 4th and 21st day of the onset of complete paralysis.
  • The fall of summating potential to 10% of the normal value indicates surgical decompression (90% degeneration).
  • Degeneration of 90% occurring in the first 14 days indicates poor recovery of function.
  • A faster rate of degeneration occurring in <14 days has a poorer prognosis.

Medical management of Bell's palsy

Steroids:

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If the patient reports within 1 week, the adult prednisolone dose is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. The patient is seen on the fifth day.
  • If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered in the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and tapered in the next 5 days (a total of 20 days).
  • Contraindications to using steroids include pregnancy, diabetes, hypertension, peptic ulcer, pulmonary tuberculosis, and glaucoma.

Surgical Treatment:

  • Nerve decompression relieves pressure on the nerve fibers and thus improves nerve microcirculation.
  • Vertical and tympanic segments of the nerve are decompressed. Some workers have suggested total decompression, including labyrinthine segment by postural and middle fossa approach.
  • 80-90% of the patients recover fully. 10-15% recover incompletely and may be left with some stigmata of degeneration. Recurrent facial palsy may not recover fully.
  • The prognosis is good in incomplete Bell’s palsy (95% complete recovery) and in those where clinical recovery starts within 3 weeks of onset (75% complete recovery).

 Option A: Physiotherapy

  • It is a false statement.
  • For 2 weeks, the patient has been on steroids; an ENoG on day 14 can help us know if there is a faster degeneration of the nerve and predict the prognosis.

Option B: Stop steroids abruptly

  • It is a false statement.
  • For 2 weeks, the patient has been on steroids; an ENoG on day 14 can help us know if there is a faster degeneration of the nerve and predict the prognosis.

Option C: Vasodilators

  • It is a false statement.

  • For 2 weeks, the patient has been on steroids; an ENoG on day 14 can help us know if there is a faster degeneration of the nerve and predict the prognosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male comes to the otolaryngology department with a complaint of chronic headache for 4 months. He also had a 2-week history of insensitivity of the leg. He went to the neurology department with these complaints initially. MRI and magnetic resonance venography (MRV) revealed right disseminated sinus thrombosis. On physical examination, the vitals are within normal range. The right tympanic membrane was hyperemic, and the pain and oedema were present at the mastoid apex with palpation. The neurological examination revealed bilateral pupil stasis and insensitivity of the left lower extremity. Intravenous meropenem 2 g BD was administered. The patient was operated on 8th day of his admission. A right simple mastoidectomy was performed. All mastoid air cells were infected. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lateral sinus thrombosis

  • The above given is a case of lateral sinus thrombosis.
  • Chronic headache, insensitivity of leg, MRI and MRV findings are suggestive.
  • Clinical features are;
    • Pallor
    • Headache
    • Picket fence fever: Temperature does not come to normal baseline.
    • Griesinger’s sign: Griesinger’s sign is mastoid tenderness and oedema secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emissary vein.
  • Intravenous antibacterial therapy.
  • Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus.
  • A complete cortical or modified radical mastoidectomy is performed, depending on whether sinus thrombosis has complicated acute or chronic middle ear disease.
  • The bony sinus plate is removed to expose the dura and drain the per sinus abscess.
  • An infected clot or intrasinus abscess may be present and must be drained.
  • In such cases, sinus dura is already destroyed or may appear unhealthy and discolored with granulations on its surface.
  • Dura is incised, and the infected clot and abscess are drained.
  • Before incision in the dura, the sinus is packed, above and below, by inserting a pack between the bone and dura of the sinus to control bleeding.
  • Healthy red clots beyond the abscess at either end of the sinus should not be disturbed.
  • The pack is removed 5-6 days post-operatively and wound secondarily closed.
  • Ligation of Internal Jugular vein:
  • It is rarely required these days.
  • It is indicated when antibiotic and surgical treatment has failed to control embolic phenomenon and rigors, or tenderness and swelling along the jugular vein are spreading.
  • Anticoagulant Therapy: It is rarely required and used when thrombosis extends to the cavernous sinus.
    • Supportive treatment: Repeated blood transfusions may be required to combat anemia and improve the patient's resistance.

Option A: Cavernous sinus thrombosis

  • This potentially devastating complication is seen where veins around the paranasal sinuses are congested during ARS and become phlebitic, with propagation centrally. This can lead to cavernous sinus thrombophlebitis, causing sepsis and multiple cranial nerve involvement.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Bilateral ptosis.
    • Proptosis and chemosis.
    • Ophthalmic nerve neuralgia.
    • Retro-ocular headache, which can be severe.
    • Complete ophthalmoplegia.
    • Papilledema.
    • Signs of meningeal irritation associated with spiking fevers.
    • Confusion and reduced level of consciousness.
  • Treatment is undertaken in a specialist neurosurgical center. Anticoagulants may be considered, as long as imaging has excluded intracerebral hemorrhage, in conjunction with intravenous antibiotics and/or steroids. Drainage procedures will include attention to the involved paranasal sinuses.

Option B: Brain abscess

  • Brain abscesses are more commonly associated with chronic ear disease but may occur in association with AOM and its complications.
  • They develop in both the temporal lobe and cerebellum.
  • In the setting of acute mastoiditis, the most common causative organism is S. pneumoniae or other non-pneumococcal Streptococcus species.
  • Persistent headaches are the commonest symptom.

Option D: Petrositis

  • Infection may extend to the petrous apex.
  • Patients commonly present with other intracranial complications.
  • Historically, the treatment has been surgical, with a minimum of drainage of the mastoid and, in some centers, decompression of the petrous apex.
  • Resolution of the sixth nerve palsy follows a variable course, from almost instant recovery to take up to 6 weeks.

questions.text: A 35 years old male came to the E.N.T. outpatient department with complaints of fluctuating hearing loss and experienced a sudden onset of spinning sensations and imbalance associated with a ringing in her left ear. The patient also reports progressive left-sided hearing loss and is unable to follow conversations in noisy surroundings. On physical examination patient also complained of hearing the same sound in two different frequencies. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. Which of the following test is confirmatory for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Electrocochleography

  • Electrocochleography-confirmatory test for Meniere's disease measures summating potential (S.P.) vs. action potential (A.P).
  • The above clinical features are seen in the case of Meniere’s disease.
  •  In Meniere's disease, males are affected more than females.
  • Usually, the disease is unilateral, but the other ear may be affected after a few years.
  • The exact cause of Ménière's disease is not yet known.
  • Episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.

Meniere’s disease

  • Meniere’s disease is also known as endolymphatic hydrops.
  • Due to faulty reabsorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac.
  • Unilateral, episodic, fluctuating hearing loss.
  • Tullio’s phenomenon- Vertigo on hearing loud noises.
  • Diplacusis- hearing the same sound in 2 different frequencies.
  • Electrocochleography - confirmatory test for Meniere's disease- it measures summating potential (S.P.) vs action potential (A.P.).
  • In normal ear → SP < 30% AP.
  • In Meniere's disease → S.P.>70%-confirmatory.
  • →SP >45% - indicative

Option A: Tuning fork test

  • Meniere's test indicates sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Rinne's test is positive, absolute bone conduction is reduced in the affected ear, and Weber is lateralized to the better ear.

Option C: Tympanometry

  • It is an acoustic evaluation of the functioning and condition of the middle ear by creating a variation pressure in the middle canal.

Option D: Audiometry

  • P.T.A./pure tone audiometry:
  • There is sensorineural hearing loss.
  • In the early stages, lower frequencies are affected, and the curve is of rising type.
  • When higher frequencies are involved curve becomes flat or a falling type.
  • The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing impairment at that frequency. It is charted in the form of a graph called audiogram. The threshold of bone conduction is a measure of cochlear function.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male presents to the clinic with frontal headache. After the careful assessment, a diagnosis of the frontal sinusitis is made. Sinusitis is the inflammation of the sinuses. These sinuses are pneumatized. The pneumatization of the marked structure mainly begins at?
questions.solution:
Option D: 2 Years after the birth

Sphenoid Sinus:

  • The sphenoid Sinus is recognizable at around the third intrauterine month as an evagination from the spheno-ethmoidal recess, and again a small cavity is found at birth.
  • At the two years of life, the main pneumatization of the sphenoid bone progresses, and at age seven has frequently reached the floor of the Sella.
  • Attains adult size by 15 yrs of age.

Option A: Birth

  • The sphenoid Sinus is recognizable at around the third intrauterine month and pneumatization for this sinus occurs at two years of life.
  • The sphenoid sinus attains adult size by 15 yrs of age.

Option B: 2 weeks after birth

  • The sphenoid Sinus is the structure that is marked above.
  • It attains the pneumatization at the age of the 2 years.

Option C: 2 months after birth

  • By the age of the two years, the pneumatization of the sphenoid sinus takes place.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of nasal bleed 20 minutes ago. He was working in a garden when he suddenly experienced such gush of blood from the nasal cavity. He tried to stop bleed with nasal pressure but bleeding continues. An endoscopy has been ordered. Endoscopy shows bleeding in the woodruff area. Which of the following describes the location of Woodruff's plexus?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posteroinferior part of the nose

Woodruff's Plexus:

  • A nosebleed (epistaxis) usually occurs in the anterior part of the nose from an area known as Kiesselbach's plexus which consists of arteries.
  • Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus in the posterior part and a nosebleed here accounts for only between 5 and 10 per cent of nosebleeds.
  • Older adults are most often affected.
  • Posterior nasal packing is needed for posterior epistaxis.

Option A: Anterosuperior part of the nose

  • Woodruff's plexus is a plexus of veins situated inferior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.
  • It is a site of posterior epistaxis in adults.

Option B: Anteroinferior part of the nose

  • Woodruff's plexus is a plexus of veins situated inferior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate not on the anteroinferior turbinate.

Option D: Posterosuperior part of the nose

  • The Woodruff's plexus which is a site for the posterior nasal bleed is located below the posterior end of the inferior concha, on the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 66-year-old homeless male is brought to the Ophthalmology clinic. On examination, a dense hemorrhage in the posterior chamber of the right eye is found, involving the visual axis. What are the normal anatomical contents of this chamber?
questions.solution:
Option B: Aqueous humour

  • Posterior chamber is the region between the iris and the anterior surface of lens.
  • It contains aqueous humour.
  • The anterior and posterior chambers of the eye are connected through the pupil.

Anterior Chamber: Impact on Product Development | SpringerLink" src="https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-030-76367-1_3/MediaObjects/472416_1_En_3_Fig1_HTML.png" />

Option A: Retinal vessels

  • Retinal vessels are not present in this chamber.
  • No vessel is found.

Option C: Iris

  • Iris is the anterior demarcation of the posterior chamber. It is not a content of posterior chamber.

Option D: All are correct

  • Iris and the retinal vessels are not found in the posterior chamber.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the eye clinic with a complaint of progressive blurring of vision for 3 years. He has a 10-pack-year history of smoking. He has had non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus for 3 years. When should this patient have been screened for Diabetic Retinopathy from the time of his diagnosis of Diabetes?
questions.solution:
Option A: Type 2 DM Immediately

Diabetic Retinopathy Screening

  • The most important risk factor for the development of Diabetic Retinopathy is the duration of Diabetes mellitus.
  • In patients with Diabetes before 30 years of age (most likely Type 1 DM), the incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) after 10 years is 50% and 90% after 30 years.
  • In patients with Type 2 DM, 5% of patients have DR at the time of presentation/diagnosis.
  • Hence suggestions for DR Screening are:
    • Type-1 Diabetes: Within 5 years of diagnosis.
    • Type-2 Diabetes: Immediate fundus examination.
    • Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) & gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM): Immediate.

Option B: Type 2 DM Within 6 months

  • Screening for DR in patients of type 2 diabetes mellitus should be done at the time of diagnosis, not within 6 months.

Option C: Type 2 DM Within 1 year

  • Waiting for one year for screening for DR is not appropriate as patients could have developed the DR at the time of diagnosis.

Option D: Type 1 DM Within one week

  • The screening for DR in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus should be started within 5 years of diagnosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents to the Pediatric outpatient department with a painless nodule on the inner surface of his lower eyelid. Her mother reported that it started as a small lesion, progressively increasing in size over several weeks without any pain in the surrounding area. On physical examination, a lipogranulomatous inflammation is noted. Which of the following do you think is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Chalazion

  • It is a small swelling or lump on the eyelid which presents as a painless nodule due to obstruction of the sebaceous glands in the eyelid.
  • Obstruction of the Zeis or meibomian eyelid glands, due to which thickened secretions lead to blockage of glands, producing a granulomatous inflammatory response.
  • A patient can present with eyelid discomfort from swelling and even eyelid pain in cases of secondary infection.
  • Lipogranulomatous inflammation is usually present.
  • Diagnosis is mostly made clinically based on the eye exam finding of a painless eyelid nodule.
  • In case of recurrent chalazion or seborrheic blepharoconjunctivitis, rule out sebaceous cell carcinoma.
  • Incision and curettage are done from the conjunctival side.
  • Horizontal incisions are avoided to minimize damage to meibomian ducts.

Option A: Fungal infection

  • Fungal keratitis can occur suddenly from an eye injury or using a contact lens.
  • It can cause vision loss without treatment.
  • The risk of fungal infections is associated with an eye injury, eye surgery, chronic eye disease, contact lenses, fungal bloodstream infection, and immunocompromised people.
  • This patient does not present with features of fungal infection.

Option B: Tuberculosis

  • Ocular TB can also involve any part of the eye and can occur with or without evidence of systemic TB.
  • Tuberculosis and viral agents cause infection and associated inflammation but not lipogranulomatous inflammation.

Option D: Viral infection

  • Most viral infection causes conjunctivitis, which is highly contagious, usually due to adenovirus.
  • Symptoms include irritation, photophobia, and watery discharge.
  • There is no lipogranulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented to Eye OPD with complaints of eye discomfort, redness, and foreign body sensations in her eyes for the last 3 weeks. On examination, she was vitally stable, the cornea was clear but dull, the reduced marginal tear film was seen, a string of mucus was seen, and the Schirmer test was 5 mm. rest of the systemic examination was unmarked. She is a known patient with diabetes and hypertension. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Systemic vitamin A deficiency

  • Vitamin A deficiency causes damage to goblet cells.
  • Hence patients present with dry eyes due to a deficiency of mucin.
  • Dry eyes:
    • Not in itself a disease
    • Usually, a symptom of an underlying disease
  • Symptoms of dry eyes:
    • Irritation
    • Feeling of foreign body in the eye
    • Itch
    • General eye discomfort or pain
  • Signs of dry eyes:
    • Lustreless cornea
    • Stringy mucus seen
    • Reduced tear margins
    • Erosions on cornea 
  • Causes of Dry Eye:
    • Aqueous Deficiency
    • Lipid Abnormality
    • Mucin Deficiency
    • Lid problems  
  • Investigations: ​​​​​​​
    • Schirmer's test is less than 5mm severe, 5 to 10 mm mild deficiency, and more than 15mm- normal.
      • Rose Bengal staining can detect mild cases of dry eyes
      • Tear levels of lysozyme and lactoferrin
      • Tear film breakup
      • Tear osmolarity conjunctival impression cytology.
      • If the first 2 positive diagnoses are confirmed
  • Management:
    • Artificial tears
    • Local cyclosporine
    • Mucolytics
    • Local retinoid
    • Punctual occlusion.

Option A: Viral conjunctivitis

  • Viral Conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva due to a viral cause.
  • Signs and symptoms: mild congestion, watery discharge, swelling of the conjunctiva.
  • Usually self-limiting.
  • Highly contagious.

Option B: Bacterial conjunctivitis

  • Bacterial conjunctivitis is inflammation of conjunctiva due to bacterial infection.
  • causative organism: Staphylococcus aureus, Koch-Weeks bacillus, Pneumococcus, Streptococcus.
  • Usually, cause excessive tear production and discharge.
  • Complications: corneal ulcer,  keratitis, blepharitis, dacryocystitis.

Option D: Concretions

  • Collection of cell debris and mucus.
  • Mostly found on palpebral conjunctiva.
  • Sign and symptom: hard yellow mass, lacrimation and foreign body sensation.
  • Treatment: removal under local anaesthesia.  ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A twelve-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by her mother. He has born with congenital cataracts and was soon operated on for these cataracts after birth. Cataract surgery was uneventful, and the patient was left aphakic. Eye tests reveal an area in the visual field that is not visible to the patient. That blind spot appears and disappears with the changing position of the eyes from object to object. This phenomenon is seen in patients using which of the following for the correction of aphakia?
questions.solution:
Option B: Spectacles

  • Some patients, after cataract surgery, are left without a lens.
  • This is called aphakia.
  • To correct refractive errors in aphakia, a 10-dioptre convex lens is required for distance vision and a 13-dioptre for near vision.
  • Such high-power lenses are associated with numerous physical and optical problems.
  • In aphakic spectacles, the light falling at the lens's edge bends towards the lens's centre and does not reach the pupil and is, therefore, not seen. This results in an area of the visual field which is not visible to the patient.
  • A blind spot in the visual field is known as a scotoma.
  • As the edge encircles the lens like a ring, the scotoma formed is ring-shaped.
  • The position of this scotoma is not fixed in the visual field. This is due to the eye's movement against the static spectacle.
  • The resulting scotoma is known as a roving ring scotoma.
  • When an object appears in the corner of the patient's visual field, it is blurred (due to light passing from the side of the spectacle frame). The patient moves his head towards the object to see it clearly. As he turns his head, the object comes to lie in the area of the scotoma and thus disappears from his visual field. As he turns his head further so that the object comes to lie in front of the spectacle, the object reappears again and is clear and sharp. This sudden disappearance and sharp reappearance of the objects is called the jack-in-the-box phenomenon.

Option A: IOL

  • Due to difficulties in the correction of aphakia by spectacles, intraocular lenses are now preferred for the correction of aphakia.
  • The problems faced by this patient are due to aphakic correction by spectacles.

Option C: Contact lens

  • A special contact lens can be used for the correction of aphakia.
  • These can be worn for a month without the need to change.
  • However, intraocular lenses are the preferred modality for aphakic correction.

Option D: None

  • If aphakia is left uncorrected, the patient develops refractive problems.
  • Symptoms include loss of accommodation and problems with near vision.
  • To correct aphakia, spectacles or intraocular lenses are used.
  • The patient's symptoms are suggestive of problems with aphakic spectacles.

questions.text: A fifty-five year old male is admitted to your hospital for a scheduled cataract surgery procedure. His previous medical history is positive for hypertension which is well managed with medications. During surgery, the patient's blood pressure starts to rise uncontrollably. What is the feared complication of hypertension during this surgery?
questions.solution:
Option D: Suprachoroidal hemorrhage

  • Suprachoroidal hemorrhage is characterised by bleeding into the suprachoroidal space due to a ruptured posterior ciliary artery.
  • It can result in the extrusion of intraocular contents leading to expulsive hemorrhage.
  • It is extremely rare (0.04%) with phacoemulsification.
  • Risk factors include advanced age, glaucoma, increased axial length, systemic hypertension, systemic cardiovascular disease, vitreous loss, and larger incision size.
  • Diagnosis needs a high index of suspicion. Warning signs include:
    • Progressive shallowing of the anterior chamber, increased intraocular pressure (IOP), and iris prolapse.
    • Vitreous extrusion, loss or partial obscuration of red reflex and appearance of dark mound behind the pupil.
    • Extrusion of posterior chamber contents into the anterior chamber.
  • Management of suprachoroidal hemorrhage includes:
    • Immediate termination of surgery and suturing of the incisions made.
    • Speed of closure is the most important factor.
    • Diagnosis should be confirmed with the slit lamp as soon as possible.
    • IOP-lowering agents like oral Acetazolamide should be given to manage the IOP spike due to the bleeding within the closed globe.
    • Intensive topical and systemic steroids with postoperative antibiotic cover.
    • Discontinue any NSAIDs, antiplatelets or anticoagulants to prevent rebleeding.
    • Observe for spontaneous absorption for 7-14 days.
    • Drainage may be done after 1-2 weeks if there is no absorption.
    • The prognosis is poor in cases of prolonged cilioretinal occlusion (>14 days).
    • Cataract surgery can be repeated after 2-4 weeks if considered appropriate.

Option A: Glaucoma

  • Glaucoma is a risk factor for suprachoroidal hemorrhage.
  • Patients with hypertension are not at risk of developing glaucoma during ocular surgery.

Option B: Retinal detachment

  • Patients with hypertension are not at risk of developing retinal detachment during ocular surgery.

Option C: Endophthalmitis

  • Uncontrolled diabetes is a risk factor for developing endophthalmitis.
  • Patients with hypertension are not at risk of developing endophthalmitis during ocular surgery.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the eye clinic complaining of blurred vision, painless floaters and photophobia. On ocular examination, the ophthalmologist encounters vitreous that range in severity. There is an absence of cellular activity in the vitreous. The presenting visual acuity is often reduced to 20/40 (mild visual loss). The fundus photographs show documentation of the baseline appearance of retinal lesions. After a complete exam, a diagnosis of Pars planitis was made. The commonest complication that you can expect in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cataract

  • Pars planitis, also known as intermediate uveitis, is an inflammation of the intermediate part of the uvea, which is the vascular layer of the eye. It often affects young adults and is characterized by blurred vision, painless floaters, and photophobia (sensitivity to light).

  • Cataract is the most common complication of Pars planitis in this scenario. Cataract refers to the clouding of the lens in the eye

Other options -

Option A: Glaucoma

  • Glaucoma may be related to uveitis and corticosteroid use.
  • It is a less common early complication.

Option C: Retinal detachment

  • It is a complication in the case of intermediate uveitis.
  • However, it is less common than CME and cataracts.

Option D: Vitreous hemorrhage

  • It rarely occurs as a rare complication can cause traction on the peripheral retina and lead to retinal detachment.
  • It is the extravasation of the blood into the potential space which is formed around the vitreous body.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented to the clinic with the symptoms of acute congestive glaucoma. He has been taking anticonvulsant drugs for seizures, Allopurinol for gout and amiodarone for tachyarrhythmia for a couple of years. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Topiramate

  • Topiramate is an anticonvulsant also used in the treatment of migraine. It can cause acute angle-closure glaucoma with associated myopia due to ciliochoroidal effusion.

Option A: Amiodarone

  • Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication used to treat and prevent several types of cardiac dysrhythmias.
  •  This includes ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and wide complex tachycardia, as well as atrial fibrillation and paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.
  • This drug is not associated with glaucoma.

Option C: Chlorpromazine

  • Chlorpromazine, marketed under Thorazine and Largactil, among others, is an antipsychotic medication.
  • It is primarily used to treat psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia
  • This drug is not associated with glaucoma.

Option D: Allopurinol

  • Allopurinol is a medication used to decrease high blood uric acid levels.
  • It is specifically used to prevent gout, prevent specific types of kidney stones and the high uric acid levels that can occur with chemotherapy.
  •  It is taken by mouth or injected into a vein.
  • This drug is also not associated with glaucoma.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the dermatologic clinic with a history of hair loss in the frontoparietal region for the past few weeks. Her medical history is consistent with depression. Her medication includes sertraline. On examination, hairs are twisted and broken at various distances. There is no erythema, scarring, or scratch marks. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Trichotillomania

  • This patient with hair loss and a history of depression likely has trichotillomania.
  • Trichotillomania is a disorder in which individuals repeatedly pluck hairs from the scalp or other hair-bearing areas. The areas of alopecia may have irregular, bizarre shapes.

The following are important points related to trichotillomania

  • Trichotillomania is a behavioral disorder characterized by compulsive hair pulling.
  • It presents as a pattern of hair loss, often bizarre, with no clear biological or overt traumatic explanation.
  • Hair is plucked most frequently from one frontoparietal region.
  • This results in a patch of hair loss, often in a bizarre or angular pattern, in which the hairs are twisted and broken at various distances from the clinically normal scalp.

Option B: Alopecia areata

  • It is well-defined round to oval patches of nonscarring hair loss with characteristic exclamation hair is present.

Option C: Telogen effluvium

  • Diffuse hair loss from the scalp due to the underlying systemic cause.

Option D: Tinea capitis

  • It presents with patchy loss of hair with fine scaling (grey patch), broken hair remnants (black dot), or painful boggy swelling with discharge (kerion) and thick adherent crusting(favus).

questions.text: A 13-year male child presents with complaints of fever and malaise associated with a skin rash on hands followed by thighs and trunk. Rash gives the appearance of a dew drop on a rose petal. Which of the following is the characteristic skin lesion in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vesicle

  • A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation less than 1 cm in diameter that contains fluid (clear, serous, or hemorrhagic) and is often grouped.

Chickenpox:

  • Also known as Varicella Zoster/Chicken Pox Virus
  • Portal of entry: Respiratory tract/conjunctiva
  • SAR (secondary attack Rate): >90%
  • Infectivity period:2 days before and 5 days after
  • Characteristics of rash
    • Centripetal Rash
    • Dew Drop Appearance on Rose petal
    • Pleomorphism seen

Option A: Abscess

  • An abscess is a collection of pus in any part of the body. In most cases, the area around an abscess is swollen and inflamed.

Option B: Nodule

  • A solid, palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is more than 0.5 cm in diameter; some would define it as being greater than 1 cm. It may consist of fluid, other extracellular material (e.g., amyloid), and inflammatory or neoplastic cells.

Option D: Pustule

  • A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. It may occur within a pilosebaceous follicle, a sweat duct, or, less often, on glabrous skin. Most commonly due to infections, but some eruptions typically cause sterile pustules.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to the clinic with the complaint of rash for the past 2 days. She denies any fever or drug intake. On examination, flaccid bullae over the skin and oral cavity are noted. Histopathology shows intraepidermal blister with acantholytic cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pemphigus vulgaris

  • It is an Autoimmune condition
  • IgG Antibodies are formed against Desmoglein (Desmosomal protein)
  • Desmoglein is present within the epidermis resulting in Intra-epidermal bullae.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is the most common type of pemphigus.
  • Histology shows intraepidermal acantholytic blisters and flaccid bullae over the skin and oral erosions.

Option A: Pemphigoid

  • Pemphigoid: Tense bullae
  • Flaccid bullae are present in pemphigus vulgaris.

Option B: Erythema Multiforme

  • Target lesions are seen on distal extremities.
  • If the mucosa is involved, it is called Epidermal Multiforme Major

Option D: Dermatitis herpetiformis

  • Extremely pruritic vesiculo-papular lesions over extensors
  • Associated with celiac disease.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy visits the clinic with a complaint of discolored patches on his cheek for the last four months. He has a history of allergic rhinitis. On examination, small hypopigmented scaly macules with intact sensations are found on the cheek. The rest of the body is spared. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pityriasis alba

This patient, with small hypopigmented scaly macules on the cheek having intact sensations and a history of atopy (allergic rhinitis), most likely suffers from pityriasis alba.

  • It is a type of dermatitis.
  • Occurs predominantly in children (3-16 years). Both sexes are equally susceptible.
  • The typical Lesion is rounded, oval, or irregular plaque, red, pink, or skin in color, and has fine lamellar or branny scaling.
  • Initially, there is erythema with minimal crusting
  • Later, erythema subsides, and persistent fine scaling with hypopigmentation develops
  • History of atopy is mostly present

Option A: Pityriasis Rosea

  • Flu-like symptoms occur 1-2 weeks before the appearance of a rash
  • Herald patch, initial Lesion that is characterized by a single ovoid macule with a slightly raised border and a central salmon-colored clearing zone
  • Collarette scaling is seen
  • Secondary eruptions with a Christmas tree pattern on the back

Option B: Pityriasis Versicolor

  • Superficial fungal infection
  • Scaly macule shows both hyper- and hypopigmentation
  • Seen on the upper trunk and shoulders commonly
  • Most cases are seen in summers or after significantly prolonged sunlight exposure.

Option C: Indeterminate leprosy

  • A very early form of leprosy usually progresses to one of the major types
  • Non-scaly
  • Epidermal atrophy, wrinkling
  • Slight hypoesthesia is found
